When logged into Pleo, head to the Setti: When logged into Pleo, head to the Settings page and choose Xero from the Accounting list. Follow the onscreen instructions, which include granting Pleo access to your Xero data. It's a quick process and you'll only need to do it once.

How do I enable the Direct Feed?: How do I enable the Direct Feed?
When logged into Pleo, head to the Setti: When logged into Pleo, head to the Settings page and select the Accounting tab. Xero will show as "Connected" to Pleo and underneath will be a Direct Feed option. Once that's ticked, head to Xero and refresh your Pleo back account page. Now, Pleo will automatically send statement data to Xero, twice a day. There's a lot more on how it works here.

Pleo is an out-of-the-box business spend:
Pleo is an out-of-the-box business spending solution that offers smart payment cards and automated expense reports for employees, enabling them to buy the things they need for work while giving finance teams full control and visibility of all company spending. 

Pleo catches receipts on-the-go, automatically categorises expenses based on previous behaviour and eliminates the need for manual expense reports.¬†

17,000+ companies are using Pleo across six markets (UK, Denmark, Sweden, German, Ireland, Spain). In 2020, Pleo was marked as a potential billion-dollar EU company by GP Bullhound.
Pleo was founded in early 2015 by fintec: Pleo was founded in early 2015 by fintech veterans Jeppe Rindom and Niccolo Perra, who met while working at the Danish startup success, Tradeshift. The Pleo team is 300+ people based in Copenhagen, London Stockholm, Berlin & Madrid.
The company is financed by Stripes (back: The company is financed by Stripes (backers of Monday.com, Upwork and Blue Apron); Kinnevik (portfolio includes: Zalando, Betterment, Babylon Health, Home24, Westwing and Tele2); Creandum (investors in over 60 companies including Spotify, Tictail, iZettle, Edgeware and Vivino); Seedcamp (Hopin, Revolut, Wise) and Founders A/S (owned by Kirkbi A/S, Anders Holck Povlsen and the Oticon Foundation).

Many of us have dreamed (‚Ä¶ or still dream!) of becoming a professional football player. Jonas Linn√© found an alternative way to make that dream come true.
He‚Äôs the CFO at live score app Forza F: He‚Äôs the CFO at live score app Forza Football. They bring you the latest soccer results and data as it happens, but they also want to make the beautiful game more welcoming for all. That‚Äôs why they‚Äôve put a big focus on ramping up coverage of women‚Äôs matches and grassroots games too.
With the help of Pleo, Jonas and the tea: With the help of Pleo, Jonas and the team can focus on their big goals¬† ‚Äì and not tedious expense management.
In essence, Forza Football is a live sco: In essence, Forza Football is a live score app for football results.
Actually, it just happened to become an: Actually, it just happened to become an app, as that was the cool new thing back then. Judging from our three million monthly users ‚Äì I‚Äôd say it worked!
Access to football results at the highes: Access to football results at the highest level is relatively good, but it‚Äôs not the same for grassroots games.
That‚Äôs where we want to be. In our opi: That‚Äôs where we want to be. In our opinion, it should be as easy to follow a junior girls‚Äô game as it is to keep up to date with El Cl√°sico¬†between Madrid and Barcelona.
So what are we doing to change that?: So what are we doing to change that?
Lately, we launched a new reporter tool,: Lately, we launched a new reporter tool, enabling any team or club to share their match action immediately with the world. This means football fans can follow their friends or family members in the same app as they follow Lionel Messi, Marta, Megan Rapinoe or Harry Kane.
We‚Äôve seen the impact on women‚Äôs foo: We‚Äôve seen the impact on women‚Äôs football too: With small tweaks, like showcasing a selection of women‚Äôs teams (not just men‚Äôs), we have doubled the number of users who follow women‚Äôs teams in the Forza app.
How did you end up at Forza Football?: How did you end up at Forza Football?
As the football nerd that I am, I had al: As the football nerd that I am, I had already been using the Forza app for many years. Also, tech start-ups have always interested me. When I saw Forza Football were looking for someone to manage the company‚Äôs finances, it felt like a chance I had to take.
Our CEO Patrik ran into the Pleo team at: Our CEO Patrik ran into the Pleo team at an event organized by our joint investor, Creandum. He could see its value straight away.
When he got back to the office, he didn‚: When he got back to the office, he didn‚Äôt have to do much to convince us.
How has Pleo changed Forza Football‚Äôs: How has Pleo changed Forza Football‚Äôs way of working?
A basic idea we have within the company: A basic idea we have within the company is that we want to manage through values, rather than policies. This, of course, comes with some great challenges, but it also creates trust internally. Pleo has made this possible.
‚ÄúWe manage through values ‚Äì rather t: ‚ÄúWe manage through values ‚Äì rather than policies. Pleo makes that possible.‚Äù
Today, with a Pleo card in the hand of e: Today, with a Pleo card in the hand of every employee, the whole team feels a completely different sense of ownership of company expenses.
There‚Äôs always a person behind every e: There‚Äôs always a person behind every expense. That transparency means that all employees take greater responsibility to make sure that everything is handled correctly.
Can you remember an a-ha moment an emplo: Can you remember an a-ha moment an employee had with Pleo?
A colleague was booking a flight ticket: A colleague was booking a flight ticket and was double-charged by the airline.
Since the payment was made with his own: Since the payment was made with his own Pleo card, he felt a personal responsibility.
So instead of just dumping the issue on: So instead of just dumping the issue on the finance department, he contacted the airline himself to investigate if it was fraud. It wasn‚Äôt, but more importantly; it was great to see him taking responsibility like that.
What are Forza Football‚Äôs biggest spen: What are Forza Football‚Äôs biggest spending challenges?
Almost all our challenges are linked to: Almost all our challenges are linked to the company‚Äôs quick growth.
With more and more people joining the te: With more and more people joining the team, it simply became unsustainable to have one credit card being passed around. When questions like ‚Äúwho has the credit card?‚Äù started appearing on Slack, it was the last straw.
‚ÄúWhen questions like ‚Äúwho has the cr: ‚ÄúWhen questions like ‚Äúwho has the credit card?‚Äù started appearing on Slack, it was the last straw.‚Äù
Previously, we had to wait for the bank: Previously, we had to wait for the bank statement to arrive each month ‚Äì making it absolutely impossible to predict our spending. With Pleo, I can keep track in real-time.
How did you pitch Pleo to the team?: How did you pitch Pleo to the team?
Our employees are extremely familiar wit: Our employees are extremely familiar with a broad range of digital tools and services. That makes them very picky about the new products they use!
Every expenses system I‚Äôve used before: Every expenses system I‚Äôve used before has had a strong focus on the administrator.
Pleo, on the other hand, puts the user a: Pleo, on the other hand, puts the user at the centre.
‚ÄúYou pay. You get a notification. You: ‚ÄúYou pay. You get a notification. You snap the receipt. You‚Äôre done.‚Äù

Above all, Pleo saves me from unnecessar: Above all, Pleo saves me from unnecessary paperwork and chasing lost receipts around the office. Previously that stole heaps of time from my actual job.
Thanks to the individual limits, we can: Thanks to the individual limits, we can proactively monitor how much each employee spends, without making them feel controlled or under surveillance.

What is the next big thing for Forza Foo: What is the next big thing for Forza Football?
Our main focus is always on making the w: Our main focus is always on making the world of football open and more accessible to everyone. Therefore, we want to make sure that women‚Äôs football gets the same excellent level of coverage from us that the men‚Äôs game gets.
But so far we are only scratching the su: But so far we are only scratching the surface.

To keep being a positive influence on th: To keep being a positive influence on the game, we must continue to grow. We have only just begun.

Good financial planning and accounting practices are key to running a successful business. You know that already. But you also know that these involve tasks that are time-consuming and repetitive, meaning they often aren‚Äôt given the focus that they deserve.

Spotting the difference between some acc: Spotting the difference between some accounting tools can be tricky, but it‚Äôs going to help you nail down which one is right for you. The specific features you choose to prioritise will depend on where exactly your business is in its growth cycle and what you need from the software.
Here are some questions to ask when choo: Here are some questions to ask when choosing an accounting tool.
Cloud-first tools are usually accessible: Cloud-first tools are usually accessible on any device with an internet connection. They will often have dedicated mobile and desktop apps and you may be able to use some directly through a browser.
The fact that all the information is sto: The fact that all the information is stored in the cloud means it is easy for business owners to give access to the tool to those in the company that need it, as well as to their accountant. The downside is that as the number of users with access to the tool increases, so too may the cost of the product.
Scalable and adaptable tools grow with y: Scalable and adaptable tools grow with your business, ensuring your company won‚Äôt be held back by software that is no longer fit for purpose.
Many of the tools below offer options fo: Many of the tools below offer options for organisations at different stages of growth, from micro-businesses with one employee to medium-sized companies. That said, some tools will be more suited to small companies, and others to firms with hundreds of employees.

No single tool on its own will fulfil al: No single tool on its own will fulfil all of your business needs. Because of this, it‚Äôs important that all your tools can communicate and work together; simplifying your processes.

Choosing tools with efficient support te: Choosing tools with efficient support teams can ensure that should anything go wrong, you‚Äôll easily be able to get things up-and-running again. This is essential if you want to stop your tools getting in the way of your growing business. This is also a must for those who lack technical knowledge.

Match up the type of support offered with what works best for your team: some people want to hear a human voice when they‚Äôre struggling and up against a deadline. Additionally, some of the tools have resources sections that mention common problems and may allow you to find solutions quickly on your own.
Does the pricing work for your business?: Does the pricing work for your business?

How Your Company Can Start Spending Resp: How Your Company Can Start Spending Responsibly Thanks To Pleo Assurance
Last week, we announced the launch of on: Last week, we announced the launch of one of our most anticipated features to date: Pleo Assurance. For a product built on trust, transparency and decentralisation, it‚Äôs a bold move to launch a feature that allows managers to easily review their employees‚Äô expenses; it could easily be perceived as going against everything we stand for.

Last week, we announced the launch of one of our most anticipated features to date:Pleo Assurance. For a product built on trust, transparency and decentralisation, it‚Äôs a bold move to launch a feature that allows managers to easily review their employees‚Äô expenses; it could easily be perceived as going against everything we stand for. Here‚Äôs why we built it and why we believe it‚Äôs the way forward in enabling companies to spend responsibly and efficiently.
Control is not the way forward: Control is not the way forward
It is widely known that some of the most: It is widely known that some of the most innovative companies today, such as Google and Netflix, have managed to reach astronomical valuations in part due to their employees‚Äô productivity.
In fact, research shows that employees a: In fact, research shows that employees at these companies are on average 40% more productive than employees at other companies.
But how did they get there?: But how did they get there?
As we explained in a previous article, p: As we explained in a previous article, part of the reason for their productivity is that they‚Äôve managed to dramatically reduce organisational drag and processes, which can take up to 25% of employees‚Äô time.
In terms of company spending, removing i: In terms of company spending, removing internal processes and policies might manifest itself in decentralising purchasing and giving every employee a company card, empowering employees to buy what they need for work without asking for permission, or something else.
Whatever the case may be, it‚Äôs clear t: Whatever the case may be, it‚Äôs clear that in order to transition from a company operating on control and policies to one operating without them, there‚Äôs one instrumental element which needs to be in place: trust.
In other words, for decentralised spendi: In other words, for decentralised spending to work, there needs to be a high degree of confidence and trust in place to suppress the need for control.
If you‚Äôre a Pleo customer or you‚Äôve: If you‚Äôre a Pleo customer or you‚Äôve been following our journey for some time, you probably know that trust is part of our DNA; it is one of the core pillars of our product.
In fact, Pleo is built on the idea that: In fact, Pleo is built on the idea that increased trust and empowerment in the workplace leads to happier employees, reduced tedious manual work for everyone and even reduced operating costs.
As an example of our dedication to makin: As an example of our dedication to making trust a central part of our product, we facilitate delegated spending by making it easy, intuitive and free for managers to order Pleo cards for their entire teams.
Our product also helps build trust in ma: Our product also helps build trust in managers and finance teams by being one of the only company spending and expense management tools that allows them to see company expenses as they happen, in real-time.
The second a purchase is made with a Ple: The second a purchase is made with a Pleo card, reviewers and finance teams can see it on their dashboard.
With Pleo, team reviewers and finance de: With Pleo, team reviewers and finance departments alike get detailed information about who made a specific purchase, what the money was spent on, why it was spent and the corresponding receipt.
All of this in real-time and all neatly: All of this in real-time and all neatly organised in their expense view dashboard.
This has proven very powerful in enablin: This has proven very powerful in enabling many companies to decentralise spending and trust their employees to act in the company‚Äôs best interest.
However, what we found after more than t: However, what we found after more than two years of growing our customer base to over 3000, spread across 4 countries, was that the product was missing a tool to enable bigger companies with hundreds or thousands of expenses every day to easily delegate spending and operate on trust.
Finance teams at large companies (and ma: Finance teams at large companies (and many small ones for that matter) simply don‚Äôt have the time to look at each and every expense people in their company make.
Even with tools like real-time overview: Even with tools like real-time overview of spending, we heard from our customers that there was a need for an added layer of safety in the (unlikely) event that the Pleo card is used inappropriately by someone in the company.
As we covered above, the vast majority o: As we covered above, the vast majority of expenses are fine. With Assurance, companies can be sure that a simple, automated system is in place to catch the ones that matter.
This gives finance teams and reviewers t: This gives finance teams and reviewers the gift of time back by not having to review every single expense.
On top of that, Assurance gives addition: On top of that, Assurance gives additional context to employees with the Seen By extension of the feature.
Seen By allows employees to know exactly: Seen By allows employees to know exactly who in the company has seen an expense and its details, giving them peace of mind and time back to focus on what really matters.
Finally, Assurance comes with an Activit: Finally, Assurance comes with an Activity Log for reviewers, which shows all the events on a given expense to better understand its current state (is it approved? not approved? Was additional context asked for? etc.).
This is not the first step we take in en: This is not the first step we take in enabling admins and managers to stay on top of company spending, but it is a big step in enabling companies to spend responsibly.
We‚Äôre very excited to be the only expe: We‚Äôre very excited to be the only expense management and company spending tool to offer a product like Assurance, and we hope you are too.
You can give Pleo a try by signing up fo: You can give Pleo a try by signing up for a free one-month trial here, or learn more about Assurance by registering to our upcoming webinar, ‚ÄúCreate a Healthy Company Spending Culture with Pleo Assurance‚Äú.

When it comes to productivity, these too: When it comes to productivity, these tools could help you create a team of Beethovens.
When are you at your most productive?: When are you at your most productive?
Everyone‚Äôs different. Winston Churchil: Everyone‚Äôs different. Winston Churchill often didn‚Äôt get out of bed until 11am, while Beethoven was writing music from 7am.

Accountants: Why making your business le: Accountants: Why making your business less boring adds up
Believe the hype: flexible working isn‚Ä: Believe the hype: flexible working isn‚Äôt just going to make your accountancy practice better now ‚Äì it‚Äôs going to make it fit for the future. It could be thinking about how long your employees‚Äô workday is, where they‚Äôre working from or even how many of them are sharing a job.
Many of today‚Äôs most successful and am: Many of today‚Äôs most successful and ambitious accountants realise that by being flexible about how their company gets work done, there‚Äôs real potential to develop a more dynamic company.
But there are plenty of challenges accou: But there are plenty of challenges accountants might encounter when trialling more flexible ways of working. Below we‚Äôll tackle not only some of the key benefits of redefining what a ‚Äúday at the office‚Äù looks like ‚Äì but also some of the common pain points that can follow.
Chances are you‚Äôre reading this having: Chances are you‚Äôre reading this having recently put another quarter of reports to bed. Working outside office hours during ‚Äúbusy season‚Äù like that isn‚Äôt a benefit for many accountants, it‚Äôs a necessary evil that clients sometimes take for granted.
So one benefit of flexibility that will: So one benefit of flexibility that will strike a chord for many accountancy practices is the ability to focus productivity when it‚Äôs really needed. This could be broken down into weeks or even months of the year when you know your practice is going to be swamped.
‚ÄúDuring those quieter periods, account: ‚ÄúDuring those quieter periods, accountants can take advantage,‚Äù says Olivia Hill of the Association of Accounting Technicians, ‚Äúon the assumption that when it comes to year end, they‚Äôre much more prepared to put those extra hours when it‚Äôs needed.
Olivia Hill, Chief HR Officer ‚Äì AAT: Olivia Hill, Chief HR Officer ‚Äì AAT
It might be as granular as hours of the: It might be as granular as hours of the day when your firm struggles with a workload from clients in other time zones. With a little give and take on flexibility with your workers, your clients can experience the full suite of your services ‚Äì rather than skeleton staffing there to ‚Äúhold the fort‚Äù until the cavalry arrives at 9am.
By allowing your employees flexibility a: By allowing your employees flexibility at quieter times of the year (shorter work weeks, freedom to leave early) you can achieve more buy-in from workers to give their all at times that are notoriously demanding. Transparency is key though, as employees used to flexibility at other times of the year may bristle when told that those privileges aren‚Äôt as easily available during crunch periods.
The shift in what employees want to be j: The shift in what employees want to be judged on is clear. 89% of workers questioned for an extensive Deloitte survey said that flexible working would boost their productivity, with one AAT (Association of Accounting Technicians) study suggesting that working hours actually increased for more than 20% of workers who switched to flexible routines.
When PwC launched its Flexible Talent Ne: When PwC launched its Flexible Talent Network, which lets applicants detail their preferred work pattern when applying for roles, the company was clear on the commercial benefits that increased flexibility offered.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre likely to see a rise in peopl: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre likely to see a rise in people transitioning in and out of work throughout their careers and those organisations who responsibly support their people to do this will ultimately gain a competitive advantage.‚Äù
Laura Hinton, Chief People Officer ‚Äì P: Laura Hinton, Chief People Officer ‚Äì PwC
For some bosses, that‚Äôs not enough to: For some bosses, that‚Äôs not enough to convince them to break traditional working patterns ‚Äì so it‚Äôs vital to find ways to measure productivity that everyone can agree on. Establish those KPIs and then trust your employees to meet them or go beyond them. Oh, and make note of those times when you know they‚Äôve gone the extra mile. When someone‚Äôs worked late to sign off a key document, send them a note of thanks.
3. Don‚Äôt lose those key staff members: 3. Don‚Äôt lose those key staff members
It‚Äôs not just crucial for accountancy: It‚Äôs not just crucial for accountancy practices to attract the best employees ‚Äì keeping them is equally important. Once employees have experienced flexibility, studies show the majority value it hugely.
As well as flexible hours, supporting em: As well as flexible hours, supporting employees who want to work remotely can be a great way to show you‚Äôre taking their needs into account. We‚Äôve all experienced periods where life admin or personal commitments make our daily commute a nightmare.¬†
But be aware too that flexibility presen: But be aware too that flexibility presents some unique challenges in employee retention. It‚Äôs not uncommon for workers who don‚Äôt do 40 hours a week (or more) in the office to believe they‚Äôre at risk of being passed over for promotion due to decreased visibility.¬†
Managing that fear is not impossible for: Managing that fear is not impossible for bosses: simple changes like video meetings for remote workers can maintain team bonds. Our Head of People, Jessie Scheepers, has written about how to make sure remote working actually, well, works.
The more flexible working options an acc: The more flexible working options an accountancy practice can offer, the more diverse a talent pool it can attract. By being open to new ways of working, you‚Äôre showing that you can find ways to work around people‚Äôs unique situations and preferences.
The classic case of this is parents, par: The classic case of this is parents, particularly mothers, returning to work after a prolonged time away. The vast majority of accountancy and finance professionals believe that flexible working options have helped to improve the representation of women in leadership roles. An instant drop back into the 9-5 might not be what many new parents want, whereas a more personalised pattern could see them more content to be back on duty for your practice.
Wider research says that the accounting: Wider research says that the accounting industry is still struggling with diversifying its workforce. An Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales survey found more than half of accountants had witnessed discrimination in the workplace, with 18% saying they had personally experienced it. Flexible working is one clear way to show a real commitment to doing accounting differently.
Yes, we‚Äôve reached the point of the ar: Yes, we‚Äôve reached the point of the article where we state how important it is to be aware of what millennials want from work.¬†
Flexible working has long been cited as: Flexible working has long been cited as a key motivator for this much-discussed demographic. CBI research says that outside of pay, work-life balance is the top factor in career decisions for 32% of the UK‚Äôs young workers.
Look specifically at finance and the ben: Look specifically at finance and the benefits of being flexible are even clearer. 71% of millennial accountants and finance professionals rate flexible working as important or very important to their career choices.¬†
With so many options available to school: With so many options available to school-leavers and graduates now, it‚Äôs key to maximise all the benefits at your disposal. The idea of accounting as a ‚Äújob for life‚Äù appeals less to millennials than previous generations, but other aspects of flexibility will.
An accountancy practice that asks the qu: An accountancy practice that asks the question ‚Äúwhy not?‚Äù instead of ‚Äúwhy?‚Äù in relation to flexible working can boost its appeal to those potential younger employees. Keep your eye out for how many job ads fail to mention flexible working ‚Äì it could be the thing that makes your notice stand out to a younger jobseeker.
There‚Äôs a fascinating nugget in the ad: There‚Äôs a fascinating nugget in the advice on flexible working drawn up by the ICAEW. ‚ÄúEmployees should be encouraged to pursue their passions‚Ä¶ Value judgements around the reasons why people choose to work flexibly should be avoided.‚Äù
By supporting employees in their interes: By supporting employees in their interests outside of work, whether that‚Äôs hitting the gym before work or volunteering after it, practices can use flexibility to demonstrate trust and support in their workforce.¬†
It can also spark interest in other team: It can also spark interest in other team members and build bonds between employees ‚Äìbefore you know it, there may be a running club operating out of your office that meets at 6am for a jog and is at their desk sorting out forecasts by 7am.
7. Be at the forefront of cultural chang: 7. Be at the forefront of cultural change
Despite all the discussion of the advant: Despite all the discussion of the advantages of flexible working, some workers maintain a fear of even opening the conversation about it with their boss.¬†
Inone poll, a striking 42% of workers sa: Inone poll, a striking 42% of workers said they thought asking about flexible working would have a negative impact on their career. Meanwhile, the ICAEW report on diversity in the workplace found many accountants speaking positively about flexible working but also reporting that managers were failing to lead properly on the issue.
So there‚Äôs an opportunity here to do b: So there‚Äôs an opportunity here to do better, with some campaigns gathering real traction in the UK.
By putting flexible working to the foref: By putting flexible working to the forefront of company values, accountancy practices can bust the myths some people still have around flexible working. And they can do it while working from their kitchen table, or at 11pm on a Friday night, or halfway up the Austrian Alps.
Accountants should embrace flexible work: Accountants should embrace flexible working in order to get the best out of their workers and maximise their business potential. Here's how they can do it.

An expense policy, if it‚Äôs done right,: An expense policy, if it‚Äôs done right, can be one of the most important documents in any business.
But it can feel daunting to start one fr: But it can feel daunting to start one from scratch. Especially if you‚Äôve got plenty on your plate already.
So, we‚Äôve built an Expense Policy Buil: So, we‚Äôve built an Expense Policy Builder that will help you quickly draw up spending guidelines that are tailored to your business.
Ready to start? Scroll down to create yo: Ready to start? Scroll down to create your expense policy.
But if you want a little advice on how t: But if you want a little advice on how to sculpt the perfect expense policy, keep reading.
An expense policy is a vital document fo: An expense policy is a vital document for almost every business.
No matter the size of your business, at: No matter the size of your business, at some point, your team will have to buy things for work.
Whether it‚Äôs for a meeting, a conferen: Whether it‚Äôs for a meeting, a conference, a training event, an online tool or just something for the office, the people you employ will have to make a decision on what's OK to spend for the good of the company.
As the business grows, this becomes hard: As the business grows, this becomes harder to handle. Unless you want to drive a culture of complete trust and transparency at scale like Netflix, having a watertight expense policy can move from a 'nice-to-have' to an essential.
An expense policy is a set of processes: An expense policy is a set of processes and rules that define how your employees can spend company money.
It's not just suggested amounts, but als: It's not just suggested amounts, but also potentially preferred payment methods or providers.
Create an expense policy with Pleo and g: Create an expense policy with Pleo and get spending on track
A typical policy might include things li: A typical policy might include things like the recommended hotel budget per night. Or details on what kind of gifts are OK. Or if your team have to pay for any parking fines they pick up on business journeys.
Nobody knows your team and what expenses: Nobody knows your team and what expenses they accrue better than you.
But create a policy that works well and: But create a policy that works well and you‚Äôll steer good habits, prevent friction and vitally, save money.
Why your team needs a policy: Why your team needs a policy
One obvious point of expense policies is: One obvious point of expense policies is that they make clear the highest amount that people are permitted to spend on something.
This isn‚Äôt just useful for the big spe: This isn‚Äôt just useful for the big spenders on your team, but for everyone ‚Äì a suggested amount can serve as a really useful benchmark for people when they‚Äôre trying to book something like a hotel or purchase a laptop.
Get everyone on the same page: Get everyone on the same page
If they‚Äôre not managed correctly, expe: If they‚Äôre not managed correctly, expenses can cause real friction and a sense of unfairness and dissatisfaction. A company-wide policy can be a great step in establishing the ground rules for everyone, from the Managing Director down.
And if it‚Äôs fair, there will be less t: And if it‚Äôs fair, there will be less temptation to break the rules. Of course Pleo can help with that transparency thanks to our spending limits and insights, but that's for another day.
When you know what people should be spen: When you know what people should be spending, it‚Äôs easier for finance teams and managers to forecast budgets. Reviewing what people are actually spending against the policy can also indicate areas where money can be saved.
If you‚Äôre telling everyone that ¬£15 p: If you‚Äôre telling everyone that ¬£15 per breakfast is fine but nobody spends more than ¬£5, you can look at updating your policy.
Business expense fraud might not be the: Business expense fraud might not be the most comfortable subject to talk about, but it matters. It costs British businesses around ¬£2bn a year according to recent estimates.
An expense policy doesn‚Äôt just set out: An expense policy doesn‚Äôt just set out the ground rules of spending, it means your team can be held accountable if they go against those rules.
How to write a great expense policy: How to write a great expense policy
Our policy builder can help with a lot o: Our policy builder can help with a lot of these points, but it‚Äôs definitely worth taking a look before you dive in.
Keep it concise. This is a document for: Keep it concise. This is a document for everyone, not just your finance team or senior managers. So it needs to be something people can quickly reference.
Get input from your team. You don‚Äôt ne: Get input from your team. You don‚Äôt need to do a company-wide survey (although it might be fun!), but it is a good idea to get as much buy-in from people as possible. Run some of the key numbers past those in your company who can influence others (like team leads) ‚Äì does ¬£80 a night for hotel stays sound good to your senior managers?
Don‚Äôt be too strict. No need to specif: Don‚Äôt be too strict. No need to specify the punishments for anyone who goes against the policy. In simple, plain language, layout the guidelines. In the rare case where someone acts outside of policy, you can decide the best course of action.
Make sure the policy stays relevant. If: Make sure the policy stays relevant. If spending habits change (say because your company expands into a new market or you change suppliers), update the policy accordingly.
Accessibility is key. Old-fashioned expe: Accessibility is key. Old-fashioned expense policies were printed out once and then gathered dust on a shelf somewhere. These days, you want to make sure the policy is saved somewhere online that can be bookmarked and referenced in a second ‚Äì by anyone who needs it.
What you‚Äôll find in the Pleo Expense P: What you‚Äôll find in the Pleo Expense Policy Builder
Travelling for work is vital for many bu: Travelling for work is vital for many businesses ‚Äì but how much are you happy for people to spend? Should they book with price comparison websites? Is there a hotel chain you prefer them to use? Or maybe Airbnb is the best option?
Is breakfast, lunch and dinner covered b: Is breakfast, lunch and dinner covered by company money? If so, how much is allocated to each meal? Don‚Äôt forget the sometimes awkward questions of who pays (the most senior person is a common rule) and how much you can tip (... please do tip though).
We‚Äôre not just talking mileage, althou: We‚Äôre not just talking mileage, although that‚Äôs a vital part of an expense policy for many companies. The transport section of the policy builder also covers rules around flights, taxis and public transport.
The first step for your conference spend: The first step for your conference spending policy is probably going to be deciding how much each person can spend on tickets per year or even per event. Of course prices for these tickets can change, so it can be a good idea to set a price range here.
The data shows just how much business sp: The data shows just how much business spending in recent times has focused on remote work set-ups. It‚Äôs not just the hardware that your WFH army need, it‚Äôs ergonomic furniture, decent lighting and software to help them collaborate better.
Keeping clients and team members sweet i: Keeping clients and team members sweet is always a good use of your money ‚Äì but how much is the right amount to spend each year? And what about presents for your own team, when they hit a life milestone‚Ä¶ or when you just want to show them you care?
Now that you know what it takes to build: Now that you know what it takes to build a great expense policy, you‚Äôre probably itching to create one.

Expense management is the way that a business makes, tracks and audits the spending that is needed to make a business run. It covers everything from travel expenses through to software subscriptions, and is an essential part of every company ‚Äì no matter its size.
Every company has its own methods for tr: Every company has its own methods for tracking expenses that is tailored to the way that particular business operates. Since no two companies‚Äô spending needs will be identical, neither will their expense management process.
Expense management can be a difficult pr: Expense management can be a difficult process, especially when relying on older (more analogue) methods of bookkeeping. Historically, expense management has been a patchwork of different, often inefficient, methods of logging spend, through a combination of spreadsheets, scanned receipts and paper invoices.
The more employees you have ‚Äì and the: The more employees you have ‚Äì and the more geographically spread out they are ‚Äì the more operationally difficult this process becomes. This can lead to a long and time-consuming paper trail, with small mistakes cascading into much bigger issues.
This is why having a reliable expense ma: This is why having a reliable expense management system is essential.
Even though there are countless ways tha: Even though there are countless ways that businesses manage their expenses, all of these methods essentially break down into two categories: Manual and Automated.
Manual expense reporting is the way expe: Manual expense reporting is the way expenses have traditionally been done, and it refers to expense management techniques that are mostly processed by hand through repetitive work. This includes using outdated or low-level software that does little more than move things from paper to the screen.
Automated expense reporting, on the othe: Automated expense reporting, on the other hand, is when the routine and menial aspects of expense management are processed automatically, via an application. This increases the efficiency of expense management greatly, freeing up accountants‚Äô time to work on more productive and critical roles. Automated expense reporting also reduces the risk of error and fraud as there is less opportunity for data to be affected by a person.
While most companies nowadays are alread: While most companies nowadays are already seeing massive benefits from automated expense management, there are many businesses that are yet to make to transition.

Advancements in payment technology, busi: Advancements in payment technology, business processes, employee behaviour and compliance requirements are changing how company spending is done. It‚Äôs time to say goodbye to expense reports.
This post also appeared in a shorter ver: This post also appeared in a shorter version on the Xero official blog, written by our CEO Jeppe Rindom.
It‚Äôs that day of the month again‚Ä¶ ex: It‚Äôs that day of the month again‚Ä¶ expense reports are due.
By now, we all know the (boring) drill:: By now, we all know the (boring) drill: Gather all your physical receipts, fill out the expense report form, get it approved by your manager and then, one day, maybe, hopefully‚Ä¶ get your money reimbursed.
All this in an era where it‚Äôs common p: All this in an era where it‚Äôs common practice to video chat with someone on the other side of the world (for free); or where amazing apps like Google Photos recognise any kind of object in our photos. Yet here we are, still filling out expense report forms‚Ä¶
I felt this pain for years as CFO of Tra: I felt this pain for years as CFO of Tradeshift. As the company grew faster and faster, so did everyone‚Äôs frustration about the amount of time lost compiling expense reports, as well as the number of people sharing company cards. Our employees hated the process, and my finance team shared their frustration. It was clear that collectively, we all spent too much time chasing missing receipts and trying to understand where each transaction came from.
I thought there had to be a better way.
Analysing the problem, we realised that: Analysing the problem, we realised that before anyone could successfully solve the expense reporting and spending problem, there were two major prerequisites that needed to be fulfilled:
Having a simple, widely accepted payment: Having a simple, widely accepted payment method for everyone, everywhere: Employees need to be equipped with a simple payment method that is accepted everywhere in the world. It would make them much more productive and get rid of shared cards, helping finance teams better understand the origin of each transaction.
Enabling a real-time transaction overvie: Enabling a real-time transaction overview: To guarantee peace of mind when giving more cards to employees, managers and finance departments should be able to control each employee‚Äôs spending and see company-related expenses in real-time. This would enable them to have a good overview of company and employee spend, be compliant and drive responsible spending cultures.
Luckily, we‚Äôve seen a wave of technolo: Luckily, we‚Äôve seen a wave of technology and societal developments in the past few years that are finally enabling our dream to come true. And that‚Äôs the reason Niccolo and I eventually founded Pleo a few years ago.
Below, I‚Äôve outlined the top seven tre: Below, I‚Äôve outlined the top seven trends that are the big enablers for the inevitable extinction of expense reports:
1. Advancements in technology make real-: 1. Advancements in technology make real-time company spending overview possible
Wide acceptance of card payments (see mo: Wide acceptance of card payments (see more below) coupled with modern web technologies powered by fintech companies is finally enabling the long promised creation of real-time transaction overviews. Let‚Äôs compare the following two scenarios in connection to real-time spending:
Scenario 1: When I was CFO at Tradeshift: Scenario 1: When I was CFO at Tradeshift we had two common problems related to delayed overview of expenses. Firstly, it was extremely cumbersome to reconcile expenses made with shared company cards (who bought what? who has the receipt? etc.). By the time the credit card statement arrived, nobody knew the context of the purchases.
The second, and perhaps even bigger prob: The second, and perhaps even bigger problem, was with all other expenses originating from personal payment cards. These purchases resulted in the dreaded process of collecting receipts, expense report forms, endless approvals and delayed reimbursements. And it was just unfair to ask the employees to bank our business.
Scenario 2: At Pleo now, our managers se: Scenario 2: At Pleo now, our managers see every transaction our team does, in real-time. This improve the process of matching receipts: employees get a mobile notification after a purchase asking them to take a picture of the receipt, matching receipts to transactions on the spot. It also greatly improves the sense of control and context around transactions for managers.
Seeing an employee who‚Äôs visiting clie: Seeing an employee who‚Äôs visiting clients buy lunch on the day makes perfect sense. In the old scenario, some 20-30 days later, I simply wouldn‚Äôt have this context any more. I‚Äôd have to either rely on the employee to make a long note, laying out the reason for the purchase or bother him again to figure it out.
We see a growing and fast-paced trend in: We see a growing and fast-paced trend in business merchants accepting payment cards. The payment card was built 40 years ago to support us when travelling. Today, businesses are using cards for just about anything from buying advertising, to ordering software subscriptions and even paying for their shared office space, at the likes of WeWork or TechSpace.
In fact, ECB research shows that payment: In fact, ECB research shows that payment card transactions grew from ‚Ç¨12bn in 2000 to ‚Ç¨60bn in 2016.
Why is this important in relation to the: Why is this important in relation to the elimination of expense reports?
Well, it finally enables the second poin: Well, it finally enables the second point from our initial thesis ‚Äì that you can‚Äôt possibly eliminate expense reports without providing a reliable payment method for employees. In other words, offering a payment method that can be easily distributed and controlled. We‚Äôve reached this point with Pleo, by offering business payment cards through Mastercard, which is a global, widely accepted payment network.
Our own estimates show that modern compa: Our own estimates show that modern companies now do up to 75% of all their spending via company payment cards, and this trend will continue to grow with the acceleration of e-commerce spend. This is great news and an enabler for speed, delegation and traceability of business payments.
3. Employees are demanding efficient and: 3. Employees are demanding efficient and modern work processes
A 2016 study by Deloitte shows that only: A 2016 study by Deloitte shows that only 28% of millennials feel that their current organisations are making ‚Äúfull use‚Äù of their skills.
Moreover, research shows that revenue is: Moreover, research shows that revenue is up by 150% for companies with engaged employees, versus competitors with low engagement levels. And to an educated millennial used to fast-paced, instantly gratifying experiences on platforms like Instagram and Snapchat, what could be more boring (or unfamiliar) than filling out expense forms or waiting for their boss to share their company card.
The rise of cloud-based SaaS application: The rise of cloud-based SaaS applications and b2b e-commerce means that employees are now responsible for a much wider spectrum of company purchases. So without a streamlined process for company spending, they feel trapped and extremely inefficient.
Case in point: here are two tweets I fou: Case in point: here are two tweets I found from the CEOs of Clearbit and Product Hunt ‚Äì both clearly showing the value of employee empowerment through modern company spending solutions:
4. Increased need for transparency and t: 4. Increased need for transparency and trust in a modern workplace
The data proves it: a study by TINYpulse: The data proves it: a study by TINYpulse found that management transparency is actually the top factor when determining employee happiness.
In the video below you can see an exampl: In the video below you can see an example of how a seemingly tiny change in internal financial processes helped Planday‚Äôs employees save a huge amount of time and effort. They went from traditional expense reporting to using a modern company spending solution:
Pleo Customer Story: Planday Employee Ex: Pleo Customer Story: Planday Employee Experience
5. Modern cloud-based business software: 5. Modern cloud-based business software enables higher degree of interoperability and automation
Nowadays, practically every major cloud: Nowadays, practically every major cloud based business software provides an open API, according to this research by Deloitte. Why does this matter?
Well, it matters because when you use a: Well, it matters because when you use a cloud-based accounting solution with a widely adopted open API (Xero for example), you‚Äôre setting your business up for success and future growth.
The reason is simple: the more interoper: The reason is simple: the more interoperable the services you use are, the more accurate and timely the information at your disposal will be. No more error-prone manual data entry, no more CSV data transfers, manual uploading of receipts and so on‚Ä¶ And the more you can rely on those services to help you do work that is really important, the more you trust and adopt them. It‚Äôs a virtuous cycle that keeps generating value.
A relevant example of this interoperabil: A relevant example of this interoperability of services is a new UK-based company called Flux. It promises to connect merchants and forward-thinking fintech services to automatically fetch receipts after purchases, and automatically deliver them in banking and company spending applications.
6. Smartphones in every pocket enable ti: 6. Smartphones in every pocket enable timely notifications and simple capture and storage of receipts
Providing proof of purchases for busines: Providing proof of purchases for business expenses has traditionally been a frustrating process. Collecting physical receipts, scanning them, matching them with transactions‚Ä¶
On top of being a very cumbersome proces: On top of being a very cumbersome process, it is also extremely error-prone. Statistics suggest that around 19% of traditional expense reports contain mistakes. This can result in internal fraud cases or even fines from the tax authorities.
Luckily, the smartphone revolution can c: Luckily, the smartphone revolution can change this, forever. Nowadays, practically everyone in the developed world owns a smartphone. It finally enables real-time purchase notifications and quality capturing of receipts.
7. HMRC acceptance of digital storage of: 7. HMRC acceptance of digital storage of receipts
This is the last, but by no means least,: This is the last, but by no means least, point. Without smart and fast acceptance of digitally-stored receipts by tax authorities, all of the trends listed above wouldn‚Äôt matter that much.
Luckily, HMRC have been fast followers o: Luckily, HMRC have been fast followers of the technology curve in this case. HMRC have been accepting digital copies of receipts for years now (confirmed in this bulletin from 1998), paving the way for true technology disruption.
The perfect storm is here ‚Äì say goodby: The perfect storm is here ‚Äì say goodbye to expense reports!
So here we are. All the crucial elements: So here we are. All the crucial elements are in place to completely get rid of the legacy expense reporting process once and for all. What‚Äôs more, all of this is possible today.
We‚Äôre about to witness a massive shift: We‚Äôre about to witness a massive shift towards the elimination of expense reports in the next five years. Early adopters will reap great rewards, enabling them to make fast, business-critical purchases, and in the process allowing them to attract and retain top talent by empowering employees.
In addition, finance departments will be: In addition, finance departments will be able to connect the new company spending solutions to the accounting systems and eliminate huge amounts of error-prone and manual work.
I‚Äôm personally hugely excited about th: I‚Äôm personally hugely excited about this!

Advancements in payment technology, busi: Advancements in payment technology, business processes, employee behaviour and compliance requirements are changing how company spending is done. As a result, we are seeing a¬†massive shift towards the elimination of expense reports in the next 5 years.

To do this they travelled around Italy, learning from the best pizza makers.¬† It was truly a¬†pizza pilgrimage.
Back in 2012, they set up their first sh: Back in 2012, they set up their first shop on a market stall on Berwick Street in Soho, selling takeaway pizzas at a reasonable price. People loved it immediately and a few years later, Pizza Pilgrims has opened ten different pizzerias across London and Oxford.
Market stall or a big company ‚Äì everyo: Market stall or a big company ‚Äì everyone hates expense reports
Growing a company from a market stall to: Growing a company from a market stall to a growing pizzeria chain with hundreds of employees in just a few years changes a lot of things. But one of the things that still needs to be done is expense reports. As co-founder Thom puts it: ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter if you are the CEO of Mega Corp Ltd. or running your tiny little market stall, everyone hates doing expense reports.‚Äù
As Pizza Pilgrims grew rapidly, their pa: As Pizza Pilgrims grew rapidly, their pain with expenses just become bigger. The receipts kept pilling up and the finance team had to reconcile a growing number of expenses manually.
Nofil, who works as a Financial Controll: Nofil, who works as a Financial Controller at Pizza Pilgrims, tells us their company card reconciliation happened at the end of each month. The process of adding all those transactions, along with the receipts, to an expense journal ‚Äî which they later imported to Xero, their accounting software ‚Äî was a very strenuous task.
At one point, Thom even tried to build a: At one point, Thom even tried to build a solution himself, storing the receipts in a photo stream in a bid to keep them organised. But that didn‚Äôt help too much, as he found that he still struggled to find the time to do the expense reports properly.
Making expense processes easier with Ple: Making expense processes easier with Pleo
Thom stumbled upon Pleo while browsing o: Thom stumbled upon Pleo while browsing on the Xero Partner page to find tools to streamline their processes. He thought to himself: ‚ÄúWhy has no one done this before?‚Äù and sent it over to his finance department.
The finance team were impressed too‚Ä¶ o: The finance team were impressed too‚Ä¶ or as Nofil puts it: ‚ÄúIt was‚Ä¶ godsent‚Äù.
After a quick trial with two of their em: After a quick trial with two of their employees, Pizza Pilgrims rolled out Pleo across the entire organisation, meaning that nobody at the company ever has to do expense reports again.
While employees love the idea no longer: While employees love the idea no longer paying for expenses out of their own pockets, it‚Äôs the finance departments that actually save a lot more time and manual work by bringing in Pleo.
It was the same in Pizza Pilgrims‚Äô cas: It was the same in Pizza Pilgrims‚Äô case. Switching to Pleo cards for expensing meant saying goodbye to downloading credit card statements, chasing people for receipts, creating a manual journal, uploading it to the account software.
With Pleo, their finance department now: With Pleo, their finance department now has this whole process fully automated. From the point of sale, employees are instantly reminded to add the receipts and categorise it and everything is integrated directly with Xero, their accounting software.
This way they can also track all transac: This way they can also track all transactions in real-time and allocate expense properly. Thom describes Pleo as a clear and obvious solution that just makes life better.
Pizza Pilgirms is a fast growing pizzeri: Pizza Pilgirms is a fast growing pizzeria chain that said goodbye to expense reports (and made life better) with the help of Pleo.

Accountants: Learning from 2020 trends t: Accountants: Learning from 2020 trends to make the new year a success
What does 2021 hold for the accounting i: What does 2021 hold for the accounting industry?
We asked our accounting partners and ind: We asked our accounting partners and industry experts for some 2021 inspiration ‚Äì they didn't disappoint.
A lot has changed for the accounting ind: A lot has changed for the accounting industry in 2020. A lot.
The past 12 months completely transforme: The past 12 months completely transformed how so many firms deliver their services, and changed for the better how they communicate with clients. Finally, clients want to engage with all the good stuff their advisors have been trying to offer them for years.
Up-to-date numbers have become the basel: Up-to-date numbers have become the baseline, digitising systems have moved to the top of the to-do pile and suddenly clients are desperate to have regular meetings looking at strategy and planning.
No doubt the dust from this year will ta: No doubt the dust from this year will take some time to settle. The public health crisis might end, but the impact on businesses and their advisors will continue for years to come.
We‚Äôve spoken to some industry colleagu: We‚Äôve spoken to some industry colleagues and key Partners to look ahead to 2021, highlighting the key trends that could dominate the world of accounting.
Accountants excelled in a difficult year: Accountants excelled in a difficult year ‚Äì but what's next?
AccountingWeb has highlighted their read: AccountingWeb has highlighted their readers' calls to extend the January 31st tax deadline, with some at least a month behind in work.
The stark reality is that millions of bu: The stark reality is that millions of businesses have deferred their VAT payments and/or taken bounceback and CBILS loans.
With a faltering economy, it‚Äôs expecte: With a faltering economy, it‚Äôs expected that a lot of businesses will continue to suffer, and accountants are going to have to be on hand to help their clients through it.
Looking at social media, it‚Äôs clear th: Looking at social media, it‚Äôs clear that practices are taking pride in giving clients everything they can in order to adapt and survive. The extra workload might hurt, but they care about their clients and are taking the hit. We‚Äôve said it before and we‚Äôll say it again: accountants really are superheroes.
Compassion and empathy will become even: Compassion and empathy will become even more vital
Here at Pleo, ‚ÄòBeing Human‚Äô is one o: Here at Pleo, ‚ÄòBeing Human‚Äô is one of our core values. It‚Äôs about acting with compassion when speaking with our colleagues, our Partners, not to mention all 13,000 of our Pleo customers.
This year has proven the perfect opportu: This year has proven the perfect opportunity to practice empathy in business. The next 12 months is a chance to take this even further.
Accountants will have had their fair sha: Accountants will have had their fair share of tough conversations this year. This too will continue as we navigate finances in 2021, with many looking at forecasts for clients and unfortunately, the prospect of slow sales.
‚Äú2021 is the year where we need to rec: ‚Äú2021 is the year where we need to reconnect with the human aspect in the way we work as accountants,‚Äù says Dave Sellick of Sidgrove. ‚ÄúThis is more relevant than ever in what is going to be a year where many clients will be going through some major financial and emotional ups and downs‚Äù.
Where analytical brains and attention to: Where analytical brains and attention to detail may have traditionally been front-and-centre, compassion and empathy are clearly skills that are now a vital part of a financial advisor‚Äôs armoury. This can be draining, so community forums are a welcome reminder that you are not alone in this strife. There are some very active Facebook groups for accountants (we like Simon Chaplin‚Äôs!) that are a great place to go for support and advice with peers.
Cloud-based accouting will be in more de: Cloud-based accouting will be in more demand than ever before
The traditional once-a-year check-in wit: The traditional once-a-year check-in with clients is a relic of the past after a year of so much turmoil. A large portion of the industry are now fighting to help clients get much closer to the numbers that define their business.
The tools that support accountants to ro: The tools that support accountants to roll these services out to clients are becoming increasingly popular. Fluidly, an intelligent cashflow, forecasting and funding app, say they‚Äôve seen their customer base grow exponentially in 2020 as accounting partners rushed to roll out support to the businesses they work with.
As efforts to boost the economy continue: As efforts to boost the economy continue to kick in, there will be opportunities for businesses.
Having up-to-date and accurate access to: Having up-to-date and accurate access to spending data and trends is something we see as being hugely important - and something that Pleo has major plans to help practices with in the next 12 months.
We think accountants are going to play a: We think accountants are going to play a critical role in helping their clients identify and execute on opportunities. Those tidy Xero accounts are going to be a huge asset when it comes to looking at potential opportunities. Are you in the right spot to try something new? Or is it a moment where waiting makes more sense? What was profitable in 2019 may not be in 2021 and vice versa.
Accountants will continue to embrace soc: Accountants will continue to embrace social media
The craving for community was a sentimen: The craving for community was a sentiment shared around the globe in 2020 ‚Äì an inevitable reaction to the enforced confinement we all endured for so many months. For accountants, it meant no longer being able to pay clients a visit in person.
Not only this, but the one-on-one format: Not only this, but the one-on-one format no longer made any sense. When the government announced a new support scheme, (which they continue to do, almost weekly), accountants needed a quick and simple way to communicate with as many clients as possible in one broad brush.
LinkedIn was one channel that proved ver: LinkedIn was one channel that proved very useful for that.
Sheffield-based Pleo Partner, Gravitate: Sheffield-based Pleo Partner, Gravitate Accounting, are never ones to shy away from that ‚Äòpost‚Äô button. But it‚Äôs as much about how you communicate, as well as what you‚Äôre saying. Co-founder Sam Newton believes it‚Äôs important to have a variety - not just post about the informative stuff.
\"Some posts are about telling our story: "Some posts are about telling our story and the good people of LinkedIn like to hear a positive story... Some is business support, some is just us messing around - but the key thing is it‚Äôs not accounting jargon that no one cares for. "
\"We aren‚Äôt afraid to act differently: "We aren‚Äôt afraid to act differently to accountants on LinkedIn!"
Experiment with your social media presen: Experiment with your social media presence ‚Äì focus on the topics you‚Äôre passionate about and have a clear plan for what you‚Äôre going to cover. It‚Äôs better to post on areas where you really care, rather than try to fake it.
Firms that focus on cloud and apps will: Firms that focus on cloud and apps will have their busiest year yet
2020 has been a catalyst for many busine: 2020 has been a catalyst for many businesses to embrace digital change. We asked Matt Flanagan of Appacus about the impact that would continue to have.
‚Äú2020 and the pandemic has brought dig: ‚Äú2020 and the pandemic has brought digital to the fore, whether that‚Äôs with communication, collaboration or general business. 2021 will bring a much more digitally-aware SME who will be looking to understand better ways of running their business, utilising digital technology.‚Äù
Matt believes there is ‚Äúa great opport: Matt believes there is ‚Äúa great opportunity for accountants to lead [clients] through this, with cloud accounting at the fore.‚Äù
The opportunity to drive real innovation: The opportunity to drive real innovation using new tools in their business is a very tempting prospect to many. They‚Äôll want to come out of this downturn stronger and leaner than ever before.
Firms that put cloud and apps at the hea: Firms that put cloud and apps at the heart of their offering are going to have their busiest year in 2021. It looks like clients will really start to engage with this side of practices as they find ways to increase efficiency and adapt to the business environment that emerges.
The future of accounting is offering mor: The future of accounting is offering more to clients
That‚Äôs our take on some of the account: That‚Äôs our take on some of the accounting trends likely in 2021. There are a lot of caveats of course ‚Äì we made some predictions before 2020 that didn‚Äôt take long to be turned on their head. The new year will contain its own share of surprises and innovations.
But thanks to our daily conversations wi: But thanks to our daily conversations with accountants, we know the efforts that so many practices have been making. And if there‚Äôs a common theme through all of our thoughts here, it‚Äôs that the accountants who implement the lessons of 2020 will be in a great place this time next year.
At which stage, we hope we can all get b: At which stage, we hope we can all get back together in person to review a remarkable time for the industry.

Take the lead: What I‚Äôve learned as a: Take the lead: What I‚Äôve learned as a first-time manager
Your first leadership role can be a chal: Your first leadership role can be a challenging experience, so we asked one of our team to share her tips for making it work.
I‚Äôm not somebody who naturally doubts: I‚Äôm not somebody who naturally doubts myself. I‚Äôve got an exciting job in an industry I‚Äôm passionate about.
Two and a half years ago, I started at P: Two and a half years ago, I started at Pleo as an Account Manager. Before long, I took leadership of one of our sales teams.
Now I‚Äôm heading up our partnerships te: Now I‚Äôm heading up our partnerships team in Denmark, Sweden and the UK.
When you‚Äôre new to leadership, it‚Äôs: When you‚Äôre new to leadership, it‚Äôs natural to ask yourself: What am I even doing?
Stepping into a leadership role has been: Stepping into a leadership role has been a fun ride, but doubt was unavoidable. And the question I return to in my moments of doubt is a simple one ‚Äì but also a big one.
I‚Äôm figuring out how to answer that qu: I‚Äôm figuring out how to answer that question and deal with those doubts.
So I wanted to share some off-the-cuff t: So I wanted to share some off-the-cuff thoughts that might help anyone else who‚Äôs managing people for the first time.
One thing that helps me in those moments: One thing that helps me in those moments of doubt is to remember what got me into this position: I wanted to be a leader.
I saw our team needed someone to take ch: I saw our team needed someone to take charge and I started to do just that. The title came afterwards.
Seeing people grow? That‚Äôs the most re: Seeing people grow? That‚Äôs the most rewarding thing.
And I‚Äôve loved so many aspects of lead: And I‚Äôve loved so many aspects of leading. Seeing people grow is the most rewarding thing ever.¬† Helping people to learn new skills, to overcome challenges, is an amazing motivator.
In those moments of doubt or stress, rec: In those moments of doubt or stress, reconnect with why you wanted to lead in the first place. Put your focus on the most rewarding elements of the role.
Concentrate on the questions, not the an: Concentrate on the questions, not the answers
As a novice manager, it‚Äôs tempting to: As a novice manager, it‚Äôs tempting to believe that I always have to lead the way. To imagine that my team need me to have all the answers.
It would be scary if that was true!: It would be scary if that was true!
Instead of firing off an answer when my: Instead of firing off an answer when my team comes to me, I‚Äôve learned to try to ask the right questions.
It‚Äôs OK for me to admit when I‚Äôm stu: It‚Äôs OK for me to admit when I‚Äôm stumped.
But where I don‚Äôt have answers, my tea: But where I don‚Äôt have answers, my team often does. Tell somebody what to do and you don‚Äôt get the same investment as when you guide them to developing their own answer ‚Äì even if they want your backing.
It‚Äôs OK to admit when you don‚Äôt have: It‚Äôs OK to admit when you don‚Äôt have the answers right away.
So even when things are running smoothly: So even when things are running smoothly (rare for any manager I know!), prompt your team to uncover their own potential improvements.
Show them their input is valued, even in: Show them their input is valued, even in small things, and you‚Äôll be encouraging their ability to think for themselves.
An empowered team is the kind of team I: An empowered team is the kind of team I want to lead. I bet you‚Äôre the same.
A beginner‚Äôs mindset is something that: A beginner‚Äôs mindset is something that you hear a lot of people talk about in business ‚Äì and especially start-ups.
For me as a leader, it means observing m: For me as a leader, it means observing my team closely. Talking to them about what is and isn‚Äôt working. Learning from the way they perform best. No assumptions.
Challenge yourself to investigate new wa: Challenge yourself to investigate new ways of working.
Sometimes it‚Äôs easy to think that beca: Sometimes it‚Äôs easy to think that because something worked for you, it will work for your team.
A beginner‚Äôs mindset means challenging: A beginner‚Äôs mindset means challenging yourself to be open to other ways of working.
Here‚Äôs an example of how to embrace th: Here‚Äôs an example of how to embrace the beginner‚Äôs mindset.
Ahead of a meeting, list the questions y: Ahead of a meeting, list the questions you want to be answered. Even though they might seem obvious, ask them.
And use silence. Often when we shut up,: And use silence. Often when we shut up, we get much more valuable information ‚Äì handy when you‚Äôre a beginner.
Feel the fear‚Ä¶ and give feedback anywa: Feel the fear‚Ä¶ and give feedback anyway
It can feel really weird to give feedbac: It can feel really weird to give feedback for the first time.
What‚Äôs the best way to do it? Feedback: What‚Äôs the best way to do it? Feedback that will benefit the employee, the team, the company and me‚Ä¶ all at the same time?
Obviously, good feedback is great to del: Obviously, good feedback is great to deliver.
It‚Äôs the negative feedback that really: It‚Äôs the negative feedback that really presents the challenge. Imposter syndrome can set in: who am I to tell somebody this isn‚Äôt right? What do I know?
Here‚Äôs my advice: Just start doing it.
When giving feedback, offer lots of spac: When giving feedback, offer lots of space for the other person to share their thoughts.
In my experience, people can appreciate: In my experience, people can appreciate feedback that‚Äôs delivered from a place of wanting to help them. At the start, you might feel like you haven‚Äôt nailed exactly what you wanted to say, but that‚Äôs OK.
Give lots of space for the other person: Give lots of space for the other person (or people) to have input.
And get feedback on your feedback. A few: And get feedback on your feedback. A few days later, follow up with the person and see if they found your input helpful or if it‚Äôs raised any questions. Encourage honesty.
If you‚Äôve read this far, you might thi: If you‚Äôve read this far, you might think that being a young leader in business sounds exhausting.
The most important lesson so far? Don‚Äô: The most important lesson so far? Don‚Äôt be afraid to take a break!
Overthinking and analysing is part of th: Overthinking and analysing is part of the role (at least for me), which can be draining.
The benefit is that I feel I‚Äôm constan: The benefit is that I feel I‚Äôm constantly improving because I spend so much time reflecting.
The downside is I need to remind myself: The downside is I need to remind myself to take a break. That might be the most important lesson I‚Äôve learned so far.
For me, that involves daily meditation,: For me, that involves daily meditation, adding breaks in my calendar (so that I will actually stick to it) and sharing my thoughts with people outside Pleo.
That‚Äôs been my road into leadership so: That‚Äôs been my road into leadership so far.
One of my guiding principles is to be re: One of my guiding principles is to be real and to be myself. That kind of transparency is vital to me and to Pleo.
And I hope that by sharing some of my do: And I hope that by sharing some of my doubts ‚Äì and my strategies for coping with them ‚Äì I‚Äôll help shake up the old ideas about what management involves.
