Company Spending Fully Paperless, Thanks: Company Spending Fully Paperless, Thanks To Pleo & Storebox
Buying things today is becoming much eas: Buying things today is becoming much easier, while work purchase processes remain in most cases a big mess. With Pleo, we are proud to be changing this and setting the path for the future. Now, we are introducing the next step: fully paperless company spending, thanks to our integration with Storebox.
Buying things for work is a big mess.
For most people, it looks something like: For most people, it looks something like this: ask your manager for an approval, check if the expense policy justifies the purchase, the purchase gets approved, buy it with your own card, file an expense claim, hand it over to finance team and finally, wait to get reimbursed.
It‚Äôs no surprise that most people who: It‚Äôs no surprise that most people who have to do it, have grown to openly dislike it.
On the other hand, buying things as a co: On the other hand, buying things as a consumer has never been easier. Thanks to mobile payments, contactless cards, Apple and Android Pay, most people today just tap away and they are done.
While the disconnect between buying thin: While the disconnect between buying things for work or in your free time keeps growing for most people, our happy users who have Pleo cards can take most of the unnecessary steps away. At Pleo, we strongly believe technology behind our cards will keep on removing these tedious steps, while still making sure the purchases include all the requirements from the finance department.
One of the most popular Pleo features to: One of the most popular Pleo features today is the instant notification that reminds users to take a photo of the receipt whenever a purchase is made with a Pleo card. In our above mentioned quest to remove the manual steps, we are excited to announce we made this even easier, thanks to the direct Pleo integration with Storebox, a digital receipt service by Nets.
Now whenever a Pleo user makes a purchas: Now whenever a Pleo user makes a purchase at one of the +5,000 merchants in Denmark that are connected to the Storebox network, Pleo will automatically fetch a digital version of the receipt, link it to the correct transaction, automatically categorise the expense, and export it to the accounting system of your choice.
We‚Äôve written a step-by-step guide on: We‚Äôve written a step-by-step guide on how to enable the integration if you are a Pleo user today, you can read more by following this link.
And if you want to find out more about S: And if you want to find out more about Storebox and how it works, you can find out here.
World‚Äôs first fully automated expense: World‚Äôs first fully automated expense reporting solution
While Storebox is available only to our: While Storebox is available only to our users in Denmark at the moment, we see it is a big milestone towards making company spending as frictionless as possible for everyone.
We‚Äôre excited to see that Denmark is p: We‚Äôre excited to see that Denmark is paving the way for the future of payment technology by enabling companies, not to go only cashless and adopt mobile payments, but also be fully paperless.
This step adds the last piece of the puz: This step adds the last piece of the puzzle for Pleo to become the first fully automated, end-to-end expense reporting solution on the market with growing number of merchants embracing e-receipts.
The world will follow soon and we are al: The world will follow soon and we are already talking with several emerging companies in the UK that are exploring this space to expand our offering to all our happy Pleo users.
Accounting is changing, and that starts: Accounting is changing, and that starts with more women
Pleo's Ida St√∏ier offers her take on th: Pleo's Ida St√∏ier offers her take on the current status of women in the accounting industry ‚Äì and offers an exciting vision for the future.
One of our Pleo team asked me once what: One of our Pleo team asked me once what I would say to a young female student to convince them to join the accounting industry.
I think they thought asking me would be: I think they thought asking me would be a challenge. That I‚Äôd be stumped, would struggle to come up with an answer.
Once I started, I couldn‚Äôt stop talkin: Once I started, I couldn‚Äôt stop talking. So, they asked me to start writing instead.
I‚Äôve been working with our accounting: I‚Äôve been working with our accounting partners for a few years now, really digging into what motivates them. Attending events big and small to get the bigger picture.
Accounting isn't a bunch of men in suits: Accounting isn't a bunch of men in suits any more.
It‚Äôs been fun! From what I can see, gr: It‚Äôs been fun! From what I can see, great times lie ahead for the industry. There‚Äôs an appetite for change.
A huge part of the excitement among the: A huge part of the excitement among the accountants driving that change is moving past those outdated perceptions of what accountants ‚Äúlook like‚Äù.
A bunch of men in suits? Not any more.
There‚Äôs good news and bad when you loo: There‚Äôs good news and bad when you look at the research on gender diversity in the industry.
The foundation for positive change is th: The foundation for positive change is there among the younger female accountants.
Research shows they‚Äôre more interested: Research shows they‚Äôre more interested than men in the long term career prospects that finance offers ‚Äì they‚Äôre in this for the long haul.
I don‚Äôt want to ignore the facts. Is t: I don‚Äôt want to ignore the facts. Is the number of women in leadership roles still disappointing? Yes.
Add to that the fact that the number of: Add to that the fact that the number of female accountants has been growing over the past few years and you‚Äôve got a positive start.
Has it been growing fast enough? No.
Is the number of women in leadership rol: Is the number of women in leadership roles still pretty disappointing? Yes.
So, what would I say to a female student: So, what would I say to a female student considering a career in finance?
I‚Äôve spoken at finance events where ou: I‚Äôve spoken at finance events where out of nine speakers, I‚Äôve been the only female.
It‚Äôs still quite a traditional industr: It‚Äôs still quite a traditional industry. When you bring something else ‚Äì even if that‚Äôs just being female ‚Äì you already have a bit of a cutting edge.
Sometimes that difference can feel like: Sometimes that difference can feel like a barrier or a challenge. That‚Äôs totally natural.
I‚Äôve spoken at finance events where I‚: I‚Äôve spoken at finance events where I‚Äôve been one of nine speakers. And yes, it was eight men in blue suits and me on the stage.
But I figured it gave me an advantage, a: But I figured it gave me an advantage, a chance to have more impact with what I was saying.
(I did also open with: ‚ÄúHey guys, I kn: (I did also open with: ‚ÄúHey guys, I know this is going to be pretty groundbreaking - but there‚Äôs a woman on stage now.‚Äù)
So see if you can convert what seems lik: So see if you can convert what seems like a barrier to a USP.
Remember too that accountancy is no long: Remember too that accountancy is no longer just about numbers ‚Äì it‚Äôs about the unique value each employee brings.
I‚Äôm just speaking from my own experien: I‚Äôm just speaking from my own experience here, but I know a lot of women who are extremely detail-oriented and often brilliant at preparation.
In the world of finance, those skills al: In the world of finance, those skills alone will earn you a great reputation!
When I told the joke at that event where: When I told the joke at that event where I was the only female speaker, everyone in the room laughed with me. They listened to what I had to say. They were on my side.
It was a great reminder to me that there: It was a great reminder to me that there are so many people out there that want to help young people, young women, fulfil their dreams in the industry.
Senior figures are well aware of the nee: Senior figures are well aware of the need for more gender diversity.
I‚Äôm super-optimistic that this problem: I‚Äôm super-optimistic that this problem will be fixed ‚Äì and I think that a positive approach is the only one to have.
Realise the opportunities that change of: Realise the opportunities that change offers women
I‚Äôm sure I wouldn‚Äôt need to tell tha: I‚Äôm sure I wouldn‚Äôt need to tell that young female student that accountancy is changing in a lot of ways.
Technology means accountants are moving: Technology means accountants are moving away from just managing numbers. Now the focus is on communicating what those numbers mean.
I think women have an advantage when it: I think women have an advantage when it comes to breaking down complex data to something simpler.
Flexible working is also becoming more c: Flexible working is also becoming more common.
Research shows a growing awareness of ho: Research shows a growing awareness of how much mothers returning to work can offer.
Smart companies have figured out that th: Smart companies have figured out that they need to do more to help unlock the potential of these women ‚Äì and how flexible work can help do that.
Job titles and definitions are shifting: Job titles and definitions are shifting on a daily basis too. That‚Äôs so exciting ‚Äì and gives individuals a chance to bend the role to suit their own needs and skillsets.
More flexible working in accountancy is: More flexible working in accountancy is helping mothers return to work successfully.
All of these are great opportunities for: All of these are great opportunities for candidates (male and female!) who want to play a part in transforming the industry.
I don‚Äôt have far to look to find women: I don‚Äôt have far to look to find women in finance who are inspiring me.
Cheryl Sharp, whose company PinkPigFinan: Cheryl Sharp, whose company PinkPigFinancials puts family commitments front and centre.
Della Hudson, leading the way with thoug: Della Hudson, leading the way with thought-provoking blogs on topics like finding yourself on a panel that‚Äôs just men. Been there, done that!
Or in Denmark, Nina Esmann Lindgreen, wh: Or in Denmark, Nina Esmann Lindgreen, whose entrepreneurial mindset always impresses me.
Let‚Äôs celebrate those female role mode: Let‚Äôs celebrate those female role models in finance who are achieving so much.
If that young student was hesitant about: If that young student was hesitant about her ability to make it in a male-dominated industry, I‚Äôd tell her to find people like that and reach out to them.
She can always start her network with me: She can always start her network with me.
Optimism about how the industry can grow: Optimism about how the industry can grow and let more women shine doesn‚Äôt mean being blind to its problems.
We need to do more to celebrate those ro: We need to do more to celebrate those role models.
We need workplaces that reflect the diff: We need workplaces that reflect the different demands on mothers.
But we also need more positivity about h: But we also need more positivity about how we‚Äôre going to get there. The industry is not dying, it‚Äôs changing.
Women are going to be a vital part of th: Women are going to be a vital part of that change ‚Äì so let‚Äôs make it happen!
What is the current status of women in t: What is the current status of women in the accounting industry and how can we do more to increase gender diversity in finance?

Netflix‚Äôs expense policy is not what y: Netflix‚Äôs expense policy is not what you expect, but it works
Employees at companies like Netflix or G: Employees at companies like Netflix or Google can be up to 40% more productive than average workers, studies suggest. A huge part of that is eliminating ‚Äúorganisational drag‚Äù, those internal processes or policies that take up way too much time‚Ä¶ like expenses.
Netflix‚Äôs expense policy is summed up: Netflix‚Äôs expense policy is summed up in just five words:
Ten years ago, the entertainment giant r: Ten years ago, the entertainment giant released a presentation on how they run their company: who they hire, who they fire and how they create their culture. ‚ÄúNetflix Culture: Freedom & Responsibility‚Äù has been praised by many, although at the time it was seen by some as controversial.
CEO Reed Hastings and former Chief Talen: CEO Reed Hastings and former Chief Talent Officer Patty McCord say the outcome of their approach has increased talent density and pushed productivity to new heights.
Patty McCord: Lessons from a Silicon Val: Patty McCord: Lessons from a Silicon Valley maverick: new ways of working and collaborating
The numbers don‚Äôt lie. Since the 2009: The numbers don‚Äôt lie. Since the 2009 presentation, the company has grown from 12m monthly subscribers to more than 150 million customers worldwide. It‚Äôs one of the fastest-growing and most innovative companies in the world, employing more than 7000 people‚Ä¶.
‚Ä¶ and it still doesn‚Äôt have an expen: ‚Ä¶ and it still doesn‚Äôt have an expense policy in place.
The Netflix Way: ‚ÄúTreat People Like Ad: The Netflix Way: ‚ÄúTreat People Like Adults‚Äù
In small or family businesses, people kn: In small or family businesses, people know each other and trust can come naturally. But things change when companies start to scale. A growing number of policies and procedures get put in place, often in a very ad hoc way. While most organisations find this inevitable and welcome it, Netflix approached things a bit differently.
As Reed Hastings puts it, these processe: As Reed Hastings puts it, these processes emerge as an urge to stop the overwhelming chaos. ‚ÄúTime to grow up‚Äù becomes a management mantra as they try to justify the new rules and regulations. As a result, policies pop up in different areas, including the one about how much money employees are allowed to spend on business expenses.
But this is where another, often overloo: But this is where another, often overlooked, problem actually occurs.
As companies get bigger, the growing num: As companies get bigger, the growing number of procedures, rules and policies mean a reduction in employee freedom. Netflix realised a different type of chaos happens as a result: the increased complexity significantly reduces the productivity of high-performing employees, who become unhappy and look elsewhere.
Research published in the Harvard Busine: Research published in the Harvard Business Review shows that on average, a company loses more than 25% of its productive power to organisational drag.
Organisational drag is the bureaucratic: Organisational drag is the bureaucratic processes that waste time and prevent people from getting things done, like expense reporting. And guess who really doesn‚Äôt like tedious, time-consuming processes? Millennials. They don‚Äôt want to be micromanaged and say that autonomy is the most valuable company perk, sometimes even more important than the size of their salary. No, really.
Netflix is not alone in realising the pa: Netflix is not alone in realising the pain that drag can cause. Companies in the technology sector, whether smaller start-ups or huge corporations, often trust that the people who they hire will end up doing the right thing, so policies are not just a drag but quickly become obsolete. And according to research from consulting firm Bain & Company, employees in companies like Netflix and Google are on average 40% more productive as a result.
‚ÄúWhat does a ‚Äòno limits‚Äô expense p: ‚ÄúWhat does a ‚Äòno limits‚Äô expense policy actually mean?‚Äù
In Netflix‚Äôs case, it‚Äôs quite simple: In Netflix‚Äôs case, it‚Äôs quite simple.
Their five-word policy actually means em: Their five-word policy actually means employees are instructed to ‚Äúexpense only what you would otherwise not spend, and is worthwhile for work‚Äù. They don‚Äôt have any limits, rules, reporting or tracking set in place to follow that, as it has proved as a waste of time.
‚ÄúWe assume you are not here to rip off: ‚ÄúWe assume you are not here to rip off the company, and we‚Äôre not going to put in place processes that consume human capital, waste time, and zap energy.‚Äù
‚Äì Patty McCord, former Chief Talent Of: ‚Äì Patty McCord, former Chief Talent Officer at Netflix
On the other hand, Google does things a: On the other hand, Google does things a bit differently:
Most companies today have corporate card: Most companies today have corporate cards reserved only for senior management. Google, on the other hand, has decided to give one to every employee. This doesn‚Äôt just symbolise the amount of freedom and trust they‚Äôre giving workers, it‚Äôs also a rational business decision to automate their expenses. In this case, the employees are not just allowed to spend what they need to in order to get their job done well, but also to use the company funds to do so.
It‚Äôs a huge disruption to the status q: It‚Äôs a huge disruption to the status quo.
In most companies, the majority of emplo: In most companies, the majority of employees have to follow a strict expense policy and pay out of their own pocket for a simple business purchase. This is where the ‚Äúexpense report‚Äù comes in, as a detailed record and description of each company‚Äôs purchases, left for review by the finance team so that workers can later receive their money back.
This goes against everything the Netflix: This goes against everything the Netflix approach stands for. Unfortunately, this cumbersome bureaucratic process has become a norm for the majority of businesses nowadays. People have learned to hate it and the fact it often leaves them seriously out of pocket is no doubt tied to that.
At Pleo, we‚Äôve already written pieces: At Pleo, we‚Äôve already written pieces about why the era of expense reports is coming to an end and what the overlooked costs for organisations are.
‚ÄúWon‚Äôt the employees just spend more: ‚ÄúWon‚Äôt the employees just spend more money?‚Äù

At Google, which employs more than 98,00: At Google, which employs more than 98,000 people worldwide, things are harder to dig into on a case-by-case basis. This is why they had to find a way to give employees trust and freedom, but at the same time let them know what is deemed acceptable by the company.
‚ÄúOn a very fundamental level, people l: ‚ÄúOn a very fundamental level, people like being told what they can and can‚Äôt do. They want flexibility, choice and to be able to do what they want to do, but they also want to know what‚Äôs reasonable and what‚Äôs acceptable in this company.

They have managed to redefine the concep: They have managed to redefine the concept of a travel policy in everyone‚Äôs favour. Employees are allowed to book flights and hotels by themselves, but there‚Äôs a system in place to suggest the best option available, with incentives for choosing what‚Äôs cheaper.
At last, the tools are here to do expens: At last, the tools are here to do expenses better.
For the past few decades, the trade-off: For the past few decades, the trade-off between the requirements of the finance team and what employees want has resulted in a bad compromise for both: an expense report.
This has combined manual reconciliation: This has combined manual reconciliation times, no real-time overview, expense fraud attempts and unhappy employees waiting to get reimbursed. All of this is a source of stress and time loss for the entire organisation. The most innovative companies in the world have found ways of making it easier for their employees by building cutting-edge tools to fit their needs and even help them attract new talent.
Thankfully, the fast developments in bus: Thankfully, the fast developments in business and finance technology are moving things in the right direction for forward-thinking companies everywhere. Expense and travel tools are becoming smarter by automating the necessary regulatory requirement parts, and at the same time they give employees a much easier and a smarter way to just get things done.

Inspired by Google‚Äôs internal travel system mentioned above, it‚Äôs an enterprise platform that rewards employees with gift cards if they go under budget on travel. Finance managers can follow all travel bookings and can set policies, while employees can book by themselves and earn rewards to save company money.
Another example is Pleo. Employees are t: Another example is Pleo. Employees are trusted with smart company cards, while at the same time finance teams can set individual limits. Workers are reminded to snap a photo of their receipt and add project or customer tags if needed. Finance teams sees everything in real-time, categorised and automatically synced with their accounting software. This means everyone is compliant, everything is tracked, but no one has to do an expense report.
It brings the best of both worlds: a way: It brings the best of both worlds: a way to keep your staff agile and fast, while at the same time giving companies more control over all their spending to help them save time and money.

As we‚Äôre officially saying goodbye to summer, we reflect on the recent updates, where the product is headed and what you can expect from us in October ‚Äî apart from some very last minute Halloween costumes. From strengthening and expanding our accounting integrations, to doubling down on events and opening new offices, here‚Äôs your October digest.
Things have been heating up in our produ: Things have been heating up in our product team over the last few months and it has resulted in a bunch of really cool and useful features being shipped. Here‚Äôs a rundown of what we built in September and where the product‚Äôs heading in the next few months.
First, we‚Äôve shipped our Fortnox integ: First, we‚Äôve shipped our Fortnox integration to simplify the lives of admins and bookkeepers in Sweden.
Fortnox is the most popular accounting s: Fortnox is the most popular accounting software in the country, used by some 240,000 companies.
By enabling this integration, our Swedis: By enabling this integration, our Swedish customers will benefit from faster data exports to Fortnox and a much simpler workflow.
This new update also comes with a much-a: This new update also comes with a much-awaited feature: Reverse VAT. Read all about it here.
Second, we‚Äôre taking a step up with ou: Second, we‚Äôre taking a step up with our Xero integration by building the Xero Direct Feed.
Currently in development, the Direct Fee: Currently in development, the Direct Feed is expected to be shipped in October.
Once enabled, this new integration will: Once enabled, this new integration will automatically sync your Pleo transactions twice daily to your Xero organisation, allowing admins and bookkeeper to have more of a real-time overview.
As phase one, the integration will only: As phase one, the integration will only automatically import the transaction amount, the merchant name and the settlement date.
For our customers in Denmark using auto: For our customers in Denmark using auto top-up, we‚Äôve made some important changes that are sure to delight you. Honestly, it‚Äôs that good!
After months of hard work, we‚Äôre proud: After months of hard work, we‚Äôre proud to announce that automatic top-ups will appear in your wallet on the same day ‚Äì so long as they‚Äôre initiated before 11:55, or the following day if initiated after 11:55.
Moreover, the 25,000 DKK top-up limit is: Moreover, the 25,000 DKK top-up limit is lifted and you can now set your auto transfer amount to whatever you want.
This feature is currently only available: This feature is currently only available for Danish companies, but we‚Äôre working hard to make it available for all markets. Stay tuned!
PSD2 is a Directive by the European Cent: PSD2 is a Directive by the European Central Bank aiming to bring into force stricter rules to protect user data and funds, as well as introduce universal security and authentication standards across Europe.
We‚Äôve taken the necessary steps to ens: We‚Äôve taken the necessary steps to ensure we are compliant with the legislation ahead of the forthcoming deadline (set to 14 March, 2021 for Danish companies by the Danish FSA).
Here‚Äôs what users can expect going for: Here‚Äôs what users can expect going forward:

How to actually get hired remotely: How to actually get hired remotely
The adoption of remote work has already: The adoption of remote work has already been growing at a fast pace, and probably will continue even after this pandemic has passed, as flexible working becomes the norm.
Before 2020, the life of the digital nom: Before 2020, the life of the digital nomad, working from wherever and having all the flexibility that goes along with it sounded nifty, new, and attractive. Now that most of us have had the experience of working from home for an extended time, it doesn‚Äôt suit everyone, but maybe it‚Äôs opened your eyes to something new.¬†¬†
Companies have caught on too, they‚Äôve: Companies have caught on too, they‚Äôve realised you can hire anyone from anywhere, and not just from the talent pool where you‚Äôre HQ‚Äôd. This has only been accelerated due to COVID ‚Äî 46% of big companies are more open to hiring remote workers, according to Monster's Future of Work report.
Take Pleo ‚Äì we‚Äôve had quite the grow: Take Pleo ‚Äì we‚Äôve had quite the growth journey: When I joined back in 2018 we went from 50 to 100 people during my first six months at the company, and we aren‚Äôt slowing down anytime soon. We‚Äôve already hired 36 people this year!
When I‚Äôve been building our people tea: When I‚Äôve been building our people team the plan has always been to go from good to great.
We need to make sure that we‚Äôre always: We need to make sure that we‚Äôre always working with people who bring different experiences, different backgrounds, and different world views to the conversation. We need to challenge ourselves and iterate to become (and remain) pioneers.
Let‚Äôs face it: though I love Copenhage: Let‚Äôs face it: though I love Copenhagen, if you‚Äôre only hiring from 1.5M people your options are limited. That‚Äôs not how you build the best team in the world. You need the world to help you out.
Sometimes, the best people aren‚Äôt in a: Sometimes, the best people aren‚Äôt in a place to relocate (or it just isn‚Äôt possible at the moment), and we try to support this as much as possible. But other times, people don‚Äôt want to. This is why we as a company aspire to be remote-first.
Back in March 2019, I worked remotely ou: Back in March 2019, I worked remotely out of South Africa for the entire month ‚Äì and went to a great incubator ‚Äì MEST ‚Äì to speak about remote work, and the potential of this in Africa. I thought I‚Äôd sum it up here and give you some honest, down-to-earth advice that I shared with the guys there.¬†
Businesses lose $600 billion a year to w: Businesses lose $600 billion a year to workplace distractions, and that remote workers are 35% to 40% more productive than their in-office counterparts. Source: Remote Work Statistics: Navigating the New Normal¬†
Can you think of a business that wouldn‚: Can you think of a business that wouldn‚Äôt want to save money and have more productive employees? Hiring remotely not only allows for a much larger talent pool, but it has its monetary and productivity benefits as well.¬†
The trend towards more flexible working: The trend towards more flexible working and remote work has been on the rise for the past 5 years, with remote workers growing by 44% in the U.S. Souce: 10 Remote Work Statistics¬†
And in 2019 in Stack Overflow‚Äôs survey: And in 2019 in Stack Overflow‚Äôs survey among almost 90,000 tech workers around the globe, 32% said the option to work remotely is one of the highest-ranking factors that would make them choose a job.
This last one makes it obvious that comp: This last one makes it obvious that companies are willing to hire remote workers if the talent is there.¬†
So the indicators are there ‚Äî more and: So the indicators are there ‚Äî more and more remote jobs are becoming available. So how do you get yourself ready for them? In my mind, there are a couple of things to consider...
Over the past year, many of us have set: Over the past year, many of us have set up a home office for the first time and has countless Zoom calls.
This might be the norm for a little whil: This might be the norm for a little while longer, but it should get you thinking: Are you even the type of person who suits remote working? I‚Äôm sure most of us would immediately say yes for the sake of it, but you owe it to yourself to be smarter than that. Be introspective. Let‚Äôs look at some good things, and some bad things (stolen lovingly from some of our favourite remotes from Qu√©bec, Canada, Will and PA).
1.1 Good thing: the flexibility to work: 1.1 Good thing: the flexibility to work from wherever
You can work from wherever. Surf trip in: You can work from wherever. Surf trip in the Canary Islands for a bit? That‚Äôs happened for kiteboarder Will. Group trip to South Africa to escape Danish winter? 12 or so of us decided to do that. Granted, when things are normal again...
So if flexibility is important to you th: So if flexibility is important to you this is a huge win.
1.1 Flip side: lack of face time with co: 1.1 Flip side: lack of face time with colleagues
The flip side of working remotely is tha: The flip side of working remotely is that you have a whole bunch of virtual, awesome penpal colleagues.¬†
If you‚Äôre someone who requires regular: If you‚Äôre someone who requires regular face-to-face conversations with others, this could be hard for you.
This also means you‚Äôll be experiencing: This also means you‚Äôll be experiencing everything virtually, the good and the rough stuff ‚Äî from hiring to training. Are you comfortable having tough conversations concerning things like a salary discussion over Zoom instead of face-to-face?
1.2 Good thing: the autonomy to set your: 1.2 Good thing: the autonomy to set your schedule
Because you‚Äôre not in the office, you: Because you‚Äôre not in the office, you can manage your time accordingly. This means avoiding rush hour traffic, going to appointments when you need to, and being able to set concentration times where you aren‚Äôt interrupted and can just get through your work.
For this, you need to be self-motivated: For this, you need to be self-motivated and self-disciplined. Remote-work comes with a lot of trust. It‚Äôs your responsibility to stay motivated and to get through your workload as normal. This can be hard for people easily distracted, or who rely on others for guidelines or energy in the room.
It‚Äôs a very individual choice whether: It‚Äôs a very individual choice whether this will work for you or not. Be honest with yourself and see if it‚Äôs a realistic option for you, and the stage of career (and stage of life) in which you find yourself.
If you ask me, there are two things to l: If you ask me, there are two things to look at when it comes to qualifications ‚Äì academic studies and work-related qualifications.
Here‚Äôs the harsh reality: if you‚Äôre: Here‚Äôs the harsh reality: if you‚Äôre applying from a country unknown to the company, you might just not be considered qualified. I was talking as a South African to fellow South Africans, so the addressing the issue of being qualified comes from this point of view.
If you‚Äôre applying for a remote job, y: If you‚Äôre applying for a remote job, you‚Äôre competing with the rest of the world. This means that the company that you‚Äôre applying to probably hasn‚Äôt heard of your school, or your specific degree.
Let‚Äôs take South Africa, for instance,: Let‚Äôs take South Africa, for instance, where we have a fourth year degree called honours ‚Äì which doesn‚Äôt exist in most other markets. So unless you went to an Ivy League school or somewhere well known, let‚Äôs face it: your degree or school is probably relatively unknown.
‚ÄúFor example I went to well-known UCT: ‚ÄúFor example I went to well-known UCT in Cape Town and in Africa. But is that well-known to the world? At a global ranking of 229., I think not.‚Äù
In some parts of the world, education is: In some parts of the world, education is expensive and it‚Äôs a huge accomplishment to graduate with tertiary education. It takes hard work and it‚Äôs achieved by the minority.
In South Africa for example, only 6% of: In South Africa for example, only 6% of adults between 25-34 years old reach tertiary attainment.
Source:¬†OECD Education at a Glance 2018: Source:¬†OECD Education at a Glance 2018, South Africa
To me, this is pretty simple. If you‚Äôr: To me, this is pretty simple. If you‚Äôre a South African applying to jobs within the country, you have your degree and university that are proof of accomplishment. Employers will use this as a sign that you are qualified above the majority of the country.
In Denmark, however, at 40% the chances: In Denmark, however, at 40% the chances are high that you have attained tertiary education. On top of this, it‚Äôs not only free but the government also supports you financially during your studies.
In that same report, you also see that D: In that same report, you also see that Denmark is the country that spends the most of its wealth on education (7.9% of their GDP). So education is more of the norm, and less of an accomplishment there, if you‚Äôre looking at it from purely a statistical point of view.
If you‚Äôre used to being one of the acc: If you‚Äôre used to being one of the accomplished minority holding a degree that holds a lot of value in your country, be aware that your studies may seem less valuable to an employer abroad who is lacking the context.
The second part that I think people ofte: The second part that I think people often forget to think about is whether you are actually qualified from a work point of view. If people are applying for remote jobs ‚Äì they can be from everywhere.
Unless you‚Äôve been working for a massi: Unless you‚Äôve been working for a massively famous international (hey Google) then people might not recognise the company that you‚Äôve worked for. They also might not understand the context of your company within your environment.
Take Africa, for example. There‚Äôs incr: Take Africa, for example. There‚Äôs incredible work done here in the fintech scene (super inspiring stuff). This is to solve problems¬†like transferring money to people who have no bank accounts, which is such a fascinating scenario and the solution is very clever.
But this could easily be unknown to some: But this could easily be unknown to someone who isn‚Äôt working within the fintech space, or just doesn‚Äôt know much about the African tech scene. Even if you were the person who built M-Pesa, you might just have to explain what it is if you‚Äôre applying for work outside of Africa, for instance.
The big question I‚Äôd suggest asking yo: The big question I‚Äôd suggest asking yourself is a tough one: do you really feel that in your work experience that you‚Äôve come up with pioneering solutions to solve problems? If not, you might not be qualified from a work point of view.
Let‚Äôs assume after thing 1 (where you: Let‚Äôs assume after thing 1 (where you had to be honest with yourself and decide if remote work is even for you) you decided that remote work is definitely what you want. Here‚Äôs the next question: does what you want = what a company is looking for in that open position?
Chances are slim, if I‚Äôm honest. Loads: Chances are slim, if I‚Äôm honest. Loads of people are after these types of opportunities. This gives employers a great opportunity to be picky. If you really want this job you need to be a shoo-in and the obvious choice for the role.
So it doesn‚Äôt add up: how do you becom: So it doesn‚Äôt add up: how do you become qualified?
Once you‚Äôve admitted this to yourself: Once you‚Äôve admitted this to yourself you‚Äôre in a great place to do the work you need to do to become the candidate that is the obvious choice. If you ask me, it‚Äôs pretty simple, hard work that will get you there. I‚Äôll go into what you can change, as well as what you can‚Äôt.
If you think your skills aren‚Äôt up to: If you think your skills aren‚Äôt up to scratch: get them there. A lot of the time actions speak louder than words here. I‚Äôd recommend starting a side project or taking on new responsibilities at work to learn by doing here, make your mistakes, and become good at your niche.
I‚Äôd actually suggest that learning by: I‚Äôd actually suggest that learning by doing and showing results speaks better to your skillset than a six-week course filled with the latest buzz words. Buzz words aren‚Äôt showing how to do the job. Proving how good you with something you actually made does.
If you want to work remotely, your netwo: If you want to work remotely, your network and community will end up being virtual-heavy. Start that now. Join your community niche ‚Äì both internationally and locally. If you‚Äôre in customer success join a customer success Slack community and share knowledge. If there‚Äôs a MeetUp for your topic, join it. If there isn‚Äôt, make it.
Be involved in knowledge-sharing, find m: Be involved in knowledge-sharing, find mentors, and learn all about the trends coming up. This will make you an interesting hire, who brings a worldwide view (one of the reasons remotes are hired in the first place).
Become an expert in the domain: Become an expert in the domain
With this community comes the trends. Le: With this community comes the trends. Learn them, try them out, experiment and share the knowledge that you find. Go deep into your expertise, and become a domain expert. Get yourself on a stage, host talks, do blog posts, speak to others.
This curiosity will also mean you can br: This curiosity will also mean you can bring best practices to the company from different regions, and different mindsets. Different is good. Make sure you are ‚Äì you need to stand out here.
This one is not always obvious. But if y: This one is not always obvious. But if you‚Äôre trying to get your dream work lifestyle (working remotely) that will come at a cost. This may also be that you take a side step in your career ‚Äì perhaps you‚Äôve been managing a team.
Consider applying for jobs for which you: Consider applying for jobs for which you‚Äôre overqualified where you just do the job day to day and aren‚Äôt a manager. Apply at companies in high growth phases and you‚Äôll have the chance to manage teams again. Be humble: this is a marathon, not a sprint.
Your nationality, passport, or country‚Ä: Your nationality, passport, or country‚Äôs reputation. And with this, the thing no one would ever like to admit is:¬†bias in hiring. But let‚Äôs face it, people have it. We at Pleo do everything we can to avoid human bias, and we like to be as open-minded as possible. But still, you can show it even if you have the best intentions at heart.
I‚Äôve heard crazy things over the years: I‚Äôve heard crazy things over the years, I think it‚Äôs important that you know they‚Äôre out there. Things like uncommon accents can throw people and they can bring up concerns on your communication skills. Things like one bad internet connection session can make people assume that your country and its connectivity issues will make it difficult from which to work. Firewalls is another example of it sounding too difficult to work together. The list can be long. Be prepared.
I‚Äôd suggest not to try to hide your ba: I‚Äôd suggest not to try to hide your background, and instead use it as a selling factor. For example, working in African markets gives you a great perspective on emerging markets: seeing huge growth, ambition, and the desire to prove yourself that I‚Äôve seen way more here than in the established ones.
You‚Äôre going to have to overcome these: You‚Äôre going to have to overcome these biases, and probably work harder than someone who people have regularly worked with. Don‚Äôt get angry about this, get clever ‚Äì it‚Äôs possible to overcome.
The last thing you can‚Äôt change is tha: The last thing you can‚Äôt change is that some jobs are not remote suitable (yet). Apply for jobs that are popular as remote jobs. Don‚Äôt try to be the exception, follow the rule. This stuff is new and still seen as a bit risky to companies. You want to get this right and to get it to work for both you and the company.
I‚Äôm ready and qualified. Now what?: I‚Äôm ready and qualified. Now what?
It‚Äôs on! Now what? Get ready for a lot: It‚Äôs on! Now what? Get ready for a lot of hard work. But the good news is that lots of places are hiring remote-only now. Companies are realising that hiring doesn‚Äôt have to stop because a person can‚Äôt physically come in for an interview or relocate.
Some handy places to keep an eye out for: Some handy places to keep an eye out for remote jobs can be places like AngelList, Glassdoor, Slack communities, remote sites ‚Äì that sort of thing.
To land a remote job, do your homework,: To land a remote job, do your homework, prepare. You got this.

What‚Äôs the journey that brought you to being Head of Finance at Cookson Adventures?

Sam Bradley of Cookson Adventures found a way to combine his love of travel with his financial skills. With Pleo, his company found a way to work smarter, make travel expenses more secure‚Ä¶ and stage gladiator battles in ancient Roman ruins.
What‚Äôs the journey that brought you to: What‚Äôs the journey that brought you to being Head of Finance at Cookson Adventures?
I grew up on an apple farm in South Afri: I grew up on an apple farm in South Africa before I qualified, but travel is where my heart is. So I did a gap year in the Cotswolds, spent time in Peru, did a season at a ski resort in the US, then worked as a tour guide for safari companies in Zimbabwe and Zambia.  But I decided I better get a degree if I didn‚Äôt want to be doing random jobs my whole life!
So having avoided finance all the way th: So having avoided finance all the way through school, because I had this perception that accountants were boring, I realised my mind was more mathematical. Also, one of the most portable types of expertise is accountancy ‚Äì you can work on a hotel on a desert island, on a ski resort, anywhere.
After moving to London, I saw the job at: After moving to London, I saw the job at Cookson Adventures on LinkedIn. And I think they saw that I wasn‚Äôt just an accountant, that the love for travel is real.
We‚Äôre a luxury adventure company that: We‚Äôre a luxury adventure company that makes the impossible come to life. It‚Äôs all about taking those crazy dreams people have and making them happen. Whether that‚Äôs a submarine trip in the Mediterranean to see ancient shipwrecks, relocating giant tortoises to the Galapagos Islands or a flying safari in Antartica.
Cookson Adventures take a family ice cli: Cookson Adventures take a family ice climbing in Antarctica‚Äôs vast wilderness ¬© Cookson Adventures
And that same love of travel flows throu: And that same love of travel flows through everyone. When a new client enquiry comes in, we all sit down in the board room and brainstorm: ‚ÄúWhat are we going to do for this customer?‚Äù So everyone needs to have that passion for travel.
I‚Äôd known for a long time that there m: I‚Äôd known for a long time that there must be something better out there. Before this, I‚Äôd been using traditional bank business cards and it was an absolute nightmare.
People lose their receipts, they don‚Äôt: People lose their receipts, they don‚Äôt want you bugging them. They‚Äôve got better things to do ‚Äî and I‚Äôve got better things to do!
So after joining, I spent some time doin: So after joining, I spent some time doing a thorough investigation into the options out there. That‚Äôs when I found Pleo.
The biggest thing is: when we go off on: The biggest thing is: when we go off on a trip, it normally involves one of our guides taking up to $10,000 petty cash in their pockets and off they go.
You had the risk of travelling who knows: You had the risk of travelling who knows where, into weird and wonderful locations, with this money ‚Äî often in different currencies.
It was a security risk and reconciling w: It was a security risk and reconciling when they come back is a massive headache. They just give you a bag of receipts and it‚Äôs ‚Äúgood luck!‚Äù It was like going back to the Stone Age. Having Pleo helps massively with that as now most of our spending is done on Pleo. So our guides don‚Äôt need to carry as much cash and they don‚Äôt collect millions of receipts.
How did you pitch Pleo to the rest of th: How did you pitch Pleo to the rest of the company, especially as somebody new to Cookson Adventures?
We kept both live for at least a month:: We kept both live for at least a month: Pleo and the bank cards that we had been using. I told the team: ‚ÄúLet me run with Pleo, let me implement it, if you don‚Äôt like it, we can go back.‚Äù  Literally, within two weeks, everyone was like: ‚ÄúYou can cut up my bank card‚Äù because they had Pleo.
And because everyone making the decision: And because everyone making the decision [about how to handle expenses] needs to carry a card around, like the CEO and the Sales Director, they felt the pain of me bugging them for receipts. So that helped!
I remember someone coming to me, someone: I remember someone coming to me, someone who‚Äôs out of the office a lot. She was trying to give me a receipt, saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôve put it on Pleo, but here‚Äôs the receipt‚Äù. I told her she could throw it away because it was already recorded on Pleo, and she just looked at me. She couldn‚Äôt believe it!
Think of the spectrum of work for a fina: Think of the spectrum of work for a finance job like mine: the bottom end is the donkey work, inputting stuff. The top end is the strategy, analysing figures, doing cool stuff.
So the question is: where do you go on t: So the question is: where do you go on that spectrum? Pleo has meant a massive shift in how much time from an average day is spent on strategy and not donkey work. And I can be so much more friendly with everyone because I don‚Äôt have to ask them about their receipts!
For us, it‚Äôs about trying to be at the: For us, it‚Äôs about trying to be at the forefront of things. The way we put trips together, the way we handle our relationships with our clients, so having finance at the forefront of things too is a must.
It‚Äôs to keep exploring really. Every t: It‚Äôs to keep exploring really. Every trip for us has to be a first, so it‚Äôs striving to do more of that.   We definitely want to expand our reach, we‚Äôd like to open an office in the States, open an office in Asia, reach more people. Keep on delivering more imaginative experiences and world firsts.
An image of a man exploring Son Doong, t: An image of a man exploring Son Doong, the largest cave system in the world ¬© Cookson Adventures
I‚Äôve been at companies where everyone‚: I‚Äôve been at companies where everyone‚Äôs relaxed with expenses. If they see the CEO catches an Uber, they think it must be fine for them to get an Uber too. Then the policy changes, it tightens up and it‚Äôs a real culture shock for employees.
We hired gladiators to fight in an old R: We hired gladiators to fight in an old Roman amphitheatre, with the full equipment, for a family who was on the trip of a lifetime ‚Äì and we did it all on Pleo.
I think that the founder mentality of tr: I think that the founder mentality of treating the company like it‚Äôs your own company is so exciting. Encouraging employees to make every decision as if they own the business.

Despite it being the last few days of summer (‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre not giving up just yet), we‚Äôve been busy at Pleo. It‚Äôs been fun too, with our biggest ever group of new starters joining and a two-day team camp. On the product side, we‚Äôve also pushed several key features that have been eagerly anticipated. Here‚Äôs a recap of what‚Äôs happened with the Pleo software you use and the team that makes it.
The way companies top up their wallet ha: The way companies top up their wallet has been redesigned and improved to help you transfer money faster and easier. For starters, the one-time reference code is a thing of the past: as of earlier this month, admins have fixed transfer details. So your transfer details will never change, and can just be saved in your online bank for quicker top-ups.
We‚Äôve also changed how wallet top-ups: We‚Äôve also changed how wallet top-ups work in the backend, which makes the actual transfer of money from your bank to your Pleo account much faster.
In essence, with our old system, funds w: In essence, with our old system, funds were funnelled through an intermediary partner, sometimes causing delays and pains.
How to top-up your wallet Video: How to top-up your wallet Video
With our new set-up, you can send money: With our new set-up, you can send money to Pleo directly and we will load the funds as soon as we receive them from your bank.
Finally, the top-up page has been redesi: Finally, the top-up page has been redesigned to give admins more clarity over their cashflow in Pleo. They can also set up low balance alerts and view their top-up history in one click.
The manage expense view is the central p: The manage expense view is the central place from which admins and bookkeepers make expenses ready for export. The past year has been terrific here at: The past year has been terrific here at Pleo. We‚Äôve grown our organisation by some 400%, we‚Äôve successfully launched in the UK and we‚Äôve added lots of new functionality. 2017 is now coming to an end, and it‚Äôs time to look back and share some insights from our journey.
Our main focus has always been to listen: Our main focus has always been to listen to you and your needs and transform this into great product experiences. This way, we‚Äôve managed to enhance the experience of Pleo. We hope this has improved your internal workflows just like it has improved ours.
Besides shipping lots of new features, w: Besides shipping lots of new features, we have had some major learnings that might be interesting for you and your business.
Our major focus on listening to and obse: Our major focus on listening to and observing our customers has enabled us to 1) establish close relations with our customers and 2) help us drive the product in the right direction. Visiting our customers in their office is a high priority, as it gives us insights and relationships, that are hard to achieve through email or phone.
Among a million other things to do, this: Among a million other things to do, this can be hard to prioritize. But it has proven to be instrumental in our development and growth in Pleo.
We‚Äôre no better than our partners¬†üí: We‚Äôre no better than our partners¬†üí°
It‚Äôs obviously important to have relia: It‚Äôs obviously important to have reliable partners. Yet, it‚Äôs not trivial.
We have experienced the consequences of: We have experienced the consequences of having an unstable partner. Our payment processor‚Äôs instability has unfortunately affected some of our customers. On those occasions, we failed to deliver the sublime user experience we are striving for every single day. This has led to us changing our setup to avoid this happening going forward. We‚Äôll share more about that in 2018.
Fintech is a complex space and as a star: Fintech is a complex space and as a startup, it‚Äôs hard or almost impossible to bring a product to market without partnerships. Going with a partner that is well-known in the industry and widely used by other players, is no guarantee of quality.
In case your customers are affected by i: In case your customers are affected by incidents make sure to be transparent and honest. We have been trying to be nothing but transparent and compassionate and it has been highly appreciated by our affected customers despite the incidents.
We have written about our next steps in: We have written about our next steps in the¬†blog post back in November.
Launching new features in a stable but q: Launching new features in a stable but quick rhythm is key to continue delivering value to our customers. In the past year, we have shipped a lot of new features (visualised in the picture above), yet we know we can do even better.
Having a solid and talented engineering: Having a solid and talented engineering team combined with lots of product iterations has helped us deliver new features that have improved workflows (some would even say lives) of our customers. Still, we‚Äôre ongoingly trying to professionalize our processes and maintaining a streamlined overview of user feedback and feature requests at scale.
We‚Äôve recently started using ProductBo: We‚Äôve recently started using ProductBoard and so far it helps us to a) capture and centralize customer feedback, b) organize and validate ideas and features and c) share roadmaps. We are confident that this will help us prioritize product development and ship features at a higher pace in 2018.
We‚Äôre excited to enter 2018 with a gre: We‚Äôre excited to enter 2018 with a great pool of learnings, an expanding team and most importantly ‚Äì you as a valued customer.
Please continue to fuel us with your fee: Please continue to fuel us with your feedback and ideas and we will make sure to continue to simplify your business spending.

Lots has happened here at Pleo in May, not only on a product-level but also on a company-level. Here‚Äôs a recap of the exciting company news, as well as the product improvements that were made in the last 30 days.
We raised a series B round of $56m: We raised a series B round of $56m
Less than a year after raising our serie: Less than a year after raising our series A, we announced the closing of our Series B round earlier this month.
Not only is this the largest series B ro: Not only is this the largest series B round in Danish history, it‚Äôs also one of the largest ever for a Scandinavian company.
We‚Äôre happy to have Stripes Group lead: We‚Äôre happy to have Stripes Group leading this round and grateful that our existing investors (Kinnevik, Creandum and Founders) have renewed their support.
As we‚Äôve previously mentioned, this ne: As we‚Äôve previously mentioned, this new round of funding will help us expand Pleo to even more markets and allow us to develop new key features that will make Pleo better, faster and more comprehensive. More on that soon!
In May, we put a lot of focus and energy: In May, we put a lot of focus and energy into making admins‚Äô experience a whole lot better and smoother on Pleo.
First, we‚Äôve made archiving of tag gro: First, we‚Äôve made archiving of tag groups possible. Amongst other things, this new feature allows admins to archive as many tag groups as they want, but they can still only have three active tag groups at once. We hope this brings more flexibility into the daily workflows of admins on Pleo.
Admins can now also see foreign exchange: Admins can now also see foreign exchange and ATM fees in the Manage Expense view. In line with our mission, this gives them more transparency, which in turn allows them to get a better understanding of their company finances.
Finally, for our Sweden-based admins, we: Finally, for our Sweden-based admins, we released a brand new SIE file format. It includes cost centres and minor bug fixes that improve compatibility with Fortnox, Visma and other Swedish accounting systems.
The cards page in the mobile and web app: The cards page in the mobile and web apps got a design uplift.
The first important change we made for t: The first important change we made for the mobile version is to move the buttons below the card, giving more room for the card PAN preview when it‚Äôs hidden.
We‚Äôve also made the entire virtual car: We‚Äôve also made the entire virtual card Pleo pink, making it easily distinguishable from the physical card.
The cards page redesign comes with anoth: The cards page redesign comes with another important new feature: easily copy cards details to your clipboard.
Indeed, it has now never been easier to: Indeed, it has now never been easier to use your virtual card to make online purchases or subscriptions.
Simply log in to the web app, click on t: Simply log in to the web app, click on the page icon to the right of the card numbers on your virtual card and your cards details are copied to your clipboard!
Smoother drag and drop of files in the w: Smoother drag and drop of files in the web app
If you‚Äôre used attaching online receip: If you‚Äôre used attaching online receipts in the web app, you‚Äôre probably familiar with the drag and drop function.
Lately, we‚Äôve noticed that this experi: Lately, we‚Äôve noticed that this experience was not optimal, so we went ahead and fixed a few bugs.
Mainly, we added a slight time gap when: Mainly, we added a slight time gap when you drag your receipt over an expense, to make sure you‚Äôve selected the right one.
The result is a much smoother and better: The result is a much smoother and better experience, which will hopefully make your day a tiny bit better when you want to upload online receipts.
But if you‚Äôre tired of logging on to t: But if you‚Äôre tired of logging on to the web app to upload your receipts, there‚Äôs good news ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to. ‚ÄúShare to Pleo‚Äù is one of several ways to get your online receipts into Pleo straight from your mobile phone!
As always, there‚Äôs lots going on at Pl: As always, there‚Äôs lots going on at Pleo ‚Äî between the ambitious hiring targets, new market launches and product updates, this summer is shaping up to be very busy and productive for us.
Two of the major features that we are ho: Two of the major features that we are hoping to release soon are sure to make admins and employees alike excited.
Without revealing too much, wallet loads: Without revealing too much, wallet loads are about to become lighting fast, and manually getting your online receipts to Pleo could very well be a thing of the past.

A 9-step checklist to modernise your wor: A 9-step checklist to modernise your workforce

Your workforce is changing ‚Äì and it‚Äôs changing fast.
Some UK studies suggest there‚Äôs been a: Some UK studies suggest there‚Äôs been a 74% increase in the number of people working from home in the past decade. But the change is even deeper than that. Globalisation and rapid advances in technology are changing not just how we work, but also how we *think* about work.
There‚Äôs been a shift away from the con: There‚Äôs been a shift away from the concept of a job for life, with many members of the workforce opting instead for flexible work on their terms ‚Äì when they‚Äôre given the choice, of course.
Add in the gig economy (think short term: Add in the gig economy (think short term contracts or freelance work rather than traditional, permanent working arrangements) ‚Äì responsible for 1m jobs in the UK and millions more globally ‚Äì and you‚Äôve got a situation that brings opportunity. And a lot of uncertainty too.
Decision-makers are feeling an increasin: Decision-makers are feeling an increasing demand to empower their teams with preferred tools and techniques. It can be a daunting process at first, so here are nine straightforward ways to prepare for the workforce of tomorrow.
1. Provide support for autonomous and fl: 1. Provide support for autonomous and flexible workers
It‚Äôs not enough for employers to just: It‚Äôs not enough for employers to just introduce flexibility and increased autonomy for their workers ‚Äì it‚Äôs so important that they keep up a dialogue with those employees, encouraging them to maximise the opportunities afforded to them. After all, how good is autonomy if employees don‚Äôt feel truly trusted to innovate and try things out?
Progressive employers are realising that: Progressive employers are realising that the relationship has changed but they stand to gain hugely by fully buying into that.
Speaking candidly about this shift, one: Speaking candidly about this shift, one Senior Accenture Talent Manager stated:
‚ÄúThe war for talent is over. The emplo: ‚ÄúThe war for talent is over. The employee won. They demand from us the same level of choice and service as they do as consumers. Millennials are less interested in pensions and other benefits like equity or stock options. They value choice, autonomy, growth and purpose.‚Äù
While this can be a disconcerting change: While this can be a disconcerting change, businesses that support and enable this shift will reap the rewards. It‚Äôs not hard to tell a motivated new starter apart from a jaded veteran in the workplace. But imagine if you could unlock the enthusiasm of the experienced worker by showing them how much you trusted them? It‚Äôs a win-win.
2. Empower teams to work across borders: 2. Empower teams to work across borders
One of the most profound changes in the: One of the most profound changes in the modern workforce is the evolving way we interact with colleagues. Finding ways to cultivate a workspace that allows remote teams to flourish is a challenge but one that offers huge rewards.
(cranks up time machine) Just 20 or so y: (cranks up time machine) Just 20 or so years ago, most offices were still isolating employees into cubicles or in enclosed rooms. And while Office Space is a great movie, that style of layout doesn‚Äôt lend itself to collaboration.
Now, office spaces are typically open pl: Now, office spaces are typically open plan ‚Äì to encourage collaboration within and between teams.¬†
In plenty of other companies, there is a: In plenty of other companies, there is a shift towards remote collaboration ‚Äì with teams working from multiple locations, often in different timezones. (It‚Äôs something we embrace at Pleo. Just ask the Slovenian, British and Irish workers combining forces to bring you this list).
But great collaboration like this relies: But great collaboration like this relies on great software ‚Äì supporting the specific needs of the team.¬†
If it‚Äôs a remote design team, collabor: If it‚Äôs a remote design team, collaborative tools like Marvel or Abstract offer intuitive and powerful solutions. If it‚Äôs a remote content team, tools like Trello or Airtable can streamline the content management process.
If I miss your call, you‚Äôll hear my au: If I miss your call, you‚Äôll hear my automated message apologise for missing you‚Ä¶ and tell you if you really want to get me, you won‚Äôt leave me a voicemail. You‚Äôll text me instead. Or hit me up on Whatsapp. Or reach out on Slack. I can‚Äôt stand voicemails, but that‚Äôs not a problem because there are 503 other ways to reach me.
In today‚Äôs workplace, Slack and Skype: In today‚Äôs workplace, Slack and Skype can keep your team connected throughout the day, no matter where individuals are. It frees employees up to travel and work abroad, without sacrificing productivity.
One suggestion though is to establish gu: One suggestion though is to establish guidelines on ‚Äúswitch off time‚Äù. Most people won‚Äôt mind a call or WhatsApp message at 7pm in case of an emergency, but they probably won‚Äôt appreciate a random Slack notification to share the latest Stranger Things meme.
4. Develop a culture of continuous feedb: 4. Develop a culture of continuous feedback
One of the more outdated practices withi: One of the more outdated practices within the corporate world is that of performance reviews.
These annual or semi-annual reviews are: These annual or semi-annual reviews are intended to evaluate how well a particular employee is performing, but in reality tend to only create extra tension throughout the office when they‚Äôre taking place. Everyone can remember that feeling when a review was approaching ‚Äì the pressure to not screw anything up often leading to an almost inevitable screw-up.
A better approach is for managers to com: A better approach is for managers to communicate daily with their team and use collaborative tools to give them real-time feedback on tasks. This not only reduces the stress caused by an annual review but also facilitates faster, more actionable insights on actual performance.
5. Insist on work-life balance. Yes, ins: 5. Insist on work-life balance. Yes, insist.
From striking workers in Germany pushing: From striking workers in Germany pushing for flexible hours to sweeping changes to the strictures of Japanese work culture, evidence of people becoming increasingly resistant to the rat race is hard to miss. A CIPD (Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development) report suggested the UK ranks poorly for work-life balance compared to comparative economies, so the issue seems unlikely to go away.
Improving work-life balance for employee: Improving work-life balance for employees also helps to reduce burnout, often cited as one of the leading causes behind employee turnover. Providing employees with flexible hours, working around personal events, and switching from fixed hours to a deliverable-based environment are great ways to boost employee morale.
Work-life balance can also be improved w: Work-life balance can also be improved while employees are still at work. They might feel like a gimmick at first, but implementing features like exercise rooms or meditation areas can help employees pursue personal goals within the office space. If they don‚Äôt sound like a great fit for your team, why not canvas opinion on what does?
Trusting employees to help drive the dir: Trusting employees to help drive the direction of your business can have huge rewards for companies, boosting job satisfaction and potentially unlocking new ways of working better. But just paying lip service to workers‚Äô input isn‚Äôt sufficient, with CIPD research showing that only 40% of employees feel their superiors are good at listening.
So how can leaders do better at encourag: So how can leaders do better at encouraging employee engagement?
Transparency is one big step. Celebratin: Transparency is one big step. Celebrating achievements is easy (and fun!), but speak candidly about low points too. If teams aren‚Äôt reaching their goals, ask them about pain points that management might be unaware of. Even if there‚Äôs nothing that can immediately be done, employees will likely value being heard about problems they‚Äôre tackling in the trenches.
Finding the right forum for engagement c: Finding the right forum for engagement can help too. Some of your staff might love to offer up ideas in a committee setting, while for others, a one-to-one or digital suggestion box might work better.
Learning how to listen is vital ‚Äì and: Learning how to listen is vital ‚Äì and yes, it is something you can learn. Whether it‚Äôs thinking about a conversation or meeting as a form of meditation (ie clear your mind of other things) or trialling a ‚Äúlistening stick‚Äù (you can‚Äôt speak until the other person hands you the stick ‚Äì maybe try this one at home first), there are ways to ensure employees know you‚Äôre really listening.
Rather than replacing jobs, automation i: Rather than replacing jobs, automation is helping to make many employees faster, smarter, and more efficient.
So many of the roles that employees fill: So many of the roles that employees fill are spent doing menial, repetitive work. These kinds of jobs take a toll on employees, not to mention distracting people from more high-impact work.
Automation has the ability to offload th: Automation has the ability to offload these more repetitive, time-consuming tasks so that your employees can work on things that matter more to them and the company as a whole.
Find areas that it makes sense to automa: Find areas that it makes sense to automate within your business, for example company spending, and then use that time saved to engage your workforce in meaningful, high-value tasks.
We spoke earlier about how remote workin: We spoke earlier about how remote working is increasingly popular ‚Äì but more than that, it‚Äôs something to be encouraged. The benefits include increased productivity and lower overhead costs for businesses.
Employees‚Äô work also tends to be more: Employees‚Äô work also tends to be more effective, as there is more focus on delivered work rather than hours worked. Now that it has become less important for employees to be in the same physical location, we are seeing a massive increase in remote work.
Embrace this change and find ways to emp: Embrace this change and find ways to empower it.
9. Share the values of your employees: 9. Share the values of your employees
Sustainability, workplace diversity, cor: Sustainability, workplace diversity, corporate responsibility. Millennials care about all of them, but‚Ä¶ how much?¬†
One US study suggested 64% of employees: One US study suggested 64% of employees in that age bracket won‚Äôt take a job if the company doesn‚Äôt have strong social values. Meanwhile, 86% of female millennials in a PwC report said their employer‚Äôs policy on diversity was important to them.
A lot of companies talk the talk on thes: A lot of companies talk the talk on these issues, but how to truly make this a core strength of your modernising business? One answer seems to be: involve everyone.
There‚Äôs a common trend in companies th: There‚Äôs a common trend in companies that have made sustainability work, argues this Harvard Business Review piece. Those firms have made sustainability everyone‚Äôs responsibility, in a goal-oriented and structured way. It‚Äôs a great approach to tackle one of the key issues of our time but also to engage every level of employee, from CEO down.
The trend of focusing on the happiness a: The trend of focusing on the happiness and well-being of employees isn‚Äôt actually a trend. It‚Äôs progress.
The modern economy is dominated by jobs: The modern economy is dominated by jobs that require intense intellectual effort.
There‚Äôs a battle for talent and the be: There‚Äôs a battle for talent and the best employees know to look for companies that boast a good track record on worker well-being. They want you to go beyond vague promises to show in practical terms how well you treat workers. Prospective hires are less afraid to ask questions about work-life balance and the input they‚Äôll have with leadership.¬†
So why not come up with answers now, rat: So why not come up with answers now, rather than when employees you want to hire or retain turn the tables and ask you some tough questions?

Matthew Booth from Blu Sky Chartered Acc: Matthew Booth from Blu Sky Chartered Accountants, one of our accounting partners, explains the benefits of Pleo for both, their practice and their clients, in this guest blog post.
This is guest blog post written by Matth: This is guest blog post written by Matthew Booth from Blu Sky Chartered Accountants, an award-winning accounting and bookkeeping firm.
One of the main problems that clients an: One of the main problems that clients and accountants have are obtaining receipts. Here at Blu Sky, we are becoming paperless with over 90% of records coming in via the cloud. Therefore, we are always on the lookout for new and upcoming applications which can benefit both our clients and ourselves.
We first discovered Pleo due to one of o: We first discovered Pleo due to one of our clients looking for a solution to get rid of numerous company credit cards as well managing cash flow. Pleo has the capabilities of addressing these issues but giving the necessary flexibility to employees to complete day-to-day activities.
How does Pleo benefit our clients?: How does Pleo benefit our clients?
There are various benefits that our clie: There are various benefits that our clients have received from using Pleo:
For the employees that have a Pleo card: For the employees that have a Pleo card and have downloaded the Pleo app, we have seen month on month that the amount of VAT Receipts being obtained have increased. When a purchase is made, a notification is sent to the employee‚Äôs phone reminding them to take a picture of the receipt.
Having this feature means that our clien: Having this feature means that our client is reclaiming as much VAT as possible. As there is an analytics feature, the company owners can see who is forgetting to upload receipts and so processes can be established to help employees obtain as many receipts as possible.
For our clients that mainly focus on cas: For our clients that mainly focus on cash and maintaining a healthy bank balance, they can limit how much a particular person can spend. Although setting limits may be seen as a negative, the fact that employees have been given Pleo cards gives them more authority and responsibility.
The analytics feature in Pleo has enable: The analytics feature in Pleo has enabled clients to see a variety of important data, which can help them manage their business.
First of all, there are graphs which sho: First of all, there are graphs which shows where most of the company money is getting spent. This could range from Food and Drink to travel expenses. The availability of this data has helped clients see where savings could be made. For example, if a client has spent the most on train tickets they can look into purchasing train tickets earlier in order to reduce the cost.
Secondly, the analytics dashboard shows: Secondly, the analytics dashboard shows clients which users forget to upload receipts. This has been used by clients to communicate back to their employees and highlight the importance of obtaining receipts. Finally, the analytics dashboard also shows which supplier receives most money. Depending on the amount being spent we have highlighted to clients that using this information may mean they could negotiate discounts due to consistent service.
No One is Out of Pocket:: No One is Out of Pocket:
This is probably the main benefit for cl: This is probably the main benefit for clients‚Äô employees. Having the ability to save their own personal cash in order to maintain their own personal cash flow is a weight off anyone‚Äôs shoulders. The resources required to keep on top of: The resources required to keep on top of the paperwork and ensure that every claim is legitimate (and that employees are paid in a timely manner) can often cost far more than the return you‚Äôll get on the expense being made in the first place.
Employee satisfaction is one of the majo: Employee satisfaction is one of the major issues with a manual system.
Most employees paying for travel expense: Most employees paying for travel expenses will be using their own accounts, and for larger travel payments, even having to wait a week to be reimbursed could put them deeply out of pocket. Manual processes make it much more diffi: Manual processes make it much more difficult to keep a real-time track of company money. Since companies usually wait for employees to submit their claims, there is often a delay in data for how company money is being spent.

From Pritt Sticks and Excel to digital a: From Pritt Sticks and Excel to digital accounting
Digital accounting ... are you ready for: Digital accounting ... are you ready for it?
I‚Äôve been working for Pleo for about f: I‚Äôve been working for Pleo for about five months now and I‚Äôm honestly shocked to see how many companies still collect paper receipts and quite literally glue together their expense reports.
Pritt Sticks, staplers and printed forms: Pritt Sticks, staplers and printed forms
‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure these are exception: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure these are exceptions‚Äù, I was thinking to myself, when CFOs kept explaining to me how their employees glue paper receipts to a printed form, only to fill it in and sign it by hand (sometimes even adding a stamp).
Little did I know that these were not ac: Little did I know that these were not actually exceptions.
Instead, it was a perfect description of:
Instead, it was a perfect description of the status quo of ‚Äòmodern bookkeeping‚Äô. In many cases, the external bookkeeper receives these receipts by post. For me, this is an extremely old school and incredibly time-consuming process.

Hours are spent on making sure receipts end up on the bookkeeper‚Äôs table, categorising and matching receipts with respective items on credit card bills, and entering the data into the accounting system.

Every. Single. Expense. It still leave me speechless.
\"Can I ask why a forward-thinking compa:
"Can I ask why a forward-thinking company like yours is handling these processes in such an old school way?", I want to know. 

The answer takes some time, but certainly doesn't lack conviction: "Well.. because we‚Äôve always done it this way!"

This is usually followed by a short conversation around how well these processes work, how they have proven to be efficient over decades, and that there is currently no room for improvement. 

"Interesting!" I answer. "Have you ever thought about digitising these processes?"

I (truthfully) add that they cannot only save on workload, time and money, but also gain real-time overview and transparency over their company spending.

A second of silence. Eventually, the typical replies range from ‚Äúnot desired by the board‚Äù to "not a priority right now"... and sometimes: "We want our employees to pay out of pocket to ensure that they hand in their receipts." 

I have to admit, these sound like excuses to me. I want to dig deeper. What are the real reasons here? Resistance to change? Is finance a delicate subject when it comes to new tools? Is management known for generally turning down new ideas?
A light at the end of the tunnel?: A light at the end of the tunnel?
We might experience some tension in sale:
We might experience some tension in sales calls, but the wide reality is that businesses are ready and willing to go digital.
