Super Human: Why mental health is a lead: Super Human: Why mental health is a leadership priority
How leaders can ensure they're looking a: How leaders can ensure they're looking after the mental health of their teams right now.
Recent times have seen a considerable sh: Recent times have seen a considerable shift in how we do some of the simplest things. How we go about our day, how we spend time with loved ones, and how we work.¬†
A lot of these changes are outside of ou: A lot of these changes are outside of our control.
But for leaders, the emotional and menta: But for leaders, the emotional and mental health of your employees is something that you can have a direct impact on during the working day. So it‚Äôs important to get it right.
We looked into the mental health impact: We looked into the mental health impact the current crisis is having right now, and asked experts how business leaders can step up to prioritise support for their employees.
Beyond Slack, Zoom and Houseparty, here': Beyond Slack, Zoom and Houseparty, here's how business leaders can really "be there" for their team ‚Äì without being there.
Set your team up to succeed: Set your team up to succeed
This is not a time to test your team on: This is not a time to test your team on their resourcefulness.
It‚Äôs vital to make sure that everyone: It‚Äôs vital to make sure that everyone in your business has access to the equipment and information they need, to set your team up for success from the get go.
As Steve Hoblyn, a leadership and mental: As Steve Hoblyn, a leadership and mental health coach states, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs never been a better time for leaders to know their teams, so they can recognise any changes and where they can provide help‚Äù.¬†
It‚Äôs a big change, and working from ho: It‚Äôs a big change, and working from home isn‚Äôt something everyone is comfortable with.
Make sure you give your team advice on b: Make sure you give your team advice on best practices, and offer support if people are struggling to get used to this new way of working. Emphasise that remote working doesn‚Äôt have to mean working alone, thanks to the wide array of tools available.
At a time of uncertainty, what you say,: At a time of uncertainty, what you say, and how you say it, are imperative. As a leader, your role should be to reassure your people.
For Geoff McDonald, a mental health advo: For Geoff McDonald, a mental health advocate, the delivery of the message is just as important as what you say. ‚ÄúPeople get less reassurance when the message is written. Take the time to hop on a Zoom call to open the floor up to questions and thoughts, so you can address concerns head on.‚Äù
Geoff goes on to discuss the four key pr: Geoff goes on to discuss the four key principles of communicating effectively as a leader, stating that ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crucial to instil trust, hope, stability and compassion in every message you put out there.
\"You have to make sure that you are wil: "You have to make sure that you are willing to trust your employees, as much as they trust you. Reducing some of the uncertainty by delivering facts, not hearsay, will instil stability.‚Äù
Even if you don‚Äôt have all the answers: Even if you don‚Äôt have all the answers, it‚Äôs important to convey that you will do your best by your people, and will continue to keep everyone updated on the changing situation.
Keep the communication consistent, by ma: Keep the communication consistent, by making sure that all leaders within the organisation are on the same page.¬†
And rather than being ambiguous, it is i: And rather than being ambiguous, it is important to give people something tangible to hold onto,¬†such as sharing success stories from other companies.
Take a look around at what your customer: Take a look around at what your customers, friends and even your rivals are doing.
You might be surprised to see some inter: You might be surprised to see some interesting initiatives that could inspire you.
Sophie Theen, Chief People Officer at Oa: Sophie Theen, Chief People Officer at Oakam, advises that ‚Äúbusinesses should take this time to look and explore the practices of other companies, and use their success stories to navigate their own way through the crisis, and do the best by their people.‚Äù¬†
This isn‚Äôt business as usual, and it d: This isn‚Äôt business as usual, and it doesn‚Äôt need to be.
To lead effectively, you need to underst: To lead effectively, you need to understand the psychological impact of being in lockdown, and being away from loved ones.
There will be a change in routine, mood: There will be a change in routine, mood and behaviours, all of which are totally understandable.
Your team may not operate at full capaci: Your team may not operate at full capacity over this time, but the worst thing you could do is to stay connected by closely watching when people are online, or overwhelming your team with an abundance of unnecessary meetings.
Finding a healthy balance is key: have a: Finding a healthy balance is key: have a forum for your team to catch up and share challenges, but give them the autonomy to plan their own working day.
Many people will have to juggle looking: Many people will have to juggle looking after children with their daily work.
Instead of chastising parents for having: Instead of chastising parents for having children on their call, Steve Hoblyn advises that ‚Äúgiving people permission to be themselves can speak volumes about your company, and you as a leader‚Äù.¬†
Vulnerability is a huge force at play du: Vulnerability is a huge force at play during this time.
Whether you‚Äôre in a senior position, o: Whether you‚Äôre in a senior position, or have just started at a company, no one is immune to the feelings of worry and stress that present themselves in times of crisis. And that‚Äôs valuable to remember.
We often talk about physical vulnerabili: We often talk about physical vulnerabilities in relation to the crisis, but mental health is just as essential to consider. For many people within your organisation, these unwanted feelings will feel new and unsettling, and they may not have effective ways of coping.¬†
Meanwhile, others may have already had e: Meanwhile, others may have already had experiences of poor mental health, and will have a better understanding of the kind of help they need. Whatever the situation, it‚Äôs imperative that you provide the right levels of support for everyone.
Make sure you have trained managers to l: Make sure you have trained managers to listen to their people, as they will often be the first port of call. Ensure that they feel supported to spot any changes in behaviour, as well as have those all-important conversations with their team if necessary.¬†¬†
These circumstances may lead people to d: These circumstances may lead people to disclose mental health problems they had previously not done so at work, so train your team to treat these new disclosures in a compassionate and respectful way.¬†
Having a strong HR team to provide guida: Having a strong HR team to provide guidance is invaluable at this time.
It‚Äôs their role to provide any leader: It‚Äôs their role to provide any leader or manager within the business with the correct information, and steer the wider team in the right direction.
At Oakam, Sophie‚Äôs team hosts weekly c: At Oakam, Sophie‚Äôs team hosts weekly confidential mental health support groups, which cover a wide array of concerns that team members may be having. She sees it as a chance for her HR team to ‚Äúreally step up, as they have the power to hold the company together by making the right decisions by their people.‚Äù
It‚Äôs also an important time to take st: It‚Äôs also an important time to take stock of the kind of support you can actually offer your people.
For so many companies, the physical and: For so many companies, the physical and mental health of their people hasn‚Äôt been a key concern, and Employee Assistance Programmes often fall by the wayside or remain unused.¬†
If you have mental health first aiders w: If you have mental health first aiders within your organisation, use them.
It‚Äôs never been more crucial that the: It‚Äôs never been more crucial that the right kind of help and support is provided to your people, so you can emerge out of the other side of this crisis in a good place.
Bossing it: Why now's the perfect time f: Bossing it: Why now's the perfect time for leaders to be more vulnerable
In 2020, vulnerability in leadership is: In 2020, vulnerability in leadership is more than just hype. Everyone can learn to use their soft side for the benefit of their whole team. We'll tell you how.
This has been a year that has forced eac: This has been a year that has forced each and every one of us to rethink so much of our lives ‚Äì including work.
In many cases, old methods simply aren't: In many cases, old methods simply aren't an option and it's become necessary to find new approaches.
In other areas, it's more a case of 2020: In other areas, it's more a case of 2020 providing an opportunity to pause and reconsider. To think about the path we were on.
One of those areas is leadership and how: One of those areas is leadership and how leaders can (and should) show vulnerability. Because in 2020, I've really seen that when they do, the whole team benefits.
The last few months have presented the p: The last few months have presented the perfect opportunity for ideas that once seemed like underdog approaches to seize the moment.
With everything shifting so fast, ideas: With everything shifting so fast, ideas had a new chance to flourish and spread.
As a manager, I‚Äôm glad to see one of m: As a manager, I‚Äôm glad to see one of my favourite topics (up to now an underdog in business debates) is increasingly on the agenda: Vulnerability in business leaders.
Dan Rose, who's worked at Facebook and A: Dan Rose, who's worked at Facebook and Amazon, went viral with his very open discussion about his own shortcomings.
Meanwhile, Lea Sophie Cramer, German fou: Meanwhile, Lea Sophie Cramer, German founder and member of the advisory board at Amorelie, recently published a highly-acclaimed article on vulnerability as a factor in entrepreneurial success.
\"Especially in times of crisis we reali: "Especially in times of crisis we realise: vulnerability is a leadership superpower. We should embrace it more often,‚Äù she wrote.
That piece really resonated with people: That piece really resonated with people ‚Äì including me. Because frankly, I can‚Äôt remember a better time to talk about openness at work ‚Äì and the benefits it offers.
Vulnerability ‚Äì the ace up your sleeve: Vulnerability ‚Äì the ace up your sleeve
So, how can vulnerability become a manag: So, how can vulnerability become a manager's trump card on the way to greater productivity? How does vulnerability help create high-performance teams, where each individual delivers their best, every single day?
The short answer is that it promotes tru: The short answer is that it promotes trust.¬†
Trust in a team leads to increased emoti: Trust in a team leads to increased emotional commitment at work, which in turn motivates better performance.¬†
The Harvard Business Review reports that: The Harvard Business Review reports that people at high-trust companies experience 74% less stress, 106% more energy at work and 50% higher productivity compared with people at low-trust companies.
The long answer to the vulnerability que: The long answer to the vulnerability question is really interesting too.¬†
Just 8% of employees felt an emotional b: Just 8% of employees felt an emotional bond with their employer, according to 2016 research by Gallup.¬†
The loss of productivity caused by this: The loss of productivity caused by this lack of connection is immense for companies throughout the UK. To be more specific: Gallup estimates that disengaged employees cost the UK economy ¬£52 - ¬£72 billion per year, through lost productivity and errors.
Google analysed its high-performance tea: Google analysed its high-performance teams in 2015, with the aim of identifying their essence and applying it to other departments. They discovered that groups that perform at their best stand apart in one major respect ‚Äì they enjoy a more open work environment.
Team members do not hesitate to ask each: Team members do not hesitate to ask each other for help and advice. They make each other aware of company developments and push each other towards setting the right priorities. If everyone feels comfortable and valued, a much more honest and direct form of communication is enabled, which in return encourages agile and rapid action within the company.
Teams like this embrace the concept of p: Teams like this embrace the concept of psychological safety. Trust between members is so strong that everyone can develop freely, reach their full potential and make bolder decisions with the support of their colleagues.
I speak from personal experience when I: I speak from personal experience when I say that even tiny amounts of friction over a long period of time can have large repercussions.¬†
Imagine that we all carry around a rucks: Imagine that we all carry around a rucksack with our work frustrations in it. Friction means that rucksack gets a little heavier every day ‚Äì until you eventually collapse under its weight... Or simply throw it away (to start loading up a new rucksack at a different job).¬†
Companies don't gain anything from bagga: Companies don't gain anything from baggage that leads to burnout or sudden layoffs of long-time employees.
So don‚Äôt hide behind a mask, just for: So don‚Äôt hide behind a mask, just for the sake of ‚Äúprofessionalism‚Äù.¬†
Be vulnerable. Take the ‚Äúboss‚Äù mask: Be vulnerable. Take the ‚Äúboss‚Äù mask off, be yourself and work hard to build trust with your colleagues.
It‚Äôs not easy, sure. But it is easier: It‚Äôs not easy, sure. But it is easier than you think.
How to use vulnerability as a superpower: How to use vulnerability as a superpower
1. Make it a habit to share about yourse: 1. Make it a habit to share about yourself
What goes around comes around. So as a m: What goes around comes around. So as a manager (or simply as a person who wants to engage), become a role model.¬†
Set yourself a daily goal of sharing a l: Set yourself a daily goal of sharing a little personal story with your team. Tell colleagues what moves you, what mood you are in, where you have made mistakes or where you have done something particularly well.¬†
Take the opportunity to reflect, practic: Take the opportunity to reflect, practice your awareness and train those sharing muscles.
US psychologist Arthur Arons developed 3: US psychologist Arthur Arons developed 36 questions that served as a basis for people to build a deep and lasting bond. The experiment is also known as "36 questions that can make you fall in love".¬†
Aron‚Äôs thesis (backed up by similar re: Aron‚Äôs thesis (backed up by similar research) is that intimate bonds are created through intensive and regular communication ‚Äì but especially through finding common ground.
So why not give it a try and use this kn: So why not give it a try and use this knowledge to create a more personal bond with your team? It's not about finding friends or partners for life. It is about getting to know and understand your colleagues and their needs.¬†
Let your people talk about their biggest: Let your people talk about their biggest losses in the last year (And hey, don't exclude yourself. Maybe even start the conversation by talking about your own losses). In doing so, you not only create a safe space to show vulnerability, but you will most likely encounter a lot of mutual compassion, and possibly even common ground.
Let's start to define your team through: Let's start to define your team through similarities rather than differences.¬†
3. Become transparent in your actions wh: 3. Become transparent in your actions when delegating¬†
Practice sharing responsibility, informa: Practice sharing responsibility, information, knowledge and skills.¬†
For all newbies to this practice, I reco: For all newbies to this practice, I recommend taking a small step every day. Start by thinking about what information it is that you could share with your team to give them an advantage.
Is there a chance to delegate certain re: Is there a chance to delegate certain responsibilities or even spread them across the team? Your actions will prove that you truly trust your employees ‚Äì and in return they will start to truly trust in you.¬†
This is how you strengthen team spirit,: This is how you strengthen team spirit, promote innovation and support the finding of creative solutions.
The time has come to embrace vulnerabili: The time has come to embrace vulnerability
At Pleo, we attach great importance to t: At Pleo, we attach great importance to the philosophy that showing vulnerability isn‚Äôt just a personal characteristic, but can become part of a company‚Äôs identity.¬†
What I like to call ‚Äúdaring leadership: What I like to call ‚Äúdaring leadership‚Äù can really work.
By a daring leader, I mean someone who d: By a daring leader, I mean someone who dares to be vulnerable. Who develops a deeper understanding of what's beneath the surface and works to connect with her employees. A daring leader understands that communication on a personal level ultimately improves the team's cooperation and performance.
Working together feels easy because we r: Working together feels easy because we really know each other. Think of team sports, such as football: The best results are achieved when team spirit is high and everyone relies on each other.¬†
And by the way: Not all players have to: And by the way: Not all players have to be best friends for this to work!
2020 is without doubt a year of upheaval: 2020 is without doubt a year of upheaval. The time has come to leave our comfort zones and come to work as the people we truly are. Ditch the armour and we‚Äôll be doing ourselves, our teams and our companies a real favour.

How Engineering Efficiency Weeks help us: How Engineering Efficiency Weeks help us develop the future of Pleo
In June the team gathered for Engineerin: In June the team gathered for Engineering Efficiency Week, where the main focus was to address the growing size of one of our micro-services.
Building software comes with many challe: Building software comes with many challenges.¬†
One of them is making sure to strike a b: One of them is making sure to strike a balance between the excitement of building exciting new features and taking care of TTT: Tedious Technical Tasks.
If we only focus on those new features,: If we only focus on those new features, we start accumulating cruft in our code. Cruft is designer-speak for stuff that‚Äôs left over, useless, or getting in the way. It‚Äôs a problem that‚Äôs often referred to as Technical Debt.¬†
Cruft makes it harder to build simple th: Cruft makes it harder to build simple things, plus it can also bring instability to a system. We want to invest energy into making it easier and smoother to build new features. These are investments that pay off big in the long term.
In order to simplify the delicate balanc: In order to simplify the delicate balancing act between features and those maintenance tasks, we've created Engineering Efficiency Weeks (EEW) at Pleo, where every engineer focuses their energy on building things to help developers be more efficient in the future.
A micro-service is an application within: A micro-service is an application within Pleo that performs a specific task. For example, expense management or card transaction processing.
A micro-service works best when focusing: A micro-service works best when focusing on a niche responsibility, as opposed to being in charge of doing everything.
This isn‚Äôt always easy to achieve. A c: This isn‚Äôt always easy to achieve. A common tendency is to "just add one more small thing" to a service, which makes it bigger and less manageable over time.¬†
For us, this has led to one of our micro: For us, this has led to one of our micro-services growing into a bit of a jack-of-all-trades, handling many different responsibilities around many different business flows. It also requires multiple teams to share ownership ‚Äì not ideal.
As part of this EEW, a team of three eng: As part of this EEW, a team of three engineers picked up the task of moving one of these responsibilities (processing card transactions) into a brand new micro-service.
This requires a lot of careful planning: This requires a lot of careful planning and cross-team expertise. It‚Äôs not something a single engineer should take on, but it is perfect EEW material.
We've also been able to make improvement: We've also been able to make improvements to our core infrastructure: a team of 4 developers, together with the site-reliability team, worked on migrating services from our self-managed Kubernetes cluster to EKS (Amazon's managed Kubernetes service). This greatly eases cluster management, and improves the security and availability of our services. Collaboration for this project was key: our site-reliability engineers have the know-how around Kubernetes and Terraform, while the developers understand the services, and were thus able to quickly assess that each service migration went successfully.
But it's not only our back-end services: But it's not only our back-end services and infrastructure that we got to work on. We were also busy improving the user interface of our app.
We did a long-overdue codebase cleanup r: We did a long-overdue codebase cleanup removing thousands of lines of unused code, making our app run smoother and faster.¬†
A few months back we started a project o: A few months back we started a project of building a design system - a set of tools that will help us keep Pleo experiences coherent and accessible. This week we finally got to try out this new system! Bonus points to you if you noticed the typography and whitespace across our web app as more consistent and harmonious. ü§ì
We also got a chance to implement some b: We also got a chance to implement some big changes to how the core of our web experience works - how we download data from the servers and display it on the screen. We see this as an efficiency booster in the future, making it much easier to add new features and maintain a top quality user experience as our app grows.
What it means for you (and us): What it means for you (and us)
The impact on how Pleo technically works: The impact on how Pleo technically works is big.¬†
A separate, clean micro-service is much: A separate, clean micro-service is much easier to build upon or to scale, if it becomes a bottleneck. It also enables us to define tighter security rules, and monitor that the micro-service is functioning as it should.
For Pleo users, this means even more sta: For Pleo users, this means even more stable operation, stronger security, and quicker feature turnaround.
There are other internal benefits to thi: There are other internal benefits to this approach.
One of them is that our product teams ar: One of them is that our product teams are centred around specific product areas. The teams include designers, product managers and engineers. These vertical structures are great to ensure autonomy and high velocity when shipping features.¬†
However, it means that a back-end engine: However, it means that a back-end engineer in a certain team won't have many opportunities to interact with a back-end engineer in another team. Engineering Efficiency Weeks allows all engineers of a given speciality to work together on a project. This helps with knowledge-sharing, as they'll figure out techniques and best practices together, while working on something concrete.¬†
It also helps create links between engin: It also helps create links between engineers and ensure we have the opportunity to work with different people. Some people even try totally different roles depending on their focus ‚Äì a lot of fun and a big chance to develop their skills.
We're already seeing great results from: We're already seeing great results from reworking the length and frequency of our EEWs.
The enhancement projects we've been able: The enhancement projects we've been able to undertake have a wider scope and are more impactful. Synchronizing the timing of our efficiency sprints with quarters has also simplified how designers and product managers can manage their commitments and roadmap.
We‚Äôre already counting down the days t: We‚Äôre already counting down the days to the next EEW ‚Äì thanks for taking the time to read about this one!
By The Book: Rasmus Vendelbo, Proces Kon: By The Book: Rasmus Vendelbo, Proces Konsulenterne

The house that Pleo built: Security, inf: The house that Pleo built: Security, infrastructure and how we keep your money safe
Keeping your money safe matters to us ‚Ä: Keeping your money safe matters to us ‚Äì a lot. We've worked hard to make sure your transactions are as secure as possible.
Lifting the lid on how Pleo works is som: Lifting the lid on how Pleo works is something we like to do. Whether that‚Äôs talking about how we hire or sharing information about product features in development.
Another aspect we‚Äôre keen to shine the: Another aspect we‚Äôre keen to shine the spotlight on ‚Äì because it‚Äôs something we‚Äôve thought about a lot ‚Äì is how Pleo is set up to keep customers‚Äô funds as safe as possible.
We‚Äôre talking about the structure of h: We‚Äôre talking about the structure of how money flows through Pleo.
Why this is on our mind: Why this is on our mind
You might not follow fintech news as avi: You might not follow fintech news as avidly as we do. That‚Äôs OK ‚Äì in fact, it‚Äôs probably a good idea.
One of the biggest stories in our world: One of the biggest stories in our world lately was the collapse of German payments group Wirecard, something that sent undeniable shockwaves across business in Europe.
Wirecard‚Äôs problems had major knock-on: Wirecard‚Äôs problems had major knock-on effects for a number of fintech companies who had partnered with them.
We really feel for the customers of thos: We really feel for the customers of those companies that were affected ‚Äì and the hard-working teams that scrambled to find solutions for those fintechs.
Let us be clear: Pleo wasn‚Äôt impacted: Let us be clear: Pleo wasn‚Äôt impacted by Wirecard‚Äôs problems. We don‚Äôt have ‚Äì and have never had ‚Äì a relationship with them.
But we also think that now is a great ti: But we also think that now is a great time to explain how our payment structure *is* set up. So, here we go.
Maybe you‚Äôre already a customer and ar: Maybe you‚Äôre already a customer and are curious about this kind of stuff. Or it might be that you‚Äôre considering signing up to Pleo.
While the details of who provides what s: While the details of who provides what service and in what order can be complicated, fundamentally it‚Äôs about trust. If you trust Pleo with your company‚Äôs money, it‚Äôs good to know exactly how seriously we take that responsibility.
It starts with us using state-of-the-art: It starts with us using state-of-the-art authentication and encryption technologies ‚Äì but there‚Äôs a lot more to it than that.
Paying for something with your Pleo card: Paying for something with your Pleo card is smooth. You tap your physical card at a payment terminal or enter your virtual card‚Äôs details online, capture the receipt and‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs it. We designed it to be straightforward.
But things are happening behind-the-scen: But things are happening behind-the-scenes in the split second between you making the payment and confirmation of your purchase flashing up.
(You know all this of course, you just p: (You know all this of course, you just probably don‚Äôt think about it.)
Behind the scenes of a Pleo payment: Behind the scenes of a Pleo payment
First, the merchant sends a signal to Ma: First, the merchant sends a signal to Mastercard, which recognises your card.¬†
Mastercard then sends a signal to the pa: Mastercard then sends a signal to the payment processor (ours is a company called Enfuce), who then communicate with Pleo.
We send a signal back to approve or decl: We send a signal back to approve or decline the transaction.¬†
If everything looks in order, Pleo appro: If everything looks in order, Pleo approves the transaction and‚Ä¶ Congratulations! You‚Äôve just bought that iced coffee you desperately need to power through the afternoon.¬†
That‚Äôs one side of how your team‚Äôs m: That‚Äôs one side of how your team‚Äôs money flows through Pleo ‚Äì the other is how you top up your central wallet.
Your Pleo account is hooked up to your b: Your Pleo account is hooked up to your business bank account.¬†
So every time you add funds to Pleo, to: So every time you add funds to Pleo, to help your team buy what they need for work, that money comes out of your business bank account.
But it doesn‚Äôt go directly to us.¬†: But it doesn‚Äôt go directly to us.¬†
It goes first to J.P. Morgan, or to Dans: It goes first to J.P. Morgan, or to Danske Bank for our customers in Denmark and Sweden. This means that neither we ‚Äì nor anyone else ‚Äì have direct access to your money.
So, when a transaction is made and Maste: So, when a transaction is made and Mastercard looks for the funds to cover it, Pleo takes the money from J.P. Morgan or Danske Bank to pay it.
This is where it gets interesting. Becau: This is where it gets interesting. Because there are two Pleos.
Pleo Technologies: This is the company t: Pleo Technologies: This is the company that makes the software you use every time you boot up our app. It also handles sales, marketing and most other functions of the business.
Pretty cool. But even cooler (maybe) is: Pretty cool. But even cooler (maybe) is Pleo Financial Services. This is the licenced entity that is involved in processing every transaction with one of our cards. It‚Äôs regulated by the Financial Supervisory Authority in Denmark.
Some of the fintechs that were impacted: Some of the fintechs that were impacted by Wirecard‚Äôs collapse were hurt because they didn‚Äôt have their own licensed entity.
The existence of Pleo Financial Services: The existence of Pleo Financial Services means we enforce our own compliance and fraud regulations, as well as developing a relationship with the financial regulator.¬†
We‚Äôre not relying on another instituti: We‚Äôre not relying on another institution to remain compliant. We‚Äôre not exposed to any governance failings on their part. Which should be reassuring for you.
Our partnership with J.P. Morgan was som: Our partnership with J.P. Morgan was something that our team worked hard to secure.
The security and reliability they offer: The security and reliability they offer to Pleo Financial Services ‚Äì and thus our customers ‚Äì were the fundamental reasons for that.
J.P. Morgan and Danske Bank are both dee: J.P. Morgan and Danske Bank are both deemed to be Systemically Important Financial Institutions, in the US and Denmark respectively.¬†
That means that if something truly catas: That means that if something truly catastrophic happened, the central banks in the relevant countries would step in to ensure the survival of those institutions.
And Mastercard has more than a billion c: And Mastercard has more than a billion cards in circulation at the time of writing, so we don‚Äôt foresee any plausible scenario where they‚Äôd stop functioning.
Hopefully, all of this information helps:
Hopefully, all of this information helps put you at ease and make that smooth Pleo experience even more stress-free.
¬†
If anything, the issues with Wirecard have shown the importance of being transparent about these payment structures.
The foundation our team has put in place: The foundation our team has put in place ‚Äì the house that Pleo has built ‚Äì ensures that we‚Äôve set the highest possible benchmark for keeping customers‚Äô money safe.
We aim to continue living up to that sta: We aim to continue living up to that standard.
Super Human: Learning how to build trust: Super Human: Learning how to build trust in a team
Lots of companies like to talk about how: Lots of companies like to talk about how to build trust in a team. Here's how we do it.
Despite the fact it‚Äôs etched onto offi: Despite the fact it‚Äôs etched onto office walls, written in employee handbooks and featured in countless job postings ‚Äì it‚Äôs an idea that‚Äôs trickier to put into practice.
It means stepping back, and for many lea: It means stepping back, and for many leaders, that‚Äôs hard. Especially at a time like this, when the idea of trust has been really tested.
Trust is central to positive working rel: Trust is central to positive working relationships, helping teams to innovate and solve problems together. To cement your success as a business as well as a leader, you need to build an environment where trust flourishes.
Transparency is something that a lot of: Transparency is something that a lot of businesses possess during good times, but neglect when things aren‚Äôt going so well. Yet the importance of being honest (even when times are tough) is something that all trustworthy leaders recognise.
Whether the business hasn‚Äôt met its go: Whether the business hasn‚Äôt met its goals, or you‚Äôre letting a member of the team go, it‚Äôs important to have those conversations, and to be open to answering questions. It will minimise gossip and speculation, but more importantly, it‚Äôll ensure that your team feels informed and part of the discussion.
This should, in turn, create a two-way d: This should, in turn, create a two-way dialogue.
When employees see their leaders talking: When employees see their leaders talking openly about difficult topics, they‚Äôll be more compelled to approach those leaders when they're navigating tricky situations themselves.
Honest conversations when you fail to hi: Honest conversations when you fail to hit long-term goals is just one part of building trust.
Be honest about short term slip-ups too.
Admitting to mistakes minimises the divi: Admitting to mistakes minimises the divide between senior leadership and the wider team, and demonstrates the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù element that‚Äôs so key in establishing trust.
Equally, accountability is a really posi: Equally, accountability is a really positive force in building trust, if you take the time to show appreciation for the work their team has done. Whether that‚Äôs when presenting a company update or offering direct praise, giving everyone their due helps people to invest more in work.
Instead of forgetting to thank your team: Instead of forgetting to thank your team ‚Äì or worse, taking credit for their success ‚Äì recognise the individuals who contributed and turn the spotlight on them.
Your team should always feel that you pu: Your team should always feel that you put them first, and will support decisions they make in terms of their development. One of the ultimate goals for any leader should be empowering their team to grow.

You may have to hire again, but you will: You may have to hire again, but you will have made a positive impact on that individual‚Äôs career. And the rest of your team will see the support that you‚Äôve offered.
Lockdown has afforded us all a better un: Lockdown has afforded us all a better understanding of the different complexities that people face in their daily lives. Many have juggled childcare or looking after family members, while others were prevented from doing the most routine activities.
This has affected people in different wa: This has affected people in different ways and will continue to do so for a long time. But there‚Äôs something to be gained from this situation: Empathy.
Something that‚Äôs become more apparent: Something that‚Äôs become more apparent is that a ‚Äúone size fits all‚Äù approach is not the way to manage people. More than ever, we‚Äôre able to call into question whether adjustments could (and should) be made to accommodate people, in ways we‚Äôd probably not considered before.
Gaining trust as a leader means giving t: Gaining trust as a leader means giving trust to your team.
One way to do that is to allow them to m: One way to do that is to allow them to manage their working day based on output, not time in the office. Whether they prefer to get in the office early, or start work later, or if they‚Äôd rather work remotely ‚Äì as long as they do their job to the best of their ability, that‚Äôs all you can ask for.
Don‚Äôt get caught up in the numbers, un: Don‚Äôt get caught up in the numbers, understand the people you‚Äôre working with, what personally drives them, and how you can help them maintain a healthy work/life balance.
You won‚Äôt be able to fully understand: You won‚Äôt be able to fully understand how good a job you‚Äôre doing until you get honest feedback. And there‚Äôs no better way to do that than through a survey, where you will get anonymous feedback on areas such as communication, support, and the working environment.
Regular surveys are even better, allowin: Regular surveys are even better, allowing you to track trends and progress.
You must act on the feedback as soon as: You must act on the feedback as soon as possible ‚Äì whether that‚Äôs securing some ‚Äúquick wins‚Äù through small fixes, or communicating back to the organisation about the changes that you will be making over the next few months.
You should also invite questions in sess: You should also invite questions in sessions such as all-hands or town hall meetings.
It‚Äôs a great opportunity for people to: It‚Äôs a great opportunity for people to raise concerns or questions in a safe environment. If you‚Äôre doubtful that people will speak up, allow anonymous submissions prior to the session. That way, people feel comfortable asking the tougher questions and you can tackle concerns head-on.
Trust takes time. It‚Äôs not an overnigh: Trust takes time. It‚Äôs not an overnight thing.
But if you create a working environment: But if you create a working environment that enables trust through transparency and understanding, and lead with empathy, you‚Äôll find that trust soon builds. And stays.

Why you can never judge a business by it: Why you can never judge a business by its profits
Cash flow expert Craig Alexander Rattray: Cash flow expert Craig Alexander Rattray on why profits don't offer the full picture for any company.
The UK government has announced a consul: The UK government has announced a consultation into the future of auditing, in an attempt to avoid major collapses like BHS, Carillion, Thomas Cook and Patisserie Valerie.
There are various proposals that Busines: There are various proposals that Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng believes will assist in not just "restoring business confidence" but also "people‚Äôs confidence in business".
That‚Äôs a lot of confidence that needs: That‚Äôs a lot of confidence that needs to be restored. But will it make a difference?
For me, the key point is not whether the: For me, the key point is not whether the Big Four have a dominant market share, or are unduly influenced by fees and retaining clients.
Various high-profile collapses have occu: Various high-profile collapses have occurred over the years, some not long after audited accounts were signed off, and I expect that will continue.
Why? The focus is wrong. We spend too mu: Why? The focus is wrong. We spend too much time looking back and not forward. We focus on profit rather than cash.
Yes, the audit should address the workin: Yes, the audit should address the working capital needs of the business for the next 12 months, but how much focus is placed on that? How much work is done on interrogating the forecasts and looking closely at the cash flow assumptions?
It is cash that pays the employees and t: It is cash that pays the employees and the suppliers, not profit.
Many business owners realise at some sta: Many business owners realise at some stage that the profit they make in the business does not equal their cash flow.
Even profitable businesses cannot surviv: Even profitable businesses cannot survive without cash ‚Äì it‚Äôs the oxygen a business needs to stay alive.
We should remember the saying ‚Äúrevenue: We should remember the saying ‚Äúrevenue is vanity, profit is sanity and cash flow is reality‚Äù. It is true.
There is an expectations gap with respec: There is an expectations gap with respect to what an audit provides.
Download Getting a grip on cashflow eBoo: Download Getting a grip on cashflow eBook banner
The fundamental purpose of the audit is: The fundamental purpose of the audit is to provide independent assurance that the accounts present a ‚Äútrue and fair‚Äù view of a company‚Äôs financial performance and position.
Some of that can be subjective and may i: Some of that can be subjective and may include aggressive and judgemental accounting treatments, which can be used to artificially inflate profitability.
If we look at some high-profile collapse: If we look at some high-profile collapses, what were the causes?
1. Aggressive accounting treatments, esp: 1. Aggressive accounting treatments, especially with respect to work-in-progress/long-term contracts/stock, goodwill impairment, and recoverability of sums due. Such aggressive accounting allows profits to be kept artificially high, thereby allowing dividend payments to continue and indeed to increase.
2. Paying dividends out of cash not gene: 2. Paying dividends out of cash not generated from operations. Carillion paid ¬£376 million in dividends over a five-year period in which it made only ¬£159 million in net cash from operations.
3. A broken business model ‚Äì no longer: 3. A broken business model ‚Äì no longer profitable and cash generative. In the case of Thomas Cook, think of the move by consumers from physically going to stores to booking online.
4. For me, the most important cause is t: 4. For me, the most important cause is the failure to focus on cash.  There are numerous accounting treatments and tricks that can be used to keep profits high.  However, one thing that is usually 100% correct is the bank position.
Taking action with your own company: Taking action with your own company
If we focused on looking forward and on: If we focused on looking forward and on cash rather than manipulating profits, many of these collapses could be prevented.
This is where business owners should foc: This is where business owners should focus.
I have been introduced to many companies: I have been introduced to many companies that have shown a profit in their management accounts. But dig a little deeper and the cash issues were clear.
Sometimes these problems are due to fund: Sometimes these problems are due to funding growth and an increase in the working capital requirement.
However, sometimes the cash situation is: However, sometimes the cash situation is down to manipulation of profitability, in an attempt to ‚Äúwindow dress‚Äù accounts and keep banks and investors happy.
This generally only lasts for a short pe: This generally only lasts for a short period of time, as eventually reality bites and the cash issues and mismatch with reported profit comes to light.
What lessons can business owners learn f: What lessons can business owners learn from this? Focus on cash, not profit.
Yes, we want to have profitable business: Yes, we want to have profitable businesses and we need to understand profitability.
However, we need to stop accepting the m: However, we need to stop accepting the manipulation of the profit position and instead focus on looking forward.
We must understand the cash flow dynamic: We must understand the cash flow dynamics of the business based on its strategic plan, and ensure that it makes both commercial sense and that it fits with the operational side of the business.
I have met many business owners who tell: I have met many business owners who tell me that the numbers do not make sense and do not equate with what the business is doing. That gap shouldn‚Äôt exist.
Excellent financial management is about: Excellent financial management is about understanding:
current management accounts and informat: current management accounts and information, plus an up-to-date bank position ‚Äì "where you are"
historic management accounts and full ye: historic management accounts and full year final accounts ‚Äì "where you have been"
forecasts comprising monthly profit and: forecasts comprising monthly profit and loss, balance sheet and cash flow as well as a weekly rolling cash flow forecast ‚Äì "where you are going?"
A business owner must understand the fin: A business owner must understand the financial position and ensure that it fits with his opinion of how the business is trading operationally.
If not, questions must be asked so that: If not, questions must be asked so that there is a clear understanding of where the cash is going.
It is vital to have a profitable busines: It is vital to have a profitable business, but even more so to understand the cash.
\"Revenue is vanity, profit is sanity an: "Revenue is vanity, profit is sanity and cash flow is reality." Some things just deserve to be repeated.

Power to your people: Working to make Pl: Power to your people: Working to make Pleo more accessible
Why building highly accessible software: Why building highly accessible software means a better product for all of our users.
Technology makes so many things easier i: Technology makes so many things easier in modern life.
And for people with disabilities, techno: And for people with disabilities, technology has the potential to take the impossible and make it possible.
Accessibility is all about making conten: Accessibility is all about making content available to as wide an audience as you can ‚Äì in our case, by designing and developing flexible, high quality solutions.
That‚Äôs no matter what somebody‚Äôs abi: That‚Äôs no matter what somebody‚Äôs abilities might be, or how they might prefer to access content.
Here‚Äôs the truth: We haven‚Äôt been su: Here‚Äôs the truth: We haven‚Äôt been superstars in this arena. There are explanations for this of course, although they‚Äôre not excuses.
Small companies have limited resources a: Small companies have limited resources and if they‚Äôre to survive in competitive industries, they need to be strategic about how they focus their energy.
With tech companies, there‚Äôs another c: With tech companies, there‚Äôs another consideration.
Developing highly accessible solutions h: Developing highly accessible solutions hasn‚Äôt, historically, been an integrated part of the designer / developer curriculum.
That‚Äôs meant some well-intended but ul: That‚Äôs meant some well-intended but ultimately sub-par solutions ‚Äì from Pleo and many other software companies.
For us, this very imperfect situation ch: For us, this very imperfect situation changed last year.
In November 2020, our Design team dedica: In November 2020, our Design team dedicated an entire week to digging into accessibility and we, as an organisation, decided to take an active stance on the subject.
What I‚Äôd love to do now is fill you in: What I‚Äôd love to do now is fill you in on the background, the work we‚Äôve done so far and what we‚Äôve learned along the way.
Star Trek‚Äôs Spock famously said, \"The:
Star Trek‚Äôs Spock famously said, "The needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few." 
He's probably not the first person (or Vulcan) to have said something along these lines and in business, it‚Äôs a common sentiment.
Across a range of issues, we're a compan: Across a range of issues, we're a company that caters to and depends largely on "the many", not "the few".
But in some respects, that focus on \"th: But in some respects, that focus on "the many" can be a pretty uncomfortable thing to grapple with. Accessibility is one of those areas.
Do we prioritise \"the many\", skimping: Do we prioritise "the many", skimping on accessibility so that we can ship more features faster? Or do we make it our mission to build highly accessible software, shipping fewer features at a slower pace?
We are a business, of course. But that b: We are a business, of course. But that business is composed of caring individuals, who believe that everyone can and should be met with understanding and empathy.
And on the topic of accessibility, it go: And on the topic of accessibility, it goes beyond just wanting to do better.
In this context, we‚Äôve come to see tha: In this context, we‚Äôve come to see that it‚Äôs too simplistic to adopt that "many" vs "few" mindset. And the research backs that up.
In the UK alone, it‚Äôs estimated that s: In the UK alone, it‚Äôs estimated that seven million people of working age have a disability. The so-called "purple pound" is worth ¬£249bn to the economy.
That puts a sharp point on the dilemma t: That puts a sharp point on the dilemma that we, and many other tech companies, have wrestled with.
We've now identified the way forward and: We've now identified the way forward and it's quite simple.
Spock travels around in a spaceship, war: Spock travels around in a spaceship, warping to different planets and galaxies, battling aliens and living a rather dramatic existence.
We build and sell company spend software: We build and sell company spend software to make your life managing company expenses a whole lot easier. We aren't being hunted by Klingons and going on perilous adventures, so we don't need to be as drastic in our presumptions as Spock is.
Frankly, we needed to discard the idea o: Frankly, we needed to discard the idea of ‚Äúthe few‚Äù ‚Äì and start thinking about everyone. Because accessibility affects us all.
If we focus on building highly accessibl: If we focus on building highly accessible software, we actually end up building a better product for all of our users.
So how does this work in practice?: So how does this work in practice?
The Pleo product is built and maintained: The Pleo product is built and maintained by feature teams that have historically enjoyed a high level of autonomy and been extremely effective at pushing out contained features at pretty dazzling speeds.
That worked well for a period.
Autonomy is great, but if we‚Äôre all so: Autonomy is great, but if we‚Äôre all solving unique problems without relating them to the broader picture, we end up pulling and pushing the fabric of our software in unintended directions.
This, coupled with differing skillsets,: This, coupled with differing skillsets, personalities, goals and experience within the feature teams, can lead to some substantial deviations in the overall code base that transcend to the user interface... which is exactly where accessibility lives.
Let me start this section with a confess: Let me start this section with a confession. Our product is nowhere near as accessible as we want it to be.
But the path has been paved and we are o: But the path has been paved and we are on our way.
We‚Äôve been following the following pro: We‚Äôve been following the following process:
3) map out the most important user flows: 3) map out the most important user flows
4) make these navigable through alternat: 4) make these navigable through alternative or assistive tech (keyboard, screenreaders, etc.)
5) test with people who rely on said tec: 5) test with people who rely on said technologies
Where are we at? We're currently somewhe: Where are we at? We're currently somewhere between step 3) and 4) for our web applications and we're slowly getting started on our mobile applications.
Pleo has three main customer-facing plat: Pleo has three main customer-facing platforms: our commercial website, our web application and our mobile application.
All of these platforms have to have a hi: All of these platforms have to have a high degree of accessibility if we're to create a solid user experience for individuals who rely on assistive tech or who have specific preferences on how they consume content or solve digital tasks.
So, if you're able to onboard to the pro: So, if you're able to onboard to the product, but not use it? We've failed.
If onboarding isn't highly accessible, b: If onboarding isn't highly accessible, but the application is? You'll never know, will you? So we will have failed there too.
That's why we have to consider the entir: That's why we have to consider the entire Pleo portfolio when working with accessibility.
How do we audit? For web-based solutions: How do we audit? For web-based solutions, auditing tools are readily available. We've been using Chrome Lighthouse, ChromeLens and Axe to sniff out accessibility blunders and fix them in our main product. We aim to do the same for our commercial site and are currently looking into auditing tools for our mobile application.
How do we prioritise? We start by ensuri: How do we prioritise? We start by ensuring that the main components in our user interfaces are of a high quality and that they meet stringent accessibility criteria. If the building blocks are lacking, the construction will be lacking.
If a certain flow (let's say changing yo: If a certain flow (let's say changing your profile information) is built with non-accessible components, you won't be able to explore that flow. Therefore the components must, as a minimum, be built to mirror accessible web standards, be navigable by keyboard, have sufficient contrast ratios and have logical interaction patterns.
What's the strategy? It's no secret that: What's the strategy? It's no secret that focusing more on accessibility will affect the speed at which we can develop new features to some extent, especially at the start. But, by ensuring that the most important functionalities are accessible by assistive tech, we set a strong point of departure for future work.
This basically means determining what sh: This basically means determining what should be a feasible user journey, determined individually for the solutions that customers interact with.
Who owns what? Every team that contribut: Who owns what? Every team that contributes to the product should know about accessibility. However, skillsets and experience differ, so there is a need for clear ownership.
The DesignOps team at Pleo ensures that: The DesignOps team at Pleo ensures that every component served from our Telescope Design System is highly-accessible and built with correct semantics. We champion accessibility and assist/encourage other teams to build components to those standards.
How do we maintain high standards? A str: How do we maintain high standards? A strong focus on accessibility from the conception of a component to its launch helps us ensure that accessibility isn't just an arbitrary afterthought.

The tips you need to manage cash outflow: The tips you need to manage cash outflow in the right way
Cash flow expert Craig Alexander Rattray: Cash flow expert Craig Alexander Rattray has some practical advice to help you get on top of cash outflows.
Controlling and managing cash flow is ke: Controlling and managing cash flow is key to business success. But many ignore it, take it for granted or just‚Ä¶ hope for the best.
Guided by the old adage that \"you can‚Ä: Guided by the old adage that "you can‚Äôt manage what you don‚Äôt measure", I‚Äôve always believed in taking action and managing cash closely.
What are cash inflows and cash outflows?: What are cash inflows and cash outflows?
Very simply, cash inflows mainly relate: Very simply, cash inflows mainly relate to receipts from customers, and cash outflows relate to payments to employees, suppliers and taxes.
Clearly, receipts from customers are mor: Clearly, receipts from customers are more difficult to predict (unless using direct debit or other forms of regular payments), but cash outflows are under the control of the business ‚Äì often with set days for payments.
As a result, most businesses ‚Äúcontrol‚: As a result, most businesses ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù (and I use the word loosely) their cash by focusing on the outflows.
They make payments when there are funds: They make payments when there are funds in the bank account, and often very little planning takes place with respect to next week, next month or next quarter.
Information is key. Real-time data is vi: Information is key. Real-time data is vital for managing your business and cash flow effectively.
We must know what we owe, why we owe it: We must know what we owe, why we owe it and when it is due.
According to the 2020 QuickBooks State o: According to the 2020 QuickBooks State of Payroll report, 61% of small business owners don‚Äôt know how much money they spend each month.
That is a worrying statistic ‚Äì but it‚: That is a worrying statistic ‚Äì but it‚Äôs worth pausing to consider whether you could accurately put your finger on what your company spends.
If not, why not? You should be able to ‚: If not, why not? You should be able to ‚Äì it is your business.
So, how do we better manage cash outflow: So, how do we better manage cash outflows?
Do everything, every day. Ensure invoice: Do everything, every day. Ensure invoices are collated and posted into the accounting system immediately, and formally approved.
Have a system to collate spending commit: Have a system to collate spending commitments made and purchase invoices not yet received.
A Purchase Order system of advance appro: A Purchase Order system of advance approval for purchase commitments allows greater control of purchases. It also means that outstanding commitments can be considered when preparing cash flow forecasts. If you don‚Äôt yet forecast, start today.
Work out what is best for your company b: Work out what is best for your company based on your cash inflows, and phase the payments into your cash flow forecast model.
If you don‚Äôt have one, get one! This p: If you don‚Äôt have one, get one! This provides suppliers with certainty and avoids daily payment runs.
Review the outstanding trade payables\/t: Review the outstanding trade payables/trade creditors schedule
This is a great review exercise as you w: This is a great review exercise as you will become familiar with the amounts due, the key suppliers and the overall balance.
Most reports will also show expenditure: Most reports will also show expenditure by supplier for the year-to-date.
With this information at your fingertips: With this information at your fingertips, you can negotiate with suppliers to agree discounts, better payment terms or even annual retrospective discounts.
Understand your day's purchases outstand: Understand your day's purchases outstanding and the financial impact
This allows you to evaluate the number o: This allows you to evaluate the number of days of purchases outstanding and provides an indication of how quickly you pay suppliers.
If most of your credit terms are 30 days: If most of your credit terms are 30 days, the number should fall around this if you are paying on time.  A significant lag against credit terms can be indicative of either problems with cash and the inability to pay on time or lax administrative processes.
‚Äì Speak to suppliers regularly and not: ‚Äì Speak to suppliers regularly and notify them if payments are going to be late
‚Äì Don‚Äôt break payment commitments th: ‚Äì Don‚Äôt break payment commitments that you‚Äôve made
‚Äì Transfer all employee taxes, sales t: ‚Äì Transfer all employee taxes, sales taxes, and a provision for corporate taxes into a separate bank account
‚Äì Try to extend payment dates to suppl: ‚Äì Try to extend payment dates to suppliers by agreement, especially if there are multiple alternative suppliers (Use your status as a loyal customer who wants to stay, but needs 60 days rather than 30 days etc)
Don‚Äôt forget that cash outflows are ea: Don‚Äôt forget that cash outflows are easier to forecast as they are within your control.
The key is to ensure they are matched ag: The key is to ensure they are matched against the cash inflows of the company and included in your cash flow forecast.
Do this successfully and you will have s: Do this successfully and you will have sufficient cash for the business to breathe.

The evolution of expense management: whi: The evolution of expense management: which era are you stuck in?
Let‚Äôs take a look at the key points in: Let‚Äôs take a look at the key points in the transformation of expense management throughout human history.
This is going to blow your mind ‚Äì the: This is going to blow your mind ‚Äì the first record of accounting dates back 7,000 years ago among the ruins of ancient Mesopotamia. A record was made of crop and herd growth in order to determine if there was a surplus or a shortage for that season.¬†
And in the 5,300 year old tomb of King S: And in the 5,300 year old tomb of King Scorpion I of Ancient Egypt, bags of oil and linen were discovered with bone tokens inscribed with numerical markings ‚Äì aka receipts.¬†
We‚Äôve definitely come a long way from: We‚Äôve definitely come a long way from recording on stone tablets and using bone tokens to keep track of transactions, that‚Äôs for sure. ¬†
Since the onset of the 21st Century, we‚: Since the onset of the 21st Century, we‚Äôve seen people and businesses rapidly embracing new technology, in order to keep up with the customer‚Äôs needs and desires.¬†
The result? Expense management software: The result? Expense management software needed to advance ‚Äì and fast.
But before we look into the future, it‚Ä: But before we look into the future, it‚Äôs important to reflect back on where we‚Äôve been. Let‚Äôs take a look at the key points in the transformation of expense management.
A walk through the evolution of expense: A walk through the evolution of expense management
Mankind starts to understand the idea of: Mankind starts to understand the idea of an ‚Äúexpense‚Äù(and begins to feel the pain of the payment).¬†
Humans accept tokens, like stones or bon: Humans accept tokens, like stones or bones, instead of goods when trading. Keeping track of all of this was tough, involving a lot of counting and very heavy petty cash jars.
While there is some debate in the academ: While there is some debate in the academic world over which ancient civilisation it originates from ‚Äì Egypt, Mesopotamia, India ‚Äì there's no denying that the abacus is one of mankind's greatest inventions. Super high-tech at the time, this seemingly simple counting tool made of strings and pebbles was used in calculations to accurately record all kinds of transactions.
The Dark Ages weren‚Äôt so bad when it c: The Dark Ages weren‚Äôt so bad when it comes to money. Replacing rocks, intricate coins are produced and assigned values. Because of all this new cash (and there was quite a variety of moneys to negotiate with!), a more advanced recording system is created to keep track of transactions.
In 1883, the first cash register was pat: In 1883, the first cash register was patented by saloonkeeper, James Ritty. More automation means an increase in accounting accuracy and streamlines how businesses track expenses.¬†
And this is neat ‚Äì the bell and cash d: And this is neat ‚Äì the bell and cash drawer added a bit later ensured that everyone was aware when money was being exchanged in the shop.
Now we really start picking up speed...
The time of disco and the first accounti: The time of disco and the first accounting software (not sure which is more fun!). Called ‚ÄúSystem Analysis and Program Development‚Äù ‚Äì does SAP ring any bells? It helps businesses manage financial and inventory data. Human error is reduced and spend management gets faster.
Computers are shrinking and are being us: Computers are shrinking and are being used more and more by the average working person. And yep, Microsoft Excel starts to really dominate.
Cloud computing makes everything simpler: Cloud computing makes everything simpler and more user-friendly for businesses. The new millennium sees the birth of SaaS as a major force. In 2007, the first iPhone is launched and brings with it the start of mobile financial management.
We truly hope that you‚Äôd place your co: We truly hope that you‚Äôd place your company‚Äôs expense management in the last two eras at least‚Ä¶ No one is still hanging out in the 1970s, right?
If you think that entering receipts by h: If you think that entering receipts by hand and then emailing files around for approval is still how expense management has to get done, I‚Äôm going to let you in on a little secret ‚Äì it‚Äôs not.¬†
As you can tell from a quick walk throug: As you can tell from a quick walk through history, technology has been developing rapidly in the past 30 years or so. There are countless solutions out there helping businesses of all sizes track and record their expenses.¬†
From payroll to handling invoices to cas: From payroll to handling invoices to cashflow forecasting, a wave of fintech tools has arrived in the past few years that can truly transform how modern businesses manage their money.
And using a solution to handle expenses: And using a solution to handle expenses is more than just a nice-to-have. It‚Äôs what gives you and your people a better grip on what‚Äôs being spent across the business.¬†
These solutions eliminate human errors a: These solutions eliminate human errors and delays and lead to higher satisfaction rates amongst your employees. Because manually entering expense data isn‚Äôt just affecting your bottom line, it‚Äôs costing your employees too.¬†
And on a business-wide level, handling e: And on a business-wide level, handling expenses manually takes people away from the things they should be focusing on.¬†
Not to mention, the younger generation o: Not to mention, the younger generation of employees have no patience for manually shuffling receipts. They want the apps, and they want them now.¬†
Seems kinda silly to lose good people be: Seems kinda silly to lose good people because your expense management process is stuck in the past, don‚Äôtcha think?¬†¬†
Complete automation is making its way in: Complete automation is making its way into everyday life. There are self-driving cars for crying out loud! So there‚Äôs no way that expenses should and will stay behind.¬†
Expect way more automation, more AI, and: Expect way more automation, more AI, and most of all, more mobility.¬†
Many businesses are becoming more global: Many businesses are becoming more global, with their employees also more mobile and flexible. People need to be able to submit reports and expenses, as well as having managers approve all claims, from a smartphone or laptop, wherever they are.¬†
Uninterrupted connectivity is a must. An: Uninterrupted connectivity is a must. And this goes for all financial processes of a business.
Expense management solutions will become: Expense management solutions will become more and more seamless across all financial systems - card payments, bank accounts, accounting, and payroll. Which makes sense, since these systems share a lot of the same information.¬†
Take Bills, our invoice management featu: Take Bills, our invoice management feature. Or Pocket, making reimbursements for out-of-pocket expenses easier for everyone.¬†
Seamless integrations across systems wil: Seamless integrations across systems will make the process even smoother, but also adds an additional layer of assurance on data integrity. A win-win.¬†

How to maintain relationships for better: How to maintain relationships for better cash inflow management
Cashflow expert Craig Alexander Rattray: Cashflow expert Craig Alexander Rattray on why relationships are key for cash inflow management.
Craig Alexander Rattray¬†is a Growth Str: Craig Alexander Rattray¬†is a Growth Strategist and Cash Flow Expert based in Glasgow, Scotland. He is the author of Mastering Cash Flow for Business Owners.
I‚Äôve covered the difference between pr: I‚Äôve covered the difference between profit and cash, and managing cash outflows. All that‚Äôs left now is cash inflows and how to better manage them.
As highlighted in ‚ÄúThe tips you need t: As highlighted in ‚ÄúThe tips you need to manage cash outflow in the right way‚Äù, cash outflows are under our control as we decide when we make the payments from our bank account, and how much we pay.
But that‚Äôs not the case with cash infl: But that‚Äôs not the case with cash inflows.¬†
The timing and quantum of receipts from: The timing and quantum of receipts from customers are at their discretion, just like our cash outflows are, and that means they‚Äôre more difficult to predict with the certainty of our outflows.
Remember, without the cash inflows, our: Remember, without the cash inflows, our ability to make cash outflows will be restricted.
This clearly makes cash inflows more dif: This clearly makes cash inflows more difficult to manage and control. Credit terms and cash collection processes are a key part of good cash management.
The key in cash outflows is information,: The key in cash outflows is information, real-time data and ensuring we know what we owe, why we owe it and when it‚Äôs due.
Whilst we need that information too for: Whilst we need that information too for cash inflows, it can be a bit more complicated.¬†
I believe the key to success for good ca: I believe the key to success for good cash inflow management is down to the relationship with the customer ‚Äì an area that‚Äôs often neglected in terms of its importance.¬†
There are many things we can do that wil: There are many things we can do that will assist in improving the timing of cash receipts (more on this later). However, the personal relationship with a customer can have much more of an impact.
As the Finance Director (FD) or Chief Fi: As the Finance Director (FD) or Chief Financial Officer (CFO) in difficult cash situations, my focus is always on paying the key suppliers first that are critical to continue trading and delivering our products and services. And similarly, those that are inclined to chase for payment are generally higher up on the payment list too.
It‚Äôs equally important to ensure that: It‚Äôs equally important to ensure that the operational team stays close to their day-to-day supplier contacts and highlights any cash and payment challenges that may spring up. That provision of knowledge, care, and making them aware of the situation, helps when there are issues with retaining supply.
If we approach that from the cash inflow: If we approach that from the cash inflow perspective, we can use that insight to our benefit and adapt our approach accordingly.
Get to know the people: their family, th: Get to know the people: their family, their interests and other personal things that help build the relationship.
Established and well-developed relations: Established and well-developed relationships make customers think twice before making late payments.
If they only have limited funds left to: If they only have limited funds left to pay suppliers and it‚Äôs between your business and another where there is no relationship, in most cases you‚Äôll be paid.¬†
Steps to take to improve business relati: Steps to take to improve business relationships
There‚Äôs a lot more that I could expand: There‚Äôs a lot more that I could expand on here, but it‚Äôs important to highlight some other key tips to improve cash inflows;
Invoice when the work is done, services: Invoice when the work is done, services are provided, or products delivered. Ideally daily.
This includes good administration. Ensur: This includes good administration. Ensure all invoices have the correct details, like company name, address, the receiver, what work or service was provided, to avoid unnecessary delays.¬†
My preference is for invoices to be sent: My preference is for invoices to be sent electronically.
Provide clear credit terms, due dates an: Provide clear credit terms, due dates and credit control policy
Credit terms and due dates should always: Credit terms and due dates should always be confirmed in writing and included on all invoices.¬†
Ideally use a standard credit applicatio: Ideally use a standard credit application form, with detailed trading terms, and credit check the potential customer too. Perhaps ask why they left their previous supplier and even make a call if there are concerns.
It‚Äôs also important to follow a clearl: It‚Äôs also important to follow a clearly defined credit control policy. What is your debt collection process ‚Äì dates, timings, actions? Are the finance and operational teams aware of the contents of the policy? What are the escalation procedures for overdues or over credit limit?¬†¬†
It‚Äôs good practice to put all of this: It‚Äôs good practice to put all of this in place.
Review outstanding trade receivables and: Review outstanding trade receivables and trade debtors schedules¬†
Both should be reviewed weekly and if yo: Both should be reviewed weekly and if you have a dedicated person, they should be chasing and reminding customers daily.¬†¬†
Typically, the aged debtors schedule is: Typically, the aged debtors schedule is analysed in columns showing current, 30 days, 60 days, 90 days, 120 days and 120+ days. I aim to ensure there are no outstanding items in the end four columns, unless there are specific reasons for your company to offer extended credit terms.
There should be detailed actions for all: There should be detailed actions for all individual invoices outwith the first two columns.
Make it easy to be paid: Make it easy to be paid
Online and electronic payments should be: Online and electronic payments should be the standard method of receipt.
It avoids delays and awaiting cheques cl: It avoids delays and awaiting cheques clearing. You should be able to accept multiple payment methods including credit card and solutions, like Stripe and PayPal.
There are other things that can be done: There are other things that can be done to improve timings of receipts like direct debit/automatic payments, taking deposits, incentivising early payment and various others.
Credit control and trade debtor\/receiva: Credit control and trade debtor/receivables management should be a regular routine for all businesses.
Remember, in my view, a sale is not a sa: Remember, in my view, a sale is not a sale until the cash is in your bank account ‚Äî focus on that and you‚Äôll definitely improve your cash inflows.

Research by the Trades Union Congress fo: Research by the Trades Union Congress found that women have faced higher levels of redundancies during the pandemic than in previous recessions. In the UK, 179,000 women were made redundant between September and November 2020 ‚Äî 76% higher than the height of the economic crisis in 2008 when figures hit 100,000.

The pandemic affected almost every busin: The pandemic affected almost every business, be that having to have their teamwork from home, rethinking their entire business model or heavily reducing services.¬†
But the current ‚Äòshecession‚Äô is glob: But the current ‚Äòshecession‚Äô is globally affecting sectors like hospitality and retail, workplaces that are more vulnerable to everchanging lockdown measures and where women predominate, especially Black and Latina women.¬†
In the UK, the retail sector employs app: In the UK, the retail sector employs approximately 2.8 million people, 58% of which are women and 42% men. A recent study found that women are at higher risk of losing their jobs as retail work is moving out of stores and into warehouses and logistics centres, an industry with gender inequality.¬†
And it isn‚Äôt just customer-facing sect: And it isn‚Äôt just customer-facing sectors that are threatened by the ‚Äòshecession‚Äô. Other female-dominated industries like marketing and communications were more likely to be lost than roles in finance, roles more commonly held by men.
There will be long-lasting impacts on wo: There will be long-lasting impacts on women‚Äôs global economic participation. In Europe, the poverty rate among women in Europe is expected to increase by 1.9 percent. And in the US, almost 40 percent of unemployed women have been out of work for six months or longer.¬†
Among the layoffs, pay cuts and lack of: Among the layoffs, pay cuts and lack of new job postings disproportionately affecting women, there are the hours of unpaid labour caregiving at home that typically falls on women‚Äôs shoulders.
While many worked from home this past ye: While many worked from home this past year, research found that women are still doing more unpaid work than they were last year.
As schools and nurseries closed during t: As schools and nurseries closed during the multiple lockdowns, someone had to supervise the children and assist with online schooling. A survey by the Bureau of Statistics (Australia) set out to find out who this person most commonly was...¬†
Almost 45% of all women with children sp: Almost 45% of all women with children spend more than five hours each week supervising or caring for them ‚Äì with more than a third of women spending over 20 hours each week. Not leaving a lot of spare time to look for new employment.¬†
This is compared to 32% of men who said: This is compared to 32% of men who said they spend more than five hours a week and just 17% do more than 20 hours watching over or caring for their children.

Before the pandemic, making sure there w: Before the pandemic, making sure there was diversity across the spectrum in workplaces was nowhere near complete ‚Äî but in the past few years, milestones had at least been outlined for inclusion.¬†
With the light at the end of the Covid-1: With the light at the end of the Covid-19 tunnel, businesses are slowly starting to resume normality as offices reopen and public spending gradually increases. For parents, flexible working could look: For parents, flexible working could look like working around school hours, finding a schedule with a co-parent and a child that might not be at school yet or even role sharing with other team members.¬†

As life returns to normal, it‚Äôs likely: As life returns to normal, it‚Äôs likely companies will see more women applying for jobs, and some of these women may not have worked for many months due to childcare responsibilities or being laid off.
To accommodate this, and prevent gender: To accommodate this, and prevent gender disparity in the workplace, some businesses have already introduced re-entry programs and mentorship for women ‚Äî from skills development to tech support.¬†
One company offering this is IBM. It‚Äôs: One company offering this is IBM. It‚Äôs expanding its ‚Äúreturnship program‚Äù that aims to hire and train women who have had to step back from employment during the pandemic.¬†
Rethink the way you write job ads: Rethink the way you write job ads
When the time is right and your company: When the time is right and your company is actively hiring again, pay attention to the wording used in your job ads. Research proves gendered words and phrases like ‚Äúchallenge‚Äù and ‚Äúloyal‚Äù reinforce gender stereotypes, especially in the workplace.

It‚Äôs women that have faced the brunt o: It‚Äôs women that have faced the brunt of the pandemic and its lockdowns, and it‚Äôs even worse for women of colour. As we edge back into normality, it‚Äôs over to governments and businesses to provide an easy route back into the workplace for women.¬†
