If it‚Äôs a business, it‚Äôs got expenses.¬†
Business expenses are costs collected in: Business expenses are costs collected in the ordinary course of business, a.k.a all that stuff you need to buy to do your job. They can apply to small entities or large corporations. And being savvy with your expenses is a large part of running a successful business, regardless of its size.
It‚Äôs important for businesses to keep: It‚Äôs important for businesses to keep track and to categorise their spending not only because it makes it easier to budget and allows for proper financial control ‚Äì some expenses can count as tax deductions, resulting in significant cost savings.
And let's face it, no one wants to miss: And let's face it, no one wants to miss an opportunity to save some money!
Here is an overview of the types of expe: Here is an overview of the types of expenses that businesses can have, what is a business expense and what is not, where the definition of what qualifies as a business expense comes from, as well as some tips for keeping track of it all.¬†
The best way to identify a business expe: The best way to identify a business expense is to think about what your business uses. Here‚Äôs a some examples of the most common business expenses (please be advised this is not an extensive list):
Physical items like paper, desks, printe: Physical items like paper, desks, printer supplies
IT support, cleaning, accounting and leg: IT support, cleaning, accounting and legal fees, outsourced office functions¬†
Snacks for the office, team dinners: Snacks for the office, team dinners
Whilst you can‚Äôt reduce your tax bill: Whilst you can‚Äôt reduce your tax bill or claim VAT back, it is a business expense for many companies.¬†
Business expenses can be further broken: Business expenses can be further broken down into three main costs types:
A fixed cost is one that does not change: A fixed cost is one that does not change, or changes only slightly. Things like the monthly rent for an office space.¬†
Variable costs, or expenses, vary from m: Variable costs, or expenses, vary from month to month and are typically a company‚Äôs largest expense. An example of a variable cost would be the payment for a large amount of freelance personnel, or overtime.¬†
Periodic expenses are ones that happen i: Periodic expenses are ones that happen infrequently. These can be hard to plan for, such as your printer totally crashing and having to purchase a new one.¬†
It‚Äôs probably no surprise, but persona: It‚Äôs probably no surprise, but personal expenses cannot be deemed as a business expense.¬†
The only exception is if the expense is: The only exception is if the expense is used both for personal and business use. Then of course the business part can be deducted.¬†
Daniel runs his own gardening business. He uses his truck 50% of the time to visit clients, and the other 50% is used for family or pleasure. The rules allow the client visits to be considered a business expense, but in order to do this he needs to keep track of mileage and the purpose of each and every car ride.
Who defines what is considered a busines: Who defines what is considered a business expense?¬†
In the UK, the HMRC sets the rules for b: In the UK, the HMRC sets the rules for business expenses. It makes it quite clear that for a purchase or cost to be considered a business expense it must be necessary and that is wholly and exclusively incurred as part of the day to day running of your business. Here‚Äôs the full list of HMRC approved business expenses .¬†

A large chunk of your business expenses: A large chunk of your business expenses will be tax deductible.¬†
This means that these expenses will be d: This means that these expenses will be deducted from your profits, and in turn, reduce your tax bill.

Admins and bookkeepers can also set up t: Admins and bookkeepers can also set up tags. These can be implemented from Xero or e-conomic, and of course, can be set up directly in Pleo.¬†
Tags make it possible to trace all kinds: Tags make it possible to trace all kinds of financial dimensions of a business expense.¬†

Everything your business needs to know a: Everything your business needs to know about invoice management
Getting on top of invoice management can: Getting on top of invoice management can save your company huge amounts of time and money. Here's how.
We‚Äôre living in an era of transformati: We‚Äôre living in an era of transformation for so many industries, but some things feel as if they never change.
Invoice management is a huge deal for bu: Invoice management is a huge deal for businesses across Europe and our numbers back that up.
In a recent survey of hundreds of financ: In a recent survey of hundreds of finance admins, we discovered that for the majority of companies, invoices account for more than 50% of all spending. And for half of all finance teams, bills account for 75% or more of all outgoings.
So the process behind them is clearly a: So the process behind them is clearly a crucial one.
An invoice is issued by a business to re: An invoice is issued by a business to record a transaction with a customer ‚Äì it details the goods or services provided, how much is owed, when the transaction took place and the terms of payment.
Normally, each invoice has a unique refe: Normally, each invoice has a unique reference to help both parties track it properly.
Often, the words \"bill\" and \"invoice\: Often, the words "bill" and "invoice" are used interchanagably. If you want to dive deep into the differences between the documents, this Investopedia article is a great starting place.
Invoice management is the process by whi: Invoice management is the process by which businesses receive, track, pay and account for invoices that they receive from suppliers.
It could be goods, like office supplies: It could be goods, like office supplies or computer hardware. It could be services, like software subscriptions or agencies. Or it could be utilities: your internet, power or heating.
Some invoices you get and pay only once. Others arrive like clockwork every month. And if we‚Äôre honest, some drop into your lap at the worst possible time, when it comes to cashflow.
Let‚Äôs imagine your IT manager orders 1: Let‚Äôs imagine your IT manager orders 10 new laptops, to upgrade the hardware your team uses every day. Great for the people who get the new kit, but not so fun for everyone else involved in the payment and tracking of the bill.
The invoice will get emailed to the IT M: The invoice will get emailed to the IT Manager, since they placed the order. (Some invoices are of course still issued in hard copy, but more and more have moved to digital-only.)
Now, most likely your IT manager isn‚Äôt: Now, most likely your IT manager isn‚Äôt in a position to fork out a couple of thousand pounds, so instead they‚Äôll manually enter the vital data on your invoice processing system. That then winds its way to the finance team for their approval. Hopefully, there are no errors.
Your finance team need to check over the: Your finance team need to check over the invoice and if they‚Äôre happy , they‚Äôll sign off the payment.
A decision has to be made on when to pay: A decision has to be made on when to pay the invoice, since those large costs can have a major impact on company budgets.
Oh! And not forgetting the last key step: Oh! And not forgetting the last key step ‚Äì when the payment is made, the company accounts need to be updated to reflect the payment.
The problems with traditional invoice ma: The problems with traditional invoice management
Speaking to finance admins makes somethi: Speaking to finance admins makes something clear: Every stage of the bills process brings its own stresses.
You can break that down step-by-step.

For others, approving the paperwork was: For others, approving the paperwork was where things ground to a halt. You‚Äôve got to check for any errors or discrepancies of course and if you spot one, it might have to go back to the supplier for corrections. On top of that, often you spend a lot of time on documents that are‚Ä¶ absolutely fine.

How Pleo hires: From your application to: How Pleo hires: From your application to your first day
Pleo has a unique approach to hiring and: Pleo has a unique approach to hiring and onboarding new members of our team. We'd love to tell you more about it.
Get butterflies in your stomach before a: Get butterflies in your stomach before an interview? You're not alone.
Since 2015, our team have been feeling t: Since 2015, our team have been feeling those butterflies every time we speak to a candidate for a role in Pleo.
That's because we try our best to find t: That's because we try our best to find the right people, whether that's a new developer, a CX specialist, a Product Marketing whizz or an Account Executive.
We hire in a way that's pretty unique ‚Ä: We hire in a way that's pretty unique ‚Äì and hopefully keeps those butterflies to a minimum for everyone.
We're always excited to talk about hirin: We're always excited to talk about hiring and onboarding (in fact we wrote a whole book on these topics) but first, a quick catch-up on why we're celebrating right now.
First up, the Pleo team now numbers 300: First up, the Pleo team now numbers 300 employees.
It's very cool to say that some of our e: It's very cool to say that some of our earliest hires are still here, while naturally, some others have left to pursue their own adventure.
We're really grateful to everyone who's: We're really grateful to everyone who's been a part of the journey up to now.
Secondly, our Bricks programme just turn: Secondly, our Bricks programme just turned two.
Every Pleo hire ‚Äì be they full-time, p: Every Pleo hire ‚Äì be they full-time, part-time, student worker or full-time remote ‚Äì takes part in the same sessions.
We're really proud of how it's evolved,: We're really proud of how it's evolved, especially with the feedback continually showing that the "friendly", "energetic" but "detailed" programme helps people find their feet with us.
And the programme has survived some test: And the programme has survived some testing times. When lockdown hit, we took Bricks online and got a little creative in how we welcomed new starters.
If building a team of 300 and launching: If building a team of 300 and launching Bricks has taught us anything, it's that transparency goes a long way in making new signings to Team Pleo.
So we'd love to lay out what you can ant: So we'd love to lay out what you can anticipate if you spot a job that looks cool and want to apply.
(It's probably a good idea at this stage: (It's probably a good idea at this stage to say that not every candidate goes through the exact process below. Time pressure or business necessities can mean that things change a little bit, but we'll bend over backwards to give you the best possible experience.)
We get a lot of applications. Which is g: We get a lot of applications. Which is great, of course, but means we need to do a bit of homework before deciding who stands out.
So, we start off by running through prof: So, we start off by running through profiles on our end and pick those who we feel would be a good fit for a quick call. On this call, you'll speak to either the hiring manager (the team leader overseeing the process) or someone from our People Ops department.
Hopefully, this is a chance to create a: Hopefully, this is a chance to create a  great first impression on both sides. We‚Äôll chat about any relevant skills and experience you have and why you‚Äôre interested in working with us.
On your side, you will hear more about P: On your side, you will hear more about Pleo and see if we‚Äôre actually an exciting company for you.
Think of this as having a coffee with a: Think of this as having a coffee with a potential teammate. This is not a one-way audition, it‚Äôs equally important that Pleo is a good match for you, your needs and expectations.¬†
So take a breath and be yourself. That‚Ä: So take a breath and be yourself. That‚Äôs exactly who we‚Äôre looking to meet.
If, indeed you had your kick-off call wi: If, indeed you had your kick-off call with someone from our wonderful People Ops department, don't be surprised or alarmed if you're invited in for a quick get-to-know with the hiring manager too. If indeed this step is outlined, it'll give you the chance to ask more team and responsibility-specific questions with your potential future boss.
Lastly, this step could also be wedged i: Lastly, this step could also be wedged in as a 3.5. step following the Team interview, outlined below.
Nervous? Don‚Äôt be. There are no right: Nervous? Don‚Äôt be. There are no right or wrong answers here, the Challenge round offers candidates a chance to show off what they're bringing to the table.
Each team has a different task, designed: Each team has a different task, designed especially for the role that's available. So you might be making a mock sales call, creating a draft storyboard or sketching out plans for a new Pleo feature.
We don‚Äôt set a strict deadline for you: We don‚Äôt set a strict deadline for you to complete and send back the challenge. But we can give you a heads-up on how long the challenge should take in our initial call ‚Äì and we're only an email away if you need to check in.
This stage is a chance for you to show u: This stage is a chance for you to show us your problem-solving skills. It‚Äôs also our way of showcasing the types of scenarios you‚Äôll find yourself in should you join the team.
We‚Äôve seen a lot of people shine with: We‚Äôve seen a lot of people shine with their challenge, and we really appreciate you taking the time to give it your best.
Most of our challenges are open-ended wi: Most of our challenges are open-ended with no objectively right or wrong answer. Instead of assuming what we‚Äôd like to see, we encourage you to approach the challenge as if nobody was reviewing it. We've love to see something that‚Äôs 100% you.
Of course, the challenge won‚Äôt cover e: Of course, the challenge won‚Äôt cover everything, but it does give us a really clear idea of how you approach work and communicate your thinking.
Now, in your mind, fast forward two mont: Now, in your mind, fast forward two months. Imagine you have joined Pleo and are sitting with your new team, ready to tackle things IRL... Well, that‚Äôs what the team interview should feel like.
Expect to share a meeting room (real or: Expect to share a meeting room (real or virtual) with 2-3 people that you'll be working with if you get the job. These might be on the team you want to join, or from another Pleo department altogether, either way, they'll have a keen interest in finding the right person.
Don't expect a grilling though, by this: Don't expect a grilling though, by this stage we really want to get know you and what makes you tick.
There'll be some chat about your challen: There'll be some chat about your challenge, your experience, your responsibilities ‚Äì but also a definite chance for you to find out more about Pleo.
What's great about working here? What pr: What's great about working here? What projects make people proud? What are we working to improve?
At the end of this stage, you should hav: At the end of this stage, you should have a great sense of whether Pleo is a company you'd like to join.
Show us your way of tackling the job wit: Show us your way of tackling the job with the hard and soft skills needed. We love seeing how you‚Äôll work with us and how you‚Äôll also bring something new to our team.
We‚Äôre always changing, growing and lea: We‚Äôre always changing, growing and learning as part of work here ‚Äì we want to see that you‚Äôre just as eager to learn. Don‚Äôt be afraid to challenge our current way of working.¬†
Only a handful of people get to this sta: Only a handful of people get to this stage, so congratulations.
This is where you get a bit of face time: This is where you get a bit of face time with somebody senior in the company, but don't be daunted. For a lot of candidates this is a really fulfilling session where you see the big picture for Pleo and chat about how your role will figure into that.
And for our part, we'd love to see that: And for our part, we'd love to see that you embody the right values and would contribute positively to our culture.
Think about your values and how they wou: Think about your values and how they would match ours. What matters to you? Our team members are very easy to talk to, all the way to the top. So, and yep we're going to say it again: Be yourself.
If everybody‚Äôs onboard at this stage,: If everybody‚Äôs onboard at this stage, we might be in touch with an offer. If that‚Äôs the case, you‚Äôre just one final "yes" away from joining the team.
The nature of the modern workplace is ch: The nature of the modern workplace is changing so fast.
We believe it‚Äôs important that the hir: We believe it‚Äôs important that the hiring process keeps up with it, because it's clearly a vital step in building a company that people love.
The stages above have helped us identify: The stages above have helped us identify and hire the smart, caring, driven people that made Pleo what it is today.
If this post has got you interested in j: If this post has got you interested in joining (or more interested than you already were) you can find out what opportunities we have on our careers page.

Allowable expenses: The good, the bad, t: Allowable expenses: The good, the bad, the ugly
When it comes to your team claiming expe: When it comes to your team claiming expenses at work, there‚Äôs often a blurred line between what is and isn't allowed.

When it comes to your team claiming expenses at work, there‚Äôs often a blurred line between what‚Äôs allowed, what‚Äôs pushing it and what‚Äôs absolutely not allowed. You‚Äôd be surprised at what some people try to claim as a business expense, but more on that later.
But, what exactly is an allowable expens: But, what exactly is an allowable expense?¬†
Well, they‚Äôre essential costs that kee: Well, they‚Äôre essential costs that keep your business ticking over every month. These kinds of costs aren‚Äôt considered part of your company‚Äôs taxable profits, which means you don‚Äôt pay tax on these expenses. Let‚Äôs say you made ¬£15,000 last year but spent ¬£2,000 on allowable expenses, you would only be taxed on ¬£13,000.¬†
This is where things get a little more c: This is where things get a little more complicated: not every purchase you make can be put down as an allowable expense.¬†
In this blog post, we‚Äôll outline what: In this blog post, we‚Äôll outline what does, and doesn‚Äôt, count as an allowable expense so you‚Äôre better equipped to not commit accidental tax avoidance...
Well, these are the everyday, essential: Well, these are the everyday, essential costs that keep your business ticking over, and some of these allowable expenses come with rules as set by HMRC:¬†
Whether they‚Äôre full-time, part-time o: Whether they‚Äôre full-time, part-time or contractors. In one way or another, this expense has contributed towards your company.
Various kinds of company insurance can b: Various kinds of company insurance can be claimed at the end of a financial year. From professional indemnity insurance to contents insurance to public liability insurance and employers‚Äô liability insurance.¬†
Unless you‚Äôre self-employed, it‚Äôs un: Unless you‚Äôre self-employed, it‚Äôs unlikely that you‚Äôll be able to deduct home office space costs from your business taxes. However, HMRC does provide some relief for those having to work from home as a result of the pandemic ‚Äî ¬£6 a week from 6 April 2020.
If you‚Äôre running your own business fr: If you‚Äôre running your own business from home, you may be entitled to claim certain costs as a business expense ‚Äî from heating to water bills to home insurance to business calls. But you‚Äôll have to prove a few things: how long you spend working in your home office and what kind of equipment you‚Äôve purchased, and what for.¬†
This includes all your water, rent and p: This includes all your water, rent and power costs at the office ‚Äî and even includes the cost of your office rent.
Did you travel for work? Maybe you visit: Did you travel for work? Maybe you visited the HQ office via public transport or paid for fuel to meet with a client. If it‚Äôs a trip for work purposes, you can claim the money back.
As outlined by HMRC, if you travel 12,00: As outlined by HMRC, if you travel 12,000 business miles in your car or van, the approved amount for the year would be ¬£5,000. This works out at 45p for the first 10,000 miles and 25p for each subsequent mile after this. For motorcyclists, they can claim 24p per mile and push bikes can claim 20p per mile, with no mileage restrictions.
However, the commute to your daily workp: However, the commute to your daily workplace isn‚Äôt tax-deductible.
Almost every business relies on technolo: Almost every business relies on technology for one thing or the other, whether that‚Äôs software subscriptions or IT equipment or your phone bill. ¬†
This includes the physical things that k: This includes the physical things that keep your office running. From desks to paper to printer supplies.
The way you spread news about your compa: The way you spread news about your company is also tax-deductible ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs through social media marketing, in a newspaper or a giant billboard on the motorway. You‚Äôre also able to expense the cost of your website's domain.
This can be anything from hiring IT supp: This can be anything from hiring IT support to a cleaning team to accounting to legal fees.
You can find the full HMRC list of appro: You can find the full HMRC list of approved business expenses here.¬†
What doesn‚Äôt count as an allowable bus: What doesn‚Äôt count as an allowable business expense?
Well, this includes any personal expense: Well, this includes any personal expense, whether it‚Äôs a new mansion, a racehorse or a fancy dress outfit. These kinds of purchases can‚Äôt be claimed as business expenses, unfortunately ‚Äî unless your business is entering horse races while dressed as a superhero.¬†
Another cost that HMRC doesn‚Äôt conside: Another cost that HMRC doesn‚Äôt consider as a business expense is entertainment. Although this is a big part of impressing clients ‚Äî be that gifts or expensive meals-out ‚Äî you can‚Äôt have tax deducted. This is mainly down to the fact that you can only claim staff costs for people who work in your business.
For example, HMRC outlines that Christma: For example, HMRC outlines that Christmas or annual events can be claimed provided it‚Äôs open to all employees and the cost per head doesn‚Äôt exceed ¬£150, which includes VAT. If the cost goes over the allotted ¬£150, then tax must be paid on the whole amount.
Another example of a non-deductible expe: Another example of a non-deductible expense is any fines you‚Äôve picked up ‚Äî be that a parking penalty or fine from HMRC themselves.¬†
And then there‚Äôs the more questionable: And then there‚Äôs the more questionable expense¬†
While many companies share the same allo: While many companies share the same allowable expenses, they differ from industry-to-industry. Amidst the kind of expenses you‚Äôd expect to see ‚Äî from lunch to flights ‚Äî you might just find some pretty weird expense requests too.¬†
A Certify study, which was conducted bet: A Certify study, which was conducted between 2013 and 2018, investigated some of the more questionable expenses that companies had either approved or denied.¬†
They found that one employer approved of: They found that one employer approved of an $800 (¬£576) human skull ‚Äúfor a medical experiment‚Äù and another had approved an $8,000 (¬£5,763)men‚Äôs Rolex watch for ‚Äúcustomer appreciation‚Äù.¬†
But not everything was approved‚Ä¶ a $6,: But not everything was approved‚Ä¶ a $6,500 (¬£4,682) helicopter ride to work was denied, even though the employee said it was ‚Äúneeded to make it to a client meeting‚Äù. Also, a $10,000 (¬£7,204) hotel bill and flight change fee was denied after an employee punched a hole in a wall and rebooked a flight due to missing the original one while in jail.¬†
A ¬£60 shirt that cost the company an em: A ¬£60 shirt that cost the company an employee¬†
Over the years, we‚Äôve heard some horro: Over the years, we‚Äôve heard some horror stories about dealing with manual expenses when there‚Äôs no expense policy. Just one of these stories was from Steve Parks, Convivio‚Äôs CEO.¬†¬†
‚ÄúA friend of mine worked for a large m: ‚ÄúA friend of mine worked for a large management consultancy, he was away on holiday when a project started to go wrong. They had a crisis meeting with the client and demanded he had to abandon his holiday and fly right back to save the deal. He‚Äôs a good guy, so he agreed,‚Äù Parks said.
‚ÄúBut all he had was beachwear. The onl: ‚ÄúBut all he had was beachwear. The only chance he had to buy a shirt was at the airport for ¬£60, before he saw the client. He saved the deal and added the shirt to his expenses claim. But his manager told him: ‚ÄòShirts are not expensable!‚Äô They had an argument, he spent the next few months trying to claw the ¬£60 back in various expenses‚Ä¶ but ultimately, what it really did was set him up to leave the company.‚Äù
Consider using a few of these examples i: Consider using a few of these examples in your own company expense policy to avoid any misunderstandings. Because after all, who knew you couldn‚Äôt use company money to pay for a helicopter ride? Oh, and don‚Äôt let a ¬£60 shirt cost you a team member, especially if they‚Äôd leave their holiday for their job.¬†

In Pleo's early years, we believed our T: In Pleo's early years, we believed our Team Camps were important. Now we're absolutely certain of it.
Once you join Pleo, it won't be long bef: Once you join Pleo, it won't be long before you hear about Team Camp (TC for short).
People are either still talking about th: People are either still talking about the last TC or they're making plans for the next one. The destination, the people they're going to connect with, the things they want to learn.
Our own co-founder Nicco has referred to: Our own co-founder Nicco has referred to TCs as a "logistical nightmare" (and they can be tough for our People Ops organisers!), but he's also one of their biggest champions.
More companies are embracing remote work: More companies are embracing remote work, but still chase those moments of real world connection.
More companies are truly embracing remot: More companies are truly embracing remote work but if they're anything like us, it won't take long for them to realise that getting together in person still has huge value. And once you grow to our current stage (300+ employees, five offices across Europe ‚Äì and ambitious plans to grow even more!), the value of Team Camp just increases.
\"Logistical nightmare\" or not, this is: "Logistical nightmare" or not, this is why it's worth the hassle.
Simply put, Team Camp is us trying to ge: Simply put, Team Camp is us trying to get every member of our team together in one place ‚Äì regardless of where they're normally based.
That means everyone based in our Copenha: That means everyone based in our Copenhagen, London, Madrid, Stockholm or Berlin offices decamps to one destination to mingle together.
It gets better ‚Äì because our workforce: It gets better ‚Äì because our workforce might be scattered all over the world, but we're all part of the same team, no matter what timezone we're in. So, for TC, our remotes fly in from Quebec City, Cape Town, Milan (and lots of other places besides).
And what did they get at the end of a lo: And what did they get at the end of a long flight? A lot: Workshops, socialising and everything in between.
(NB: Of course for some people, making T: (NB: Of course for some people, making Team Camp isn't always possible for a variety of reasons. We work overtime to make sure they get a cool experience too and don't suffer too much FOMO. Keep your eyes out for a future blog on how we try to do that.)
Does Team Camp *have* to be outside your: Does Team Camp *have* to be outside your office, in some far-flung location?
It's a good question and the past few ye: It's a good question and the past few years have seen us experimenting with different options; sometimes out of necessity, sometimes out of a drive to keep experimenting.
It's all a question of what's right for: It's all a question of what's right for your team at the time of course.
In 2018, we could hit the slopes of Saal: In 2018, we could hit the slopes of Saalbach in Austria ‚Äì but that was when our company basically filled a single chalet for the apr√®s ski fun. Now we'd probably fill a couple of ski resorts... and that's harder to organise.
During the lockdowns of 2020, we staged: During the lockdowns of 2020, we staged a fully remote Team Camp which was rewarding in its own way, but which some of us felt lacked some of the sparkle of Pleo "taking over" a location.
That's probably why our first proper TC: That's probably why our first proper TC of 2021, when travel was opened up again, saw us decamp to a hotel in Spain for some sun, sand and strategy.
We've experimented with different types: We've experimented with different types of Team Camp.
Team Camp is our opportunity to reconnec: Team Camp is our opportunity to reconnect to our business goals, our purpose and to one another.
We do a number of sessions ‚Äì some of w: We do a number of sessions ‚Äì some of which see us all together in one room, some of which see us break off into smaller groups. Expect lots of interactivity, lots of idea exchanges and a LOT of "you're taller than I imagined from Slack".
Also, expect some treasure hunts or bing: Also, expect some treasure hunts or bingo games that give us a chance to have some fun together.
The beauty of Team Camp is that often we: The beauty of Team Camp is that often we're mixing with people from different parts of the business, so that Product can bump up against Sales who can mix with Marketing. It brings us all that little bit closer together and helps us appreciate the different departments that make Pleo work.
And the whole thing is kept as interacti: And the whole thing is kept as interactive as possible, because we just don't believe in sitting in the same conference room for eight hours, enduring another presentation and desperately waiting for a loo break.
If it sounds like there are a lot of mov: If it sounds like there are a lot of moving parts to a Team Camp, well, there are. But we try to make that part of the fun.
So back to our initial question: Why in: So back to our initial question: Why in the world do we do these?
Amid all of our team‚Äôs achievements, T: Amid all of our team‚Äôs achievements, Team Camp is when we hit pause and reflect. We shine a light on different teams‚Äô progress to see what's working, what isn‚Äôt, and how aspects of our business could be approached from new angles.
New brand initiatives or upcoming produc: New brand initiatives or upcoming product launches can get the kind of exciting, glitzy launch that just isn't possible in a virtual meeting.
Team Camp is a chance to set new ambitio: Team Camp is a chance to set new ambitions for the future of better business spending and form early hypotheses on what it takes to get there.
It gives us the sense of purpose that we: It gives us the sense of purpose that we need to work together toward a common goal.

How to run a great company off-site in 2: How to run a great company off-site in 2021 (and beyond)
Image collage from Pleo Team Camp 2021: Image collage from Pleo Team Camp 2021
Here are the top lessons learned from th: Here are the top lessons learned from this year‚Äôs TC.
It‚Äôs hard enough planning a team dinne: It‚Äôs hard enough planning a team dinner every few months.
Never mind getting 370 people from 20 co: Never mind getting 370 people from 20 countries to the Costa Brava, Spain for a team off-site‚Ä¶but that‚Äôs exactly what we did.
It rocked but it also taught us a lot ab: It rocked but it also taught us a lot about hosting major events after the upheaval of the past few years.¬†¬†
Think of a Team Camp (or TC) as a way to: Think of a Team Camp (or TC) as a way to kill the routine, and combine strategy with socialising.¬†
It‚Äôs a chance for every Pleo‚Äôer to g: It‚Äôs a chance for every Pleo‚Äôer to get together and get excited about what we stand for, where we‚Äôre going, and who we‚Äôre going there with.
Read more about why we think hosting com: Read more about why we think hosting company-wide TCs are crucial.¬†
Clearly this has ‚Äúlogistical nightmare: Clearly this has ‚Äúlogistical nightmare‚Äù written all over it ‚Äì not to mention the extra layer of Covid restrictions that were necessary this year.
Despite this, the People team here at Pl: Despite this, the People team here at Pleo still created a memorable, inclusive and safe experience.
A pretty impressive feat ‚Äì so it felt: A pretty impressive feat ‚Äì so it felt like a good time to catch up with the team to learn more about all the moving parts that go into planning TCs and how they see these company-wide events evolving as we continue to grow (pssst ‚Äì we‚Äôre hiring).¬†
Thinking about doing something similar a: Thinking about doing something similar at your company? Here are the top lessons learned from this year‚Äôs TC.
‚ÄúPlanning the next TC is this huge sid: ‚ÄúPlanning the next TC is this huge side project to our day-to-day responsibilities that carries a big, important cultural aspect for Pleo. We really have to dedicate ourselves to finding that balance,‚Äù says Hannah Randera, People Ops Manager.¬†
Pleo‚Äôs past TCs weren‚Äôt on such a gr: Pleo‚Äôs past TCs weren‚Äôt on such a grand scale because, well, we were a much smaller team back then. Taking ten people to go skiing in Saalbach, Austria versus 300+ to Spain ‚Äì it‚Äôs a different ball game.¬†
To kick-off a project like this, the Peo: To kick-off a project like this, the People team focused on four key points as a group:¬†¬†
‚ÄúFor an event at this size, we really: ‚ÄúFor an event at this size, we really needed to make sure that the accommodation would suit all of our needs ‚Äì and I don‚Äôt just mean comfy pillows and a delicious breakfast,"  says Evangelos Diamantis, Employee Experience Manager.¬†¬†¬†¬†
‚ÄúWe needed a conference room that woul: ‚ÄúWe needed a conference room that would fit nearly 400 people, with enough screens so there are no bad seats and a solid sound system so no-one would have a poor experience during any of the sessions.‚Äù
Picture of Evangelos Diamantis, Employee: Picture of Evangelos Diamantis, Employee Experience Manager at Pleo
There are a few things the team consider: There are a few things the team considers when it comes to location ‚Äì are there direct flights from all Pleo offices? And is it easy and accessible for the majority of Pleo‚Äôers?¬†
‚ÄúI feel the accommodation and location: ‚ÄúI feel the accommodation and location found us in a way ‚Äì we saw the rooftop pool, which had been newly renovated. Plus, nice, new rooms. It was such a good offer for our team being so big now," says Hannah.
\"And Spain is one of our markets. I thi: "And Spain is one of our markets. I think it‚Äôs important to get into our local markets.‚Äù
It‚Äôs also important to know your limit: It‚Äôs also important to know your limits
Accommodation and location locked in ‚Äì: Accommodation and location locked in ‚Äì how do you get people there?¬†
Everyone in the company was required to: Everyone in the company was required to fill out a form indicating if they were planning to participate, and then all the necessary information was collected. Names, passport numbers, food preferences, emergency contacts ‚Äì the important stuff.¬†
Receiving all those forms, marking the r: Receiving all those forms, marking the responses, and recording allergies is enough to make anyone‚Äôs head spin.¬†
So when it was time to start buying tick: So when it was time to start buying tickets, the team knew they needed some outside help.¬†
‚ÄúFlights. An absolute nightmare. Thank: ‚ÄúFlights. An absolute nightmare. Thank goodness we had an agency for that," says Evangelos.¬†¬†
Using an agency really streamlined booki: Using an agency really streamlined booking flights and trains from each of Pleo‚Äôs offices, while remotes were able to book themselves (using their Pleo cards, of course).
It‚Äôs a pandemic. People need to stay s: It‚Äôs a pandemic. People need to stay safe.
‚ÄúWe knew that we needed an on-the-grou: ‚ÄúWe knew that we needed an on-the-ground Covid safety strategy ‚Äì every day, everyone was required to self-test‚Äù, says Hannah.¬†
Not all 370 people could be individually: Not all 370 people could be individually checked each morning, so it came down to a lot of transparency and trust ‚Äì a few of Pleo‚Äôs core values.¬†¬†
Picture of Hannah Radera, People Ops Man: Picture of Hannah Radera, People Ops Manager at Pleo
‚ÄúTo hold each other accountable, we fo: ‚ÄúTo hold each other accountable, we formed teams with their own Slack channel. These teams were formulated based on other social activities and workshops during TC. And what we asked of people was simple ‚Äì just swab your nose in the morning and give the thumbs up indicating 'I‚Äôve taken the test and have a valid result' with your group. That‚Äôs it.‚Äù¬†
And who doesn‚Äôt love a little nose swa: And who doesn‚Äôt love a little nose swab before your morning cup of coffee?¬†
Two months out, it‚Äôs time to set the a: Two months out, it‚Äôs time to set the agenda ‚Äì key strategy sessions, team challenges and activities. It‚Äôs a good idea to share this ASAP. People like to know what they‚Äôll be up to for three days.¬†
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important that everyone knows: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important that everyone knows where Pleo is going, where Pleo wants to be, and what‚Äôs your part in the company and its ambition. It‚Äôs essential to have everyone informed but also empowered," says Milu Varela, Community Manager.¬†
On the docket this year? Everything from: On the docket this year? Everything from a presentation on the future of our product to a fireside chat with Pleo‚Äôs latest investors to a team-building scavenger hunt. Some yoga and kayaking, too. ¬†¬†
‚ÄúThere are a lot of different people a: ‚ÄúThere are a lot of different people and personalities in our company. It's important to calibrate for different people ‚Äì¬†know your team, and what they like," adds Evangelos.
Being inclusive means being remote-first: Being inclusive means being remote-first too
‚ÄúAll our efforts were pushing for the: ‚ÄúAll our efforts were pushing for the Spain-based TC, but we started realising that not everyone was going to make it ‚Äì people are having babies, COVID restrictions were making it too difficult... Or some people just weren‚Äôt ready to travel yet," says Hannah. "So we had to stop and think: How can we make them enjoy this time the same as everyone else?‚Äù¬†
Because no one likes sitting on Zoom for: Because no one likes sitting on Zoom for hours on end feeling like they‚Äôre looking through a window.
The answer? Solo and DIY TCs.
A Solo TC is when a Pleo‚Äôer is by them: A Solo TC is when a Pleo‚Äôer is by themselves. They were able to sign up for Master Classes, webinars and order take-away ‚Äì essentially building their own activities for the day. And a DIY TC was created for Pleo‚Äôers that lived in the same city (or close enough) and they built an agenda together.¬†
With a separate budget allocated to Solo: With a separate budget allocated to Solo and DIY TCers, the People team was able to make everyone feel included and a part of the TC in Spain too.¬†
Based on a recent Culture Amp survey, 80: Based on a recent Culture Amp survey, 80% of Pleo‚Äôers said they enjoyed the remote (DIY/Solo) TCs.
And this was done by hiring a film crew: And this was done by hiring a film crew to record the key sessions of the day, editing straight away and uploading the content for the remotes to watch all within a few hours.¬†
There was even the opportunity to link u: There was even the opportunity to link up with the Head of Brand, COO and others for a Q&A session ‚Äì aka exclusive content. The key thing here is not to try to create the same experience as the one in Spain, but to create a unique experience for all remote joiners.
Picture of Milu Varela, Community Manage: Picture of Milu Varela, Community Manager at Pleo
‚ÄúI think DIY and Solo TCs are somethin: ‚ÄúI think DIY and Solo TCs are something we need to have every year from now - regardless of the pandemic. There will always be people who can‚Äôt make it. Everyone has different personal situations. This is part of being inclusive, and Pleo is an inclusive company,‚Äù says Milu.
Time differences were accounted for too:: Time differences were accounted for too: People could also view the extra sessions whenever suited them best ‚Äì we see you Pleo‚Äôers in Canada and Argentina.
‚ÄúIf people can see what it takes from: ‚ÄúIf people can see what it takes from day one, up to the last day ‚Äì working from morning until midnight...it‚Äôs hard but very gratifying seeing people happy and satisfied - that‚Äôs the best reward. I‚Äôm really proud of what we accomplished,‚Äù says Evangelos.¬†
From the same survey, 98% of Pleo‚Äôers: From the same survey, 98% of Pleo‚Äôers said they enjoyed Spain‚Äôs TC.
‚ÄúA few days before, I felt a bit nervo: ‚ÄúA few days before, I felt a bit nervous ‚Äì like what if they don‚Äôt like the team challenge and so on? But everyone was just so excited to see each other,‚Äù says Hannah, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really nice to feel part of something big like this.‚Äù¬†
As we continue to grow, TC might start t: As we continue to grow, TC might start to look a bit different or happen less frequently but what is important is that they‚Äôll always be a crucial part of Pleo's DNA.¬†
One last tip from the team ‚Äì start enc: One last tip from the team ‚Äì start encouraging and getting people excited about company-wide events from their very first day to continuously build the TC spirit into your company culture.
And finally, a big round of applause to: And finally, a big round of applause to our People team üëè¬†

‚ÄúI provide the support and guidance to: ‚ÄúI provide the support and guidance to our Partnerships teams across our markets, ensuring that everything is working as it should‚Äù, says Ida, ‚ÄúThat we‚Äôre providing our partners with truly the best solution and that we have the right people to cater to these relationships.‚Äù¬†

And hopefully the solution is Pleo and everything we have to offer.‚Äù¬†

Put simply, cash flow management is the: Put simply, cash flow management is the process of keeping track of, as well as analysing, how much money is coming in and out of your business. The three main things to understand about cash flow are: negative cash flow, positive cash flow and profit vs. cash flow.¬†
Cash flow (noun): the total amount of mo: Cash flow (noun): the total amount of money being transferred into and out of a business, especially as affecting liquidity.¬†
When you have a negative cash flow, it m: When you have a negative cash flow, it means your business is spending more money than it‚Äôs making. But it doesn‚Äôt mean your company is in the red zone per see ‚Äì your cash flow may just be down temporarily, because of things like mismatched spending and income.¬†
For example, maybe you have large cash o: For example, maybe you have large cash outflows for a specific period ‚Äì like if your company is spending the big bucks on new equipment.¬†
Which can also, unfortunately, be a sign: Which can also, unfortunately, be a sign of fraudulent activity if the negative cash flow cannot otherwise be explained.
On the flipside, we have positive cash f: On the flipside, we have positive cash flow. A positive cash flow indicates that a company is adding to its cash reserves, meaning you have enough working capital to cover your bills and don‚Äôt require additional funding during that period.¬†
But before you bust out the cake and Cha: But before you bust out the cake and Champagne, a positive cash flow doesn‚Äôt always mean the business is profitable. The surplus in cash flow could exist due to an influx of loan capital or dividends to shareholders not being paid out yet.
Which brings us to profit versus cash fl: Which brings us to profit versus cash flow. These are not the same.
Profit is typically defined as the balan: Profit is typically defined as the balance that remains when a business‚Äôs operating expenses are deducted from its revenue.¬†
Cash flow is more important to keep the: Cash flow is more important to keep the business operating day-to-day, while profit is more indicative of your business‚Äôs overall success.¬†
And like cash flow, profits can be repre: And like cash flow, profits can be represented as a negative or positive number.¬†
Right, those are the basics of what cash: Right, those are the basics of what cash flow is ‚Äì let's dig a little deeper, shall we?¬†
Why is cash important to a small busines: Why is cash important to a small business?¬†
No business, big or small, can afford to: No business, big or small, can afford to ignore its cash flow. Because cash is what keeps your business ticking over. You need it for daily operations, taxes, purchasing inventory, paying employees and so on.¬†
If you don‚Äôt have cash, your business: If you don‚Äôt have cash, your business will stop working.
Managing your cash flow is figuring out: Managing your cash flow is figuring out when you‚Äôll have cash ready to be used, how to get it faster and how to keep an eye on company spending so you don‚Äôt run into future cash flow problems.¬†
Benefits of good cash flow management: Benefits of good cash flow management
There‚Äôs a broad range of advantages as: There‚Äôs a broad range of advantages associated with getting your cash flow management right, but here are some of the key benefits that effective cash flow management can have on your small business:¬†
Staying on top of your cash flow allows: Staying on top of your cash flow allows you to make better plans and decisions. If you don‚Äôt have accurate information, you could potentially make a bad decision and put your small business at risk.¬†
A bird‚Äôs-eye view of company spending¬: A bird‚Äôs-eye view of company spending¬†
An accurate cash flow statement also pro: An accurate cash flow statement also provides insight into your company‚Äôs overall spending. You‚Äôll know exactly where the money is going and why. Plus, it‚Äôll make it easier to identify which areas of the business you can afford to cut costs.
It‚Äôll also ensure you keep solid busin: It‚Äôll also ensure you keep solid business relationships. Staying on top of cash flow means you‚Äôll avoid having problems paying suppliers ‚Äì¬†because no one likes receiving a late payment.¬†
Get the bank loans you need¬†: Get the bank loans you need¬†
Many entrepreneurs and small business ow: Many entrepreneurs and small business owners just starting out will probably depend on a bank or similar financial institution for their business activities. Before approving a loan, the bank will take a look at the financial condition of your company as well as its ability to repay the amount. In addition to tax returns and income statements, an up-to-date and organised cash flow statement will be used as proof.¬†
Know when it‚Äôs time to expand¬†: Know when it‚Äôs time to expand¬†
Managing your cash flow effectively will: Managing your cash flow effectively will make it easier for you to know when it‚Äôs the right time for your small business to expand and grow. Because growth requires a lot of cash¬† ‚Äì renting a bigger office, hiring more people, purchasing more laptops and so on. If you don‚Äôt have the funds to match the planned growth, you‚Äôre gonna run into some trouble.

1. Expecting profitability too fast
Many start-ups don‚Äôt become profitable for two or three years. If you‚Äôre not prepared for this, that can create cash flow problems from the very beginning.

If your office rent, car leases and travel costs are too high, this will definitely eat into your finances.
3. Not getting your pricing right\nWitho:
3. Not getting your pricing right
Without a sustainable profit margin, you could always be battling cash flow problems. Make sure to continuously review and track your pricing and cost details so you can be aware if changes are necessary.

And reducing overhead costs isn‚Äôt only: And reducing overhead costs isn‚Äôt only important in those first few years, it can really make a big difference in the long-term profitability and cash flow of your business.¬†

We sat down with our Rockstar Speaker, K: We sat down with our Rockstar Speaker, Kim Scott, to talk about Radical Candor and find out what "forward" means to her.
On December 9th, we‚Äôre hosting Forward: On December 9th, we‚Äôre hosting Forward, a digital summit dedicated to the world of work. We‚Äôre inviting 20+ speakers to share their lessons learned and tell the honest truth about authentic leadership.
One of our Rockstar Speakers is Kim Scot: One of our Rockstar Speakers is Kim Scott, ‚Äã‚Äãauthor of Radical Candor: Be a Kickass Boss without Losing your Humanity and CEO Coach. We sat down with her to talk about Radical Candor and find out what "forward" means to her.

What has your career path looked like so: What has your career path looked like so far?
After 1992, I was working at a telecommu: After 1992, I was working at a telecommunications startup in Israel, which was very interesting and exhausting. As a start-up led by very young people with not a lot of great management experience, I learned how not to manage.
Then, I became the CEO of my own company: Then, I became the CEO of my own company thinking if I were in charge, everything would be great, right? No. It turned out I made a lot of the same mistakes.
At the time, a bunch of people at that s: At the time, a bunch of people at that start-up emailed me the same article about how people would rather have a boss who was a total a**hole but really competent, than a boss who‚Äôs really nice but incompetent. And I thought, are they sending me this because they think I‚Äôm an a**hole or they think I‚Äôm incompetent? But this got me thinking more deeply about leadership.¬†
The core aspects of management are build: The core aspects of management are building a great team, creating a culture of feedback and getting results. Those are the same no matter what kind of organisation you‚Äôre running and this prompted me to write Radical Candor.¬†
Can you tell us more about Radical Cando: Can you tell us more about Radical Candor?¬†
Radical Candor is the ability to ‚Äòcare: Radical Candor is the ability to ‚Äòcare personally‚Äô and ‚Äòchallenge directly.‚Äô This doesn‚Äôt sound so ‚Äòradical‚Äô, but it‚Äôs incredibly rare.¬†
Sometimes we remember to challenge but w: Sometimes we remember to challenge but we forget to show that we care, and that is what I call ‚Äòobnoxious aggression.‚Äô And the Radical Candor framework is not ‚Äòobnoxious aggression,‚Äô it doesn‚Äôt give you the right to say whatever you want.
Very often we realise we‚Äôve landed in: Very often we realise we‚Äôve landed in the ‚Äòobnoxious aggression‚Äô quadrant, and sometimes people think that‚Äôs the ‚Äòa**hole quadrant,‚Äô but I didn‚Äôt call it that for a very important reason. This framework isn‚Äôt another Myers Briggs Personality Test‚Ä¶¬†
Radical Candor is the ability to ‚Äòcare: Radical Candor is the ability to ‚Äòcare personally‚Äô and ‚Äòchallenge directly.‚Äô
Instead, this should be used like a comp: Instead, this should be used like a compass to guide you back to that upper right-hand corner. One of the things that happens when we‚Äôre ‚Äòobnoxiously aggressive‚Äô is that it‚Äôs then instinctive to go the wrong way on ‚Äòchallenge directly‚Äô instead of caring personally.
The vast majority of us make the vast ma: The vast majority of us make the vast majority of mistakes in the top left quadrant, which I call ‚Äòruinous empathy.‚Äô This happens when you do remember to show that you ‚Äòcare personally‚Äô but you‚Äôre so concerned about not hurting someone‚Äôs feelings that you fail to tell them what they‚Äôd be better off knowing.¬†
What are the common management misconcep: What are the common management misconceptions?
One of the most common misunderstandings: One of the most common misunderstandings is that management is neither taught nor valued.
More often than not, people are just thr: More often than not, people are just thrown into the deep end and they don‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs required. Becoming a manager is not a value judgement or who you are as a person, it‚Äôs a responsibility of which you will be held accountable for.¬†
In an ideal world, there are three thing: In an ideal world, there are three things you should be held accountable for as a leader: creating a culture of feedback, building a great and cohesive team and getting results. But you can‚Äôt just skip over the culture and the team and expect good results.
It‚Äôs the culture of feedback and build: It‚Äôs the culture of feedback and building a great team that‚Äôs going to help you get those results.¬†
Mistakes that both experienced managers: Mistakes that both experienced managers and new managers make is thinking they should skip right to execution.¬†
Do gender dynamics come into play when i: Do gender dynamics come into play when it comes to Radical Candor?
Gender dynamics, racial dynamics, sexual: Gender dynamics, racial dynamics, sexual orientation dynamics, religious dynamics ‚Äî there are so many ways that bias and discrimination plays into Radical Candor.¬†
One way that gender dynamics, and underr: One way that gender dynamics, and underrepresentation dynamics, comes into this is very often when a manager is very over-represented. So in the US, that would be a white, cis-gendered male. In general, he would be more reluctant to give feedback to people on his team who are underrepresented.
If you‚Äôre a manager, giving feedback t: If you‚Äôre a manager, giving feedback to everyone is your job. There‚Äôs a lot of research out there that suggests women don‚Äôt get the same developmental feedback as men, and the same is true for black people compared to white people.¬†
And there‚Äôs another thing that happens: And there‚Äôs another thing that happens as well. If you‚Äôre underrepresented, it‚Äôs harder to give feedback if you‚Äôre a woman, if you‚Äôre not white, if you‚Äôre not straight, and not get unjustly accused of ‚Äòobnoxious aggression‚Äô. Only you‚Äôre not going to get called ‚Äòobnoxiously aggressive‚Äô, if you‚Äôre a woman you‚Äôre going to be called ‚Äòbossy‚Äô, ‚Äòbitchy‚Äô or ‚Äòabrasive.‚Äô¬†
What do you think the world of work will: What do you think the world of work will look like in the future when it comes to management?
I‚Äôm an optimist. I believe organisatio: I‚Äôm an optimist. I believe organisations globally are beginning to teach and value good leadership. I also believe we‚Äôve had an awakening between the #MeToo movement and Black Lives Matter. We‚Äôre beginning to realise the extent of which we‚Äôre undervaluing huge numbers of people and therefore collectively hurting our ability as humanity to move forward.¬†
I'm very optimistic that we'll begin to: I'm very optimistic that we'll begin to notice bias, prejudice and bullying and therefore eliminate it from the workplace.
What can we expect from your session at: What can we expect from your session at Forward?
In the talk, I‚Äôll be focusing on feedb: In the talk, I‚Äôll be focusing on feedback and how to create a healthy culture of feedback. I‚Äôll be describing the Radical Candor framework and telling some stories about how I‚Äôve screwed things up in my own career, and what I‚Äôve learned from them.¬†
I‚Äôll also be talking about the specifi: I‚Äôll also be talking about the specific things you can do to solicit feedback at work and how to give praise and criticism.¬†

As we all know by now, the world of work: As we all know by now, the world of work is evolving. And so should some workplace terminology, just one example being Corporate Social Responsibility.
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is defined as a 'self-regulating business model that helps a company be socially accountable ‚Äî to itself, its stakeholders and the public.‚Äô
Alex Stephany, CEO and Founder of Beam,: Alex Stephany, CEO and Founder of Beam, a UK-based charity helping homeless people get out the streets and back into work, believes that while this term is well-intentioned, it‚Äôs time for a change. Here‚Äôs what he had to say about the idea:
‚ÄúI feel like tonally [CSR] comes from: ‚ÄúI feel like tonally [CSR] comes from the 1980/‚Äô90s, a time when companies were just beginning to think about this idea that maybe they have obligations beyond just making money for their shareholders. I think we‚Äôve moved well beyond that today so I prefer to think about ‚Äòimpact‚Äô over CSR.‚Äù

One of our leading speakers was Kim Scot: One of our leading speakers was Kim Scott, ‚Äã‚Äãauthor of Radical Candor: Be a Kickass Boss without Losing your Humanity and CEO Coach. Like a lot of us, Scott once had a terrible boss, a person who thought humiliating people was a good way to motivate them. This experience is what prompted her to research what makes a ‚Äògood boss‚Äô.
In her Forward session, she spoke all ab: In her Forward session, she spoke all about her framework, Radical Candor. So, what is this?
‚ÄúSometimes we remember to challenge bu: ‚ÄúSometimes we remember to challenge but we forget to show that we care, and that is what I call ‚Äòobnoxious aggression.‚Äô And the Radical Candor framework is not ‚Äòobnoxious aggression,‚Äô it doesn‚Äôt give you the right to say whatever you want.‚Äù
Managing with this framework in mind all: Managing with this framework in mind allows you to challenge your co-workers efficiently, without running the risk of obnoxious aggression and unprofessional behavior. ‚ÄúA failing of many organizations is the lack of honest communication.‚Äù
A good leader has the same mental qualit: A good leader has the same mental qualities as an Arctic explorer
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just apply lots of positi: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just apply lots of positive mental attitude and muscles and just assume you‚Äôre going to do it ‚Äòbecause that‚Äôs the sort of person I am.‚Äô It‚Äôs very important that that‚Äôs in the mix, but if you‚Äôre relying too heavily on that and not enough on competence and a real understanding of all the issues that need to be grasped and resolved, you‚Äôre only minimising your risk.‚Äù
Just like this exhibition, leadership re: Just like this exhibition, leadership requires more than just a positive mental attitude. It takes perseverance, experience and being prepared to fail.
